PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam ACTING SPEAKER (Mrs Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE BILL 1985[COGNATE BILLS:EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE COLLECTION BILL 1985EXPORT INSPECTION LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Export Inspection Charge Bill 1985 concurrently with the Export Inspection Charge Collection Bill 1985 and the Export Inspection Legislation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1985. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of the Export Inspection Charge Bill 1985, the Export Inspection Charge Collection Bill 1985 and the Export Inspection Legislation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1985 is to draw together under one piece of legislation a total of 10 export inspection Acts relating to dairy, dried fruit, egg, fish and grain products. The existing separate pieces of export inspection charges legislation will remain in force until such time as the consolidating legislation is proclaimed. Therefore, even if the Opposition parties moved successfully to block this legislation it would not remove the export inspection charges. The main users of agricultural export inspection services are the meat industries, which will continue to be covered by separate legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills do not alter current charges for inspection services, although the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has revealed that new rates will apply from October this year. Agricultural exports earned $4.2 billion in 1975-76, but by 1983-84 were earning $8 billion per annum. These inspection services have been an important factor in ensuring the export of quality products and in maintaining the growth of our rural exports. The rural industries are particularly significant to our foreign exchange earning capacity as their exports earn $8 for every $1 farmers expend on imported goods. That is a beneficial ratio of 8:1. Those industries covered by this legislation are vital contributors to this export income, having earned more than $3.5 billion in 1983-84.

These Bills are designed to set inspection services for each of the five respective industries on a common footing. In presenting this legislation, the Minister has noted that export inspection is progressively moving to a system under which the intensity of the inspection processes is varied according to the records of individual firms. This should result in a more efficient use of resources. One hopes that it will. The Liberal and National parties will monitor the results of these trials. It is essential to provide cost efficient inspection services which do not lessen the ability of our industries to compete on overseas markets. I say that particularly in view of the fact that the Government has loaded on to the shoulders of the export industries 50 per cent of the export inspection charges for those services. Of course, not all our competing nations are imposing that charge upon our exporters, but it does add to the further difficulty of so many of our industries in achieving competitiveness with other nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a Liberal-National Party policy.

—I will tell the honourable member what our policy is right now if he will just be patient and listen. The Liberal and National parties are concerned that export inspection charges are unduly weighing down the vital primary export industries which represent the main source of our national export income.

SPEECH.PARA: On several occasions, increases were deferred by our parties and the Australian Democrats where it was anticipated that the export performance of these industries would be harmed. Very few, if any, of our competing nations apply such charges; therefore, the Australian cost recovery policy in regard to export inspection charges is further adversely affecting our competitiveness. Not only are this inflexible wage system and the highest on-costs in the world reducing our competitiveness on export markets but also inspection charges, with increases of up to 1,000 per cent for some industries since the Hawke Government came to office, have been not just disastrous but irresponsible as well. Therefore, last year the coalition, the Liberal and National parties, announced that export inspection charges should be met by the Commonwealth Government. The coalition stated:

A coalition Government will . . . ensure that a high standard export inspection service is maintained where circumstances of trade require that certification by the Commonwealth be provided. The Commonwealth will co-operate with industry bodies and the States concerned to ensure that the inspection is efficiently conducted without duplication and at the Commonwealth's expense.
This point is made very clear in the coalition's policy on primary industry released last year. So, let there be no doubt in anybody's mind where we stand in regard to export inspection charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't get away from the fact that you could have done that here four years ago.
—Order! The honourable member for Capricornia will cease interjecting.
—I am just trying to put him straight on the matter, Madam Acting Speaker.
—Order! The honourable member will not debate the matter with the Chair; he will cease interjecting.
—The fact of the matter is that this Hawke Labor Government, of which the honourable member interjecting is a member, has been responsible for increases of up to 1,000 per cent in inspection charges.
—How much?

—Up to 1,000 per cent; that was for the oyster industry. There has been a 200 per cent increase in beef industry inspection charges. If anybody says that that is a fair go, God help us, he has a distorted, warped view of what is fair and just. We have made very clear where we stand. I hope that in the Hawke Government's review of policy, which surely it will undertake at some stage, it too will see the stupidity of imposing charges on export industries when competing nations are not doing the same thing.

SPEECH.PARA: The main Bill before the House, the inspection charges Bill, allows each product to be divided into classes according to type of packing, the form in which the commodity is exported and the inspection system applicable in its manufacture. This will facilitate the transfer of some inspection resources away from products or manufacturers with a good track record into other areas which are more problem prone. I share the Minister's hope that this will improve the cost efficiency of inspection services.

The Bill also introduces charges for the inspection of canned and processed fruit and vegetables. Similar legislation presented last year was deferred pending reports from the Interim Inspection Policy Council and the Department of Primary Industry.

The Minister in his second reading speech specified that the charges will be set at 0.5 cents per kilogram or per litre. Clause 7 (3) of the Bill sets a maximum fee of twice this amount-one cent per litre or kilogram. The 0.5 cents fee will raise an additional $330,000 a year to fund the fruit and vegetable inspection services. Any increase in these charges will further retard the competitiveness and development of these export industries. For example, producers of canned and frozen vegetables are finding there are only very limited openings on foreign markets. Additional increases in inspection fees would serve only to weaken export industries' capacity to maximise their export potential.

Canned and frozen vegetables are already subject to strict quality controls on the domestic market. The major purpose of export inspections would be to ensure that the various product grades required by importing nations are properly met. There is therefore no justification for the imposition of heavy inspection charges on this manufacturing industry. Ideally, the performance of these exporters would be served by a decision to drop these charges altogether. Certainly, there will be no justification for increases over the next few years in the charges set by this Bill.

The canned fruit industry is among those concerned about the provisions of this Bill. As the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) well knows-he brought this matter to my attention on behalf of the industry in his electorate-the industry is concerned. It has been under a lot of pressure for some time on international markets. It has been in touch with him and me as it is very concerned about the consequences of now having to bear export inspection charges when it in fact meets some of the highest health regulations in the world to serve domestic requirements. Processed fruit and vegetable preparations have justifiably earned a reputation for high quality on the world market, and the suppliers are well aware that their $60m earnings per annum depend on that reputation being maintained.

I welcome the Minister's statement that a system of inspection involving less intensive monitoring of product, premises and processing operations will shortly begin field trialling. The canning fruit industry has participated on export markets for 60 years unencumbered by inspection charges, and every effort must be made to minimise the effects of the new charge imposed by this legislation. However, I note that it is more than 12 months ago that discussions were held in Canberra between the canning fruit industry and members of the Export Inspection Service. Concern has been expressed to me that although it was agreed at these talks that the canned fruit industry should move quickly towards a system of ad hoc inspections which would see the elimination of inspectors fully employed throughout the processing season, we have reached the stage of only talking about field trialling. Every effort should be made to conduct these field trials as soon as possible so that the burden of the new inspection charges can be reduced.

The remaining two Bills, Madam Acting Speaker, the Export Inspection Charge Collection and the Export Inspection (Consequential Amendments) Bills, also formalise the consolidation of the present 10 Acts. The collection Bill sets a limit of 28 days for payment, after which time the issue of further permits will be suspended until the payment has been made. Penalties for a range of offences relating to the keeping of records, failure to lodge returns or unauthorised interference with inspection procedures are set at a maximum $1,000 fine or six months imprisonment, or both.
While the Opposition does not oppose these Bills, I draw attention to other unnecessary and harmful changes made to the export inspection services by the Hawke Labor Government. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that excessive increases in export inspection charges over the past 2 years have seriously damaged the export competitiveness of Australian agricultural industries in a period of intense world competition against other nations which do not impose these export cost burdens'.

It is commonly known that the meat producers and other large-scale exporters have been subjected to a cost increase for inspection charges, as I said a moment ago, of 200 per cent and more in two years. The meat industry is a notable case. What is less commonly known is that some smaller industries have been slugged even harder. I referred a moment ago-and I repeat it-to the fact that I was contacted by the oyster growers seeking advice about what could be done about the 1,000 per cent increase in their inspection fees under the Labor Government. The increases have been justified by this Government on the basis of a 50 per cent cost recovery.

Budget figures show that collections, including recovery of overdue payments from 1983-84, will represent 76 per cent of outlays. So instead of its being a 50 per cent cost recovery it is now apparent that it will be a 76 per cent cost recovery, unless the Budget Papers are wrong. I would like the Minister to answer that. It is all very well to say that there is a 50 per cent cost recovery; the Budget Papers show that there will end up being a 76 per cent cost recovery.

How are we to ascertain whether we do not have too many people out in the field doing these sorts of inspections? How are we to know whether those people, engaged through the Public Service or the bureaucracy, are achieving the levels of productivity that these export industries are expected to achieve in order to maintain their export and world markets? This is the sort of situation that needs the closest monitoring whilever the Government imposes this sort of cost recovery arrangement on the producers, many of whom are battling to make just enough to buy the household food.

So many farmers in the Australian community today earn only a quarter of average weekly earnings, or less. The average income of farmers in this country is $7,000. So let nobody get any ideas in his head that the farmers are the wealthy members of this community, because they are not. They are becoming the new poor in the Australian community. Ours will be a very poor society if this situation continues. There is no doubt that the agricultural sector, spread right across this vast continent, with very scattered populations-the rural hinterland of Australia-has been producing much of the wealth that is necessary to keep public servants in jobs, politicians paid and the services of this country going.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Government hates them.
—The Government seems to hate them. I ask: Why does it hate the farmers? The real difficulty for the primary export industries lies with the impact--
—What about the shearers?

—I do not hate the shearers. I was a shearer myself once. Shearers are one sector of the community who really have to do something-they have to push the shorn sheep down the chute-to get their money. They are really genuine blokes. That is why the honourable member for Port Adelaide has his better moments; he has been in a good industry. The real difficulty for the primary export industries lies with the impact of Labor's sharp cost increases on our competitiveness. Inspection charges are virtually non-existent among our overseas competitors, although the Minister informs us that some either are about to implement or are implementing such charges on their exporters. I am interested in learning more about the suggested intentions of these competing nations. The massive cost hikes of the past two years have come on top of a devastating, four-year drought. A very big percentage of eastern Australia is now facing another crippling drought. Apart from the coastal belt and the inland of Queensland--
—And Richmond.

—Apart from those areas, including Richmond, a very substantial sector of western and central western New South Wales and Victoria is now experiencing what has been one of the most frightening autumn deficiencies in rainfall for many years. So many places have had the lowest rainfalls on record between the end of October and the end of April. So let it be a warning. The big drought problem has not gone away. If it continues it will augur badly for the economy. By increasing inspection charges by 200 per cent in the initial post-drought recovery phase, the Government has displayed a lack of sensitivity to the cost-price squeeze that is grabbing the jugular veins of our farm industries.
—It has just increased the fuel costs.
—Yes, it has. It had a great opportunity.
—Don't you talk about fuel costs. There was a 30 per cent increase under Fraser.
—Order! The honourable member will cease interjecting. I understand he is taking part in the debate later.
—No, I am not.
—He will stop interjecting now. He is straining the patience of the Chair quite a bit.

—I think we ought to have a debate on fuel costs, because they are affecting every Australian. The Hawke Labor Government promised before it came to office that there would be a 3c per litre cut in the price of fuel. What has happened? We have seen excises increased by 56.6 per cent and fuel prices increased by 32.5 per cent. This recent increase is due to the devaluation of the depreciating currency which has come about because of the lack of confidence in the Hawke economic policies. The Government had its chance to reduce fuel prices by reducing the excise, but it chose not to. It has pocketed $670m at the expense of every Australian motorist, at the expense of the farmers, at the expense of industry and at the expense of jobs-wait and see.
—Mick Young has fleeced them again.

—I do not think Mick Young would do that. There are other more evil characters around who would, but Mick Young is not a bad bloke. Needless to say, there is an ugly mood welling up throughout rural Australia. As the Minister for Primary Industry knows, the farmers are getting angry. As they used to say in another age, the peasants are revolting. I think people need to be well aware of the mood that exists out there, because they are getting worried.

SPEECH.PARA: Many farmers have been out there battling, not just for one generation but for two or three generations. They are having great difficulty in encouraging their young people to go back into the country because the young people are now starting to question whether anybody really cares. That augurs badly for the economic, social and demographic structure of this nation. It is very important for people in all political parties, wherever they might live-particularly those who live in Melbourne or Sydney, the big cities-to understand the enormous pressures being imposed on those people battling to make a living from the soil.

Before the election the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a point of listening to the concerns of the $11 billion farming community. He said: 'Yes, I can see the effects of rising costs, particularly government charges. We really do need to take some firm action. How about a summit?' We had so many summits at one stage that one had a job to find him; he was running behind a summit on practically every issue. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said, he ran out of mountain tops. The announcement on new dairy marketing arrangements has shown that Labor's hearing is spot on before an election but is decidedly deaf after polling day. The farm costs summit turned out to be an utter farce. The Government side-stepped the areas where it could give immediate relief, such as reducing fuel excise, removing inspection charges, removing the tariff on grain harvesters and abandoning the assets test for the bona fide, poor, aged farmers who are apparently capital rich but cash poor.

I mention grain harvesters, because if ever there were an iniquitous situation, this is it. There is a 15 per cent tariff imposed on headers, costing the farmers $14m, to protect 260 jobs in a marginal seat on the outskirts of Melbourne.

The same objective could have been achieved with a $2m bounty. But no, the greed of the Treasury and those who are collecting revenue dictated the other course. They decided to take it out of the pockets of the farmers, some $14m or $15m to save 260 jobs. I am not against saving jobs-we should be trying to save jobs-but I am very much against that way of achieving it because it falls heavily upon a small section of the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —And devaluation has added to those costs.

—Yes, indeed. The primary producers of this nation have been treated with contempt. Clearly the National Farmers Federation has been given the big A by the Prime Minister and his Ministers at the second summit conference on farm costs. In introducing a massive increase in export inspection charges, the Hawke Labor Government has badly underestimated the tolerance of farmers and overstated their ability to meet such government charges. The attitudes of honourable members opposite had better change pretty quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: The abolition of these excessive inspection charges would be one fledgling step in the right direction for this Government. Not only would the rural sector be given one means of showing the cost-price dive, but all Australians would benefit. Rural exports account for 35 to 50 per cent of Australia's total export income. World markets have rarely been more competitive, yet our farmers have to carry a heavy export tax that is virtually unknown outside this country. Our foreign debt is escalating towards the $60 billion mark, yet we slap on these heavy increases in the costs of production which are weighing our industries down in the international competitive stakes. Even the complete abolition of export inspection charges would be only one small salvo in the cost-price battle, but it would be a start and an indication of the Government's sincere concern for the problems of the farmers and their families.

In February the Bureau of Agricultural Economics forecast an acceleration of the decline in the terms of trade from 2.4 per cent per annum to 4 per cent this financial year. Since then, the 22 per cent devaluation has helped the statistics but has not improved the long term farm outlook. Increased export earnings flowing from the devaluation have cut the decline in terms of trade back to 2 per cent in the short term. But this is only temporary because with devaluation of that magnitude the input costs and the costs of imported goods will rise, and fuel is a great example of this. In the financial year 1985-86 most of those engaged in farm industries can expect that their input costs will be much higher. This will make their task of maintaining present markets and obtaining new ones even greater. By the start of the 1985-86 financial year the higher farm input costs, combined with a 10 per cent increase in petrol prices, will cause the situation to further deteriorate. That does not take account of the indexation of excise to the consumer price index. That is a tricky little one. A piece of legislation has gone through both Houses to ensure that every time the CPI goes up the revenue to the Government will go up.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was $25m last year.

—Twenty-five million dollars! That was just ripped off. As a result of the devaluation and the introduction of a broad-based tax, we will see a big increase in inflation and another big increase in the price of fuel. I do not think people will be able to afford cars before long. It is getting that way now. I saw an economic analysis which showed that it is costing a person $118 a week to drive a Ford Falcon. That is based on the use of a full tank of petrol. That is what it costs to own a car today with registration, insurance, repayments to the hire purchase company, maintenance and depreciation. For a small car such as a Honda Civic, which my daughter drives-she cannot afford it but she still drives the thing-it costs about $87 a week. I do not think kids can afford cars without doing themselves enormous damage. Every time the price of petrol goes up, the more difficult it is for them to own a car. I hope the knackeries will not go on killing horses because the kids may have to get on Shanks's pony or a good pony before long.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the huge increases in the cost of inspection services, the failure of the Government to take any meaningful action at its farm costs summit and its failure to stave off cost increases from the devaluation of the dollar, the Liberal and National parties call for the immediate abolition of inspection charges on rural exports as a step towards recovering some of the ground we have lost in our international economic standing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes, Madam Acting Speaker, and I reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Export Inspection Charge Bill and cognate Bills, it is important to get on record immediately that the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), who has just concluded his speech, was part of a government that was notable for its economic mismanagement. I am amazed that he can come into this place and almost reduce us to tears by telling us how tough things are and that, really, members of the Opposition are the people who can manage an economy effectively and that they are the people who know all about economic management. Their record was pretty shoddy. In fact, the public recognises that they were guilty of economic vandalism the likes of which we had not seen since the Great Depression.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the honourable member for Gwydir, in his closing remarks, spoke about knackeries and the killing of horses. Another thing we have to remember is that it was under the previous Government, of which he was a member, that horse meat found its way into export meat, and it was under that Government that kangaroo meat found its way into export meat. If I were a member of an Opposition party I would not go too far into the meat export area because the Liberal-National Party record was pretty rough. So I advise Opposition members to stay out of it.

Why is it that when I went to Japan the Japanese asked me whether or not Australian steaks actually hopped or whether they stopped at the winning post? Under the previous Government export inspection and control of the export market was very bad. Several times in this place we have heard the honourable member for Gwydir raise the issue of beef exports to Japan. The market was completely killed by his Government's inability to maintain proper standards for meat exports. Let us not forget the historical circumstances. Honourable members opposite were members of a government which saw enormous decreases in Australia's economic performance and, certainly, experienced a scandal relating to meat exports. Let us not talk about knackeries and horses, and so on because, very clearly, the performance of the previous Government left a bit to be desired.

Another thing that is really quite staggering is that the Opposition's amendment proposes to remove export charges. If we go back to the record, it was the Fraser Government which introduced export inspection charges. Honourable members opposite cannot run away from their history. They were part of the group that tended to bring it in. Let us not suddenly pretend that all that history is forgotten. Let us not depart from history and imagine that they were not involved. In fact, when they were in power they did introduce export inspection charges, and the 50 per cent recovery regime that we are talking about in this legislation was introduced when they were in government. I quote:
The Balderstone group on Agricultural Policy established by and reported in 1982 to the Fraser Government stated: 'Existing 50 per cent recovery arrangements should be continued'.

Where did these recovery arrangements start? They started in 1979 under the Fraser Government. Let us not imagine that this proposal was just the action of the Hawke Government. What we have done is try to tidy up the mess honourable members opposite have left us with. I will talk about that in a minute. The 50 per cent recovery arrangements were started under the previous Government. The Balderstone Working Group to provide a Policy Discussion Paper on Agriculture, whose report Fraser accepted, stated that the 50 per cent recovery arrangements should continue. When we are talking in a debate like this, let us get our history right. History shows that the previous Government introduced the 50 per cent recovery arrangements. The other thing that needs to be noted is that the honourable member for Gwydir, and others who will follow him in this debate, behave in this place as though suddenly the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Hawke Government have introduced these export inspection arrangements.

Let us look at the legislation that we are consolidating in this Bill. We are consolidating the Dairy Products (Export Inspection Charge) Act of 1982, the Dried Fruit (Export Inspection Charge) Act of 1981, the Eggs (Export Inspection Charge) Act of 1982, the Fish (Export Inspection Charge) Act of 1981 and the Grain (Export Inspection Charge) Act of 1979. Who was in government during that time? Clearly, the honourable member for Gwydir was part of that Government. Clearly, it was the Fraser Government that was in power. Many of us try to forget that we ever had a Fraser Government, but let us not forget in terms of the accuracy of this debate that this was the time when that legislation was introduced. What we are doing in this Bill is consolidating all those pieces of legislation. That is one important thing that needs to be emphasised.

The second thing that needs to be emphasised-the honourable member for Gwydir has said this and the point is correct-is that we are introducing a monitoring system which more effectively reflects the performance of the exporter. The previous Government had a flat rate system. What we are doing is operating in a tiered system whereby, if in effect the performance of an exporter is satisfactory, our charges and the export inspection arrangements will reflect that performance. We are, if you like, reflecting the performance of the exporter. In terms of the record of this debate, what we are trying to do is to react more effectively and sensitively to what the industry is about. At the same time, we are also trying to consolidate what amounts to a very large number of pieces of legislation. We are consolidating all those Bills to make a simpler process. As I have already said, those pieces of legislation were brought down prior to our coming to government. We are tidying up those things.

I now turn to another point which needs to be established with a great degree of strength in this debate. The honourable member for Gwydir spoke about the burden being borne by export industries. It was under his Government that an artificial value was maintained on the Australian currency. Consequently, in effect, exporters tended to pay because the value of the dollar was artificially controlled. We were the ones who floated the dollar and who have therefore made it more possible for exporters to operate in a more competitive environment.

If we are talking about the economic structure, let us get the record straight. The economic structure that has been established under this Government has enabled exporters to operate in a more effective environment. That is very clearly the case. The floating of the dollar has certainly done that. If the honourable member for Gwydir and others on his side were sincere in this debate, they would talk about how we can take advantage of that improved competitive environment. Let us not forget that the economic reality is that we are working in a more competitive environment. We recognise that that also applies internally. The honourable member for Gwydir spent some time saying that Australian exporters in the primary industry area face a difficult situation. We recognise that. We also recognise that attempts to bring down inflation and interest rates and wage-price pressure are very important. Our endeavours in that respect compare favourably with the endeavours of the previous Government. Under our policy, inflation is lower, interest rates are lower and the wage-price pressure is lower. No one is pretending that everything is easy, but if we are talking about economic structures and economic competitiveness let us not forget that the economy in which we are operating today is both more healthy and more competitive than it was when we came into government in 1983.

I said at the start of my remarks that the previous Government's performance left much to be desired, and that shows. When we are talking about assisting industry, let us not just get back to the business of looking at one industry in a one-off situation; let us look at the overall economic structure. It is a more competitive economic structure. We have made it possible for industries such as the primary industries to operate with reduced cost pressures in terms of wage pressures, and certainly reduced interest rate pressures. That has to be established very clearly.

Many things can be said in this debate but the pressure of time is against us. What needs to be established very clearly, because obviously the Opposition will come back to this, is that the answer is not to say: 'Let us do away with all these export inspection charges now that we are in a situation in which we can turn the world to right'. The previous Government had those inspection charges. It also had a 50 per cent recovery regime. That approach was introduced in 1979. The other thing that needs to be said is that there was a very clear rejection by the Fraser Government of the view that governments should carry completely the cost of export inspections. Why do we have export inspections? We have them because we are part of an international trade arrangement. It is very much up to us to establish in the minds of those importing countries that the products that we are selling them are up to standard. Very clearly, if we cannot establish that in their minds, we will not have those export markets functioning properly.

I recognise that sometimes non-tariff barriers are erected by some of the importing countries with which we are dealing. We recognise, as would those opposite, that there are other ways of getting at Australian exporters. That is a collective problem that we have in trying to deal with importing countries. But we cannot abandon the export inspection arrangements and thereby hope to retain our markets. Therefore, if we are to have an export inspection arrangement, what is to be the cost recovery? We seek a 50 per cent recovery of costs on behalf of the industry vis-a-vis government. That view was adopted by the Fraser Government, so let us not forget that matter. In terms of the way we are proceeding with this legislation, we are consolidating a number of previous pieces of legislation to make a more sensible array. We are also reflecting the fact that the monitoring system can react to the performance of the exporter. If the exporter performs very well, the volume of monitoring will go down. We recognise that. So, it is a performance based export inspection system.

Finally, concerning the export inspection charges issue that has been raised by the Opposition, we have to get the record straight. The Opposition introduced that 50 per cent recovery arrangement. We are continuing it. Let us not imagine that somehow the Opposition has all right on its side, because it has not. It cannot continue to conceal the history of this matter from the Australian community. I am pleased to commend these Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that every time there is a legitimate complaint from the Opposition regarding the extravagances of this Government, the only defence the Government seems to be able to give us is a history lesson. It justifies all the bad things that it does on its perception of how a previous government may have done something. It is about time, after what is now almost three years of the present Government, that it started to stand up and say: 'We take responsibility for what we do. We are prepared to answer to the community for what we do'. Furthermore-
—You have to be kidding.

—The honourable member says that I have to be kidding. That is a very good example of the attitude of this Government. As long as it can fudge the issue and make it appear to the public that it is not the Government's fault, that all the disasters are not its fault, and that none of the matters in which it has succeeded have any relationship to the actions of a previous Liberal government, as long as it can carry on in that fashion, this Government believes it is successful.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has ridden on the tail of previous economic policy. Anybody who is silly enough to suggest in this place that any government, by its decisions, can turn an economy on its head in a matter of perhaps 18 months-certainly six or 12 months-is an economic fool, and economic fools we have in plenty on the other side of the House. The reality is that we will get changes to the economy only over time. It would not matter what a government did in its first six months of office, one would find that the economic decisions of a previous government would have a major influence.

When we find that so many of the benefits are attributed to the accord, because of certain movements in the consumer price index and therefore in inflation, we overlook entirely what happened in the time of the previous Liberal Government. Most of those benefits occurred by coincidence, not because of the accord. The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) talked about economic mismanagement. A method of altering the value of the Australian dollar was in force before we floated it. It was responding to the pressures of the international money markets. Those decisions were taken on a daily basis and, although I am very pleased that the Government chose to do away with that mechanism and let the market have its direct effect, the reality is that this situation is a problem for the Government because it is a demonstration of what the international community now thinks of the economic management of which the Government is so proud.

The Export Inspection Charge Bill seeks to entrench further the costs that are applicable to the industry, particularly to the meat industry. The Government says: 'We are here to charge only 50 per cent, and that was the fault of the previous Government'. But we have to look at what that 50 per cent represents. The 50 per cent used to be 50 per cent of an amount of over $60m in 1979-80. This meant that $31m went to the producers via the processors. In 1983-84 inspection costs were $79m, and half of those costs are charged to the industry, which is an increase of 150 per cent. That is what we are on about. We are not on about the percentages; we are on about the realities. These increases have occurred as a result of the activities of this Government. We are well aware that while the cattle kill, for instance, has dropped dramatically from 8.8 million to seven million, this massive increase in total costs has occurred during that period.

We have seen a substantial decrease in the number of meatworks operating. In fact 40 works have closed over the last five years. What have we seen concerning the number of government employed inspectors? We have seen that the number has been reduced from 1,794 to 1,632, which was the figure about a year ago. There has been no reduction in numbers because we have a Public Service mentality in relation to the employment of meat inspectors who operate in a cyclical and seasonal industry. That is quite improper.

I have spoken in this Parliament time and again in an attempt to work out why it is costing the processor between $6 and $10 for the inspection of a beast. That is the cost the processor pays, and that is only 50 per cent of the cost; so we have to double that figure. The charge by a local authority for inspecting a beast in an abattoir in my electorate is only $2.80. I am not making a comparison between the $6 to $10 and the $2.80. The $2.80 is charged by a local authority in my electorate which gives a very adequate meat inspection service. It does not provide veterinary services but it provides everything else. If we increased that charge even to $3.50, 100 per cent of the cost of the meat inspection service is met by a local authority in my electorate. It is providing qualified inspectors and doing all the things that the Commonwealth does with its inspection service.

Why is it that the service can be provided at that cost when the Commonwealth cost is so much higher? That is what the industry is on about. It would not mind if it had to pay 50 per cent of $2.80 or, say, $3.50, but it is certainly very upset with the cost that this Government chooses to levy and tries to excuse away by saying: 'The previous Government did something similar to that'. The previous Government did not; it charged substantially less. In my view, we still charged too much.

The basic meat inspection service should not be provided by government. Importing companies do not require those inspectors on the floor to be employed by government. I established that fact by asking a question in this Parliament on a previous occasion. All that is needed is for us to supervise the inspection; that is what the importing companies demand of us. But we have this bureaucracy that wants to maintain its power and its staff numbers, and it promotes arguments that do not exist.

The report of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry recommended that, as soon as possible, the basic inspection services provided by the so-called meat inspectors become the responsibility of the industry. But what does this Bill do? The fruit industry, where things are already quite satisfactory and where the label that is on the product is the best recommendation of quality, knows that if it does not maintain quality, the consumers will very quickly identify that label. That industry is already meeting health standards within Australia which are very high. We find that the Government now wants to get in to that area. To people in that particular industry this Bill represents another $330,000 cost that they are not paying now. I can guarantee that the reputation of the Export Inspection Service is not such that it will raise the market potential of the industry. Not long ago, for about the fifth time I raised other problems in regard to its handling of halal slaughter of meat. I may come back to that matter shortly.

The reality is that the Service gives very little to industry. It is a disaster. It certainly has not improved our reputation. As the honourable member for Stirling mentioned a little while ago, it contributed dramatically to the fall in the reputation of Australia's exports. He wants to blame the Fraser Government. The fact is that as a result of inquiries under the Fraser Government a large number of inspectors were stood down. They have now all been reinstated. How can the Government members, as policy makers, say that they have done anything about that problem? The Government has employed more inspectors for little gain. As I said, the costs have jumped from $31m in 1979-80 to $79m in 1983-84 and they are going up even further. How can Government members claim to be good managers? How can the honourable member for Stirling talk as he did? He wanted to give us another history lesson. He was trying to excuse the obvious inadequacies of his Government and its policies in this particular arena.

Not so long ago the Government had great concern for the terms of trade. To date, devaluation has not had a major effect in assisting the farming sector. Yes, it has propped up prices that were falling on world markets anyway, but it ignores the huge cost to farmers of increased inputs from overseas. Much of their input, such as chemicals, is being increased. On a typical farm in my electorate chemicals cost up to $50,000 a year and the cost of fuel is a similar amount. Unfortunately, the farmers have to pay the costs first. The returns on a wheat crop come after that form of expenditure. So they are not seeing a great advantage yet from devaluation although I think they, too, would approve of that move. We are stuck with the fact that because of their great concern they called on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and some of his senior Ministers to put their case. What did they get out of that? They were told that their figures were wrong. It is the same as what happened to all those poor people who put their figures into the Department of Social Security so that they could maintain their pension. They were told that those figures were wrong. The fact that some of them are now starving apparently has little influence on the Department of Social Security. The farmers went before the Prime Minister and all their figures were questioned. They were told to go back to the drawing board, but the Prime Minister nominated a time five weeks hence for that summit to continue to give time for both sides to review their figures.

It is my understanding that it was eventually agreed that the farmers' figures were right and that their terms of trade are as bad as they argued. Did that help them? No. The day before the very day that they were to meet again, the Prime Minister announced a continuation of the parity pricing policy arrangements and a 4c a litre increase in fuel. They got no assistance. They were told to go away, that there was no help for them, and an additional tax burden was added. Although our side of politics supports the concept of parity pricing-I believe it is essential for our national welfare-there is no reason for the Government to continue increasing its excise charges as it has and refuse to rebate the full amount to the rural sector as was always done. If someone wants a history lesson, this was always done by the Liberal-National Party governments of the past. The fraud that is being perpetrated on people now, whereby the Government is going to reindex the lower figure at the same rate as the higher figure and continue to increase the gap, is disgraceful. I am pleased that our parties will oppose that and try to reinstate the former situation, as we have promised in our policy.

We have a number of further concerns regarding these inspection services. I have mentioned the costs again and again. I must repeat that it is possible to carry out these inspection services for a fraction of what the Commonwealth charges and an even lesser fraction of what it costs the Australian taxpayer. If honourable members think that is all, I inform them that on 17 April this year the Cattle Council of Australia sent a telex to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) expressing its concern. It stated:

The Cattle Council is concerned at a directive which has been in force for some time from your Department to meat inspectors. I understand that the directive instructs inspectors not to cross officially authorised union picket lines where such action would either run the risk of widening an industrial dispute, or risk physical harm to the inspectors.

Of course, any crossing of picket lines could be guaranteed to do both of those things. We know very well that the union movement is prepared to use muscle and injure people to gain whatever its particular desires happen to be. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) told us yesterday that there is no way in the world that he would take any action against a union because it would inflame it. Clearly, were the Commonwealth meat inspectors to cross the picket lines, the dispute would be inflamed. So crossing the lines is banned. In other words, as has been pointed out in this telex, two people who set up a picket line can stop the whole works because the EIS employees will not cross the picket line. The instruction says nothing as to the relevance of the dispute, whether the dispute is correct or whether it is in the interests of Australia nationally. Again, it is just an example of the Government bowing to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the various unions and taking its instructions as it does on a daily basis. People are complaining bitterly of the Government's attitude in telling people that they must not have anything to do with the dispute even if the dispute is not in the national interest. We wonder why, therefore, the Government has to raise such huge costs against primary producers to provide a service which in fact they probably do not even need or desire. These are the problems we have at the moment.

The honourable member for Stirling mentioned meat substitution. It is interesting that although the honourable member for Stirling was telling us all about the problems of a previous government regarding meat substitution something worse is going on in our very important wheat industry at this time. The New South Wales grain handling authorities cannot prevent their wheat from being mixed up. There is nothing deliberate and horrible about it; they just keep putting sprouted grain in with good grain that is going to very delicate markets such as Japan, where the wheat is made into noodles and mixed wheat is a problem. Within the last week it has happened again. We have not heard much of it in the Press, but another load of substandard wheat has been sent to Japan or loaded into a ship. It is in fact mixed wheat. Whom do we blame for this? Do we blame the Fraser Government? We either blame the Wran Government in New South Wales, or we--

TALK.START.PARA: —Now you are attacking wheat farmers. You're a beaut.

—No, I am not. I am pointing out that the wheat farmer has not done this. It has occurred in the handling of the wheat after it leaves the wheat farmer. Farmers in my electorate are now willing to take legal action against the New South Wales Government, its grain handling authorities or the individuals involved to recover the $25,000 that they have estimated that it has cost Western Australian farmers for the gross inadequacy of that long time Labor State, New South Wales, when it comes to grain handling. It is a disaster. If the Government wants to talk about substitution, the substitution of half a shipload of sprouted grain in what is supposed to be the highest quality of wheat leaving Australia is certainly no recommendation for the export inspection services that are provided. It is a disaster. It just goes to show that these history lessons that we keep getting from the Government are not proper and, in fact, there is plenty of blame on the other side.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is cost. This amalgamation procedure is doing nothing to reduce the cost; it is increasing the costs in the fruit export industry. A paper entitled 'Facts on the Government's Meat Export Tax' put out by the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council tells us that jobs have dropped from 39,000 in 1979 to 29,000 in 1984. To a great extent the Council blames the extra burden of costs that inefficient and inappropriate export inspection services have imposed upon the system. One of its submissions says that the producer's gross profit was only 2.2c per kilogram but the charge for export inspection was to be 2.4c a kilogram. How do we do our sums then?

In all, although this legislation cleans up the situation, it does not go to where the problem lies. The problem lies in costs and inefficiency. The cost has done nothing to address that area; it has no intention of addressing it. If the Government says that farmers should pay 50 per cent of a charge which is about five times higher than what is necessary-I have proved that-of course the farmers have every reason to complain. I am glad to see that our government in the future will remove those charges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In seconding the amendment-

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Humphreys) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The two Opposition speakers, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), of course repeated the usual myths that they continue to repeat whenever this subject comes up. The main claim by the honourable member for Gwydir was that the 50 per cent recovery policy is not followed by all competitor countries. A recent survey has revealed that, with the exception of New Zealand, all major competitor countries charge for export inspection. New Zealand is in the process of moving towards 100 per cent cost recovery and is phasing it in over three years. The Opposition says it believes that the costs should be borne by the Government. Implementing charges to recover government export inspection costs was a Liberal-National Party initiative. That policy was consistent with a range of other cost recovery measures introduced by the Liberal-National Party Government. The Opposition now says that any additional charges on export inspection will severely impact on export competitiveness. The competitiveness of canned fruits on export markets has been a long term issue and it existed long before inspection charges were introduced. Simplified inspection procedures will enable canners to reduce their inspection charges; in other words, contrary to what the honourable member for O'Connor said, in every place we are moving to limit charges and reduce as quickly as we can the number of people involved in inspection.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor claimed that there is no requirement for meat inspection to be undertaken on the slaughter floor, and he said that this so-called fact was established as a result of a question in the House. The fact is that it is a clear condition of the United States and Japanese governments and the European Community that each carcass must be inspected on the slaughter floor. Moreover, the United States and the EC demand that ante- and post-mortem veterinary inspection be carried out, and the United States and the EC regularly send representations to Australia to review our inspection procedures to ensure that they meet these requirements.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FISHING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILL:FISHERIES LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill concurrently with the Fisheries Levy Amendment Bill. There being no objection, that course will be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill and the Fisheries Levy Amendment Bill give the Commonwealth power to set up and implement management plans for Australian fisheries. Under these plans limits can be set on the extent of fishing activity in Australian waters by allocating a fishing capacity, to be known as units, among licensed fishermen. Management plans for the rock lobster, northern prawn and southern bluefin tuna fisheries have already been adopted and will be formalised by this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Under this legislation, managed fisheries will be able to extend their licence period beyond the current limit of 12 months. The levy Bill amends the Fisheries Licences Levy Act 1984 to impose a levy to the units allocated for each licence. Levy proceeds fund the administration of the management plans, and there are no direct financial implications for the Commonwealth Government.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the three management plans formalised by these Bills have been sought by the fisheries. The Opposition will not be seeking any changes to the legislation other than a minor change that I have asked my office to forward to the office of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) relating to appeal provisions in clause 28 where the Minister or the Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry chooses to revoke the licence of a fisherman. That will be dealt with at a later stage. We advance this amendment only to be helpful and constructive, not to be obstructive. I hope the Minister acknowledges that. However, I wish to make it clear that in government the Liberal and National parties would not be automatically committed to the introduction of new management plans for other fisheries under a legislative structure. We would need to be convinced that there was no other means of achieving these goals before agreeing to extend the management plan concept. In particular, there is a degree of uncertainty over the role of the States. I do not say that in any sense to knock what the Government is doing. It may be the right way through the problem; only time will tell.

The industry has expanded significantly over the past two decades. It is already subject to a wide range of State Government controls. The Constitution gives the Federal Government power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of fisheries in Australian waters beyond territorial limits. Those limits are generally defined as three nautical miles seaward of the low water mark. The State and Northern Territory governments have the powers to regulate fisheries within their respective territorial limits. The major Federal legislation controlling the industry today, the Fisheries Act of 1952, is structured on these constitutional provisions.

The Act provides for the licensing of fishing vessels and fishermen in proclaimed waters and the issuing of such regulations as entry limitations, boat and gear restrictions, fish size regulations and seasonal and area closures. An amendment in 1973 provided for the rational utilisation of fisheries as well as the conservation of resources. There has been a significant switch of views over the role of the Commonwealth since the 1952 legislation was enacted. At that time the States believed they lacked certain powers assumed by this Act, but today there is a growing body of legal opinion that the States do in fact enjoy wider powers than had been believed.

In government the Liberal and National parties would be seeking further clarification of these powers to reassess the need for Federal controls such as those imposed by this Bill. I stress, however, that our parties do recognise the need for industry stability and a degree of certainty on which individual fishermen can plan their future activity. The southern bluefin tuna industry, for example, is among those fisheries which have been placed at a disadvantage by the existing arrangements. There has been a demonstrable need to strengthen current regulations in the face of a doubling of production over six or seven years and consequent falling returns to each industry member.

Under the new management plan the number of boats will be almost halved to a couple of dozen and the annual catch pared back from 21,000 tonnes in 1982-83 to about 14,500 tones. As one industry member put it to me, those intending to stay in the industry have been able to buy out those who wish to leave, and those withdrawing have been able to do so efficiently and with dignity. This is not to say, however, that all fisheries would welcome similar management plans. I detect from my own liaison with the industry a growing demand for self-management practices free of the rigidities of a formal government plan and individual transferable quota system. Those fisheries characterised by a relatively small number of participants may be able to achieve their optimum levels of activity without the need for Federal restrictions on their catch.

This point was developed at the recent Bureau of Agricultural Economics Outlook Conference, which I attended, by one of the three industry discussion leaders, Mr Michael Thomas. Mr Thomas is the immediate past president of the South Australian branch of the Tuna Boat Owners' Association of Australia and a member of the Interim Fishing Industry Consultative Panel, a highly experience, very intelligent and well informed spokesman for the fishing industry. In his address to the conference he recalled the Industries Assistance Commission recommendation that the Government allow the southern bluefin tuna fishery completely to manage its own affairs. In a general comment on the Australian fishing industry he pointed to industry fragmentation and a lack of economic expertise within fishing authorities as the main reasons why there had been little attempt to introduce self-management practices in the pre-1975 era. However, Mr Thomas painted a much brighter picture for the future. He told the Outlook Conference in part:
The industry now takes a far more responsible attitude towards the development of management measures.
There is now a greater awareness of what fisheries management is all about, and this can only bring benefits.
I do not, personally, believe that fishermen have reached the stage today where they could take the full responsibility for managing their particular fishery.
I am, however, confident that the industry will ultimately have the capacity to undertake the managing of fisheries in their own right.

I believe that self-management should be the ultimate goal, and perhaps the Minister believes the same, although it must not be attempted before it can be transferred with total confidence, and I think that is important. In making these comments I stress that the ultimate objectives of management, autonomous or government-operated, must be to maximise economic performance; preserve marine resources; and give participants an ability to plan ahead with confidence. One of the most crucial difficulties has been availability of finance. The management plans and extension of licence periods under these Bills should greatly enhance the borrowing capacity of individual fishermen. A lack of finance has without doubt been one of the major problems holding back development, particularly in the less-established fisheries. This was one of the concerns raised by the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce in 1982. The Committee found that evidence presented to it did not support the findings of earlier studies and in fact showed that certain sectors of the fishing industry were disadvantaged in terms of access to financial assistance and credit facilities. Perhaps the introduction of new banks and perhaps more competition in the banking sector will make that a little less of a problem to that industry as well as to other industries. Established fishermen in the more lucrative areas were the least affected, while those undertaking ventures of a developmental nature involving moderate or high risks had considerable difficulty in establishing adequate financial backing.

Australia's great primary industries have been built on the entrepreneurial spirit of reward for risk-taking, and the fishing industry is no exception. Any steps which the Government can take to improve the industry's financial capacity are welcome. Over two decades the industry has grown from a very small scale to a point today where it earns more than $400m per annum. In recent years 75 per cent or more of earnings have been raised on export markets. The introduction of these management plans underlines the need to develop new fisheries rather than over exploit those already at peak production. This development will occur only if adequate finance is available. The industry and its lending authorities can be assured that the Liberal and National parties in government would undertake any review of management plans in the knowledge that financial commitment must be based on long term industry stability.

The Opposition wishes to give speedy passage to these Bills. However, I foreshadow a review by the next Liberal-National Party Government of the way controls are being imposed on the industry. The objectives of maximising the industry's economic performance while preserving our marine resources, and the need for meaningful forward planning ability, would be paramount in such a review. The Opposition will not interrupt the passage of these Bills but it is concerned at the rather draconian powers of the Minister and the Secretary to cancel or suspend fishing licences. These powers are perpetuated by the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill. I therefore foreshadow an amendment to clause 28 of the Bill during the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the second reading speech on the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said:

SPEECH.PARA: The principal purpose of the Bill is to provide clear and legally-based powers for the development and implementation of management plans in accordance with the stated objectives of the Fisheries Act 1952 . . .

I think it is important for the House to go back to what those objectives were in 1952. The Fisheries Act 1952 sought, firstly, to ensure that the living resources of the Australian Fishing Zone were not endangered by overexploitation; and secondly, that there was optimum utilisation of those resources.

I intend to address my comments to the issue of overexploitation, and in doing so I will restrict my remarks mainly to the Capricorn coast of Queensland. Unless urgent action is taken by both the State and the Federal governments the east coast trawling area between Cape Conway and Cape Capricorn faces eventual extinction as an area for commercial harvesting of seafoods. At the moment there are approximately 80 master fishermen operating from the Capricorn coast with an investment of $30m and an annual gross income of $4m. But unless action is taken to put an end to the overexploitation of central Queensland waters the future of the region's fishing industry is indeed dim. Despite constant pleas from local fishermen, overexploitation continues because of the uncontrolled presence of fishing vessels from other parts of the State and also because of the fishing practices being adopted by some outside fishing vessels which can be described only as anti-industry. These fishermen are raping the fishery and must be stopped at all costs. Whereas it is usual for fishermen to catch prawns which weigh between 30 and 50 to the kilo, some vessels are now taking prawns which weigh 100 to the kilo. The banana prawn industry has meant tens of millions of dollars for central Queensland's economy. That has been only in the last decade. However, if the present practice of taking baby prawns continues, the industry will be destroyed.

The Capricorn-Yeppoon area provides about 90 per cent of Australia's scallops but, like the banana prawns, the scallop industry on the central coast is under threat because of outside raiders. These raiders, apparently, have no interest in the future of the industry. They will take anything from the seabed if it means making a quick quid. The scallop grounds face extinction unless protective action is taken. I was speaking the other day to some fishermen on the coast who told me that, eight years ago, local fishermen could trawl for about an hour and a half and end up with 10 to 15 baskets of scallops for their efforts. Today they say that two and a half to three hours' trawling results in only two or three baskets. So one can gauge very quickly the downturn in return to these fishermen.

The situation is worsening week by week as unscrupulous fishermen continue to use small-mesh nets. In the interests of the central Queensland fishing industry and, I believe, in the interests of the Queensland economy and the general region's economy, there has to be an end to the ongoing destruction of conservation and product control in this area. These practices not only threaten the future but also are destroying local market arrangements and prices. They are disrupting the moving and unloading of catches. They are causing additional costs to locals in harbour and mooring fees. A tougher approach has to be taken to conserve these fishing grounds. For that reason I welcome the initiatives and endeavours of John Kerin.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member should refer to the Minister as the Minister, rather than by his name.
—I ask the honourable member to do so.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I accept the pathetic, childish remark made by the honourable member. He constantly makes them. One ought to send him back to kindergarten or to the pre-school he attended, if he had an education at all.
—Order! The honourable member for Capricornia will use the proper terminology when referring to the Minister, in accordance with Standing Orders.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a further point of order. I was offended by the honourable member's remarks that I was childish. He was reprimanded. Will he withdraw those remarks, please?
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw.
—To withdraw what, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—Your stupid remarks, you dill!
—He is a typical National Party clone, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Order! The honourable member for Groom will withdraw his remarks, unqualifiedly.
—I will withdraw unqualifiedly, providing the honourable member for Capricornia withdraws unqualifiedly.

—That is the worst unqualified withdrawal I have heard in my 16 years of parliamentary experience. However, let us go on. Months ago central Queensland fishermen prepared a submission on these issues which was sent to the Queensland Government. But as yet there has been no response. The fishermen believe that there should be uniform State and Federal legislation relating to the fishing industry, especially in this region. State laws place a limit on net sizes, but under Federal law virtually any sized net can be used. It is constantly claimed by the locals that vessels using the larger mesh in Federal waters constantly sneak into State waters and take undersized catches. The main thrust of the submission centred on the closure policy to be implemented in the region, especially for scallops. The request that was put forward is for a four-month closure period between 1 June and 30 September, when scallops cannot be taken. Fishermen recommend that, outside those four months, individual areas be closed when deemed necessary to allow a build-up of stock.

SPEECH.PARA: Controls are also sought over the horsepower of vessels fishing the region. It is suggested that the engine power should be limited to 450 horsepower. The fishermen believe that it is the engine power that enables what they call these foreign or outside vessels to overexploit the scallop grounds, and not necessarily the length and overall size of nets, although they also seek controls on that aspect. Coupled with this is the call for controls on mesh size. It is recommended that the minimum size to be established for scallops be 3 1/2 inches and that there be uniformity between State and Federal legislation. The Capricorn coast fishermen have submitted that the length of nets should be not more than a combined top and bottom length of 109 metres and the mesh of nets be not less than 83 millimetres for scallops and 50 millimetres for prawns.

It is urged that, as is the case with scallops, there be a closed season for prawns. While no specific period has been recommended, it is suggested that a local zone committee made up of fishermen in consultation with the Queensland Fish Management Authority should set a commencement date each year when the taking of banana prawns is outlawed. Coupled with the closed season policy, it is strongly argued that beam trawling in the estuaries, creeks and rivers for banana prawns be phased out. Proposals have been put forward to cater for fishermen with beam trawlers, advocating that they be allowed to obtain vessels of up to 12 metres in length.

Local fishermen are also advocating limitations on the size of boats allowed to fish in the area. The length, it is suggested, should not be more than 20 metres from the forepart of the hull to the afterpart of the hull, excluding rubbing strips and other hull attachments including the bowsprit. Controls of entry to the area are also sought. It is advocated that only owners of licensed fishing vessels who have been on the Queensland electoral roll for an electorate in the region from Cape Conway, north of Mackay, south to Cape Capricorn should be allowed to fish the area. The area or zone would include all waters from Cape Conway to Cape Capricorn, east to the 100-fathom line. Fishermen believe that vessels should be required to keep log books during working hours and that no vessel should have more than one limited area entitlement. That might put an end to those Gulf fishermen who have come around from the Gulf of Carpenteria and who have been exploiting the central Queensland grounds.

As the main threat to the fishery comes from outsiders, local fishermen want vessels with a Gulf of Carpentaria endorsement and others with entitlements to fish in other areas to be prohibited from working central Queensland waters. They are not being selfish. They have given consideration to the rights of amateurs and they believe that fishermen with vessels less than 12 metres who satisfy the proposed entry requirements be granted entry without penalty, provided they do not hold an off-shore, otter trawl or beam trawl entitlement. It is a pity that some of these foreign vessels or outsiders do not give the same consideration to amateurs, as they have been exploiting the favourite, close-to-shore areas on the Capricorn coast. It has been said by spokesmen for tourist areas that this could devastate our tourist regions.

I welcome the initiative by the Hawke Government and, in particular, by the Minister for Primary Industry. This legislation has been brought forward after full consultation with the States and the fishing industry. Its objectives are to achieve an overall marketing and management plan to determine the nation's total fishing capacity. When one considers the announcement the Minister made on 22 April, one realises how clear is the Government's commitment to the fishing industry. The Minister announced that the Government would boost to $3.6m the fishing industry research trust account which will fund 32 continuing projects and also initiate 32 new projects.

The Government realises that the Australian fishing industry has a bright future. For the eight months to February 1985 the value of exports was $246.1m, imports being $204.8m. The annual estimate for 1985 means that our exports will grow to something like $300m. However, we must act against overexploitation. I believe that this is what the Government is about. We need to make sure that our fisheries are more viable. We need to increase the profitability of those in the industry. These objectives are also necessary to save the central Queensland industry. I urge the Minister and the Parliament that the overall management plan be implemented to ensure that the plight of Queensland is considered and that action is taken to save the investment of the 80 fishermen in the region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to listen to the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) who spoke of the desire of the central Queensland fishermen to kick out of their fishery the Gulf fishermen, as he called them, who come around and overexploit, as the honourable member said, the central Queensland fishery. Perhaps the honourable member can be sympathetic, then, to the plight of Northern Territory fishermen. Northern Territory fishermen make up the smallest proportion of the licence holders who operate in the northern prawn fishery. The vast majority of licence holders comes from Queensland. A large proportion also comes from Western Australia. In the past contribution of the Western Australians to the fishery has certainly involved fishing the coastline and plenty of fishing effort. Indeed, I suspect that the majority of fishermen who come around from the Gulf to fish off central Queensland, as the honourable member for Capricornia said, are Queensland fishermen. I would suggest that if that sort of favoured treatment is to be meted out to central Queensland fishermen, Northern Territory fishermen be given something of the same sort of deal.

SPEECH.PARA: In general terms, as the member for the Northern Territory, I welcome this legislation. In relation to the northern prawn fishery, the legislation will enable the implementation of almost the exact proposal that the Northern Territory put before the Commonwealth, Queensland and Western Australia in 1982, when the Northern Territory expressed its deep concern about the overexploitation of the fishery resources in the Gulf of Carpentaria. As well as the resource being abused, Northern Territory fishermen were virtually being squeezed out of their own off-shore grounds.

Some time before that the Northern Territory became extremely concerned about the excess of fishing effort in the declared management zone of the northern prawn fishery, which at that time included the Gulf of Carpentaria and the Northern Territory coast along to the Western Australian border. We proposed that the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth manage the area west of the Wessel Islands separately, leaving the Gulf of Carpentaria to tripartite management with Queensland. The howls of rage in Western Australia, which at that time contributed nothing but a great deal of fishing effort to the fishery, could be heard here in Canberra. Years ago I went to Hobart to put the Territory's case to the Australian Fisheries Council. At that time no one would have a bar of our west of the Wessel Islands proposal. The outcome of this proposal was to initiate a complete review of the management of the northern prawn fishery, which resulted in a seven-point plan being approved by the Australian Fisheries Council in 1983 and reconfirmed by the Council in 1984.

The elements of this plan included formation of the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Committee, called NORMAC, to report directly to the Australian Fisheries Council on matters relating to management of the northern prawn fishery; unitisation of the fishing capacity of all vessels in the fishery; implementation of a voluntary licence entitlement buy-back scheme; increasing the effectiveness of the boat replacing policy; extension of the declared management zone westward from Cape Ford to Koolan Island in Western Australia-I might say that it should go further; increased penalties for offences in the declared management zone; and streamlining of licensing procedures. The majority of these elements of the plan have now been agreed to. However, the unitisation and buy-back provisions of the plan cannot be implemented due to the inadequacies of the legislation. To overcome these inadequacies, the original levy legislation was introduced and passed in this House to allow the Commonwealth to collect the buy-back levy.

It has taken a long time for the sense of our reasoning to be seen, but since this legislation is at long last before us, I express my personal relief that action has been taken-better late than never. In the Territory since 1978 we have worked hard to provide the necessary facilities for the fishing industry. Where previously there was nothing for the industry, there is now a small ships facility built under a joint venture arrangement. In Darwin a public wharf has been provided specifically for the industry and new wharves and facilities are to be provided at Gove. Even so, the major casualties of the cyclone that hit Darwin a few weeks ago were prawning vessels moored in Darwin Harbour. It is hoped that a tidal basin may be able to be constructed, but this will depend on feasibilities. It will be able to be used by all small ship operators and, for that matter, yachtsmen.

The Territory Government has reclaimed land for further fishing industry infrastructure development in the area of the port of Darwin, but these efforts to ensure support for our commercial fishermen-the only facilities between Cairns and Perth-will be left high and dry if the necessary support in fishing management is not forthcoming from the Commonwealth.
