This support is forthcoming at this stage, but I hope that in the future it will not take so long. I hope that these amendments will enable speedy, effectual, and flexible responses to industry problems in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of my address I say that it is refreshing to see that the approach to this legislation seems to be on common ground. I refer to the contributions by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham), who have raised no objections to the legislation as it is presented. We have a very minor amendment, which the Deputy Leader of the National Party has put before the House. The one common thread that can be found in the contributions from both sides of the House is that there is no doubt at all that management of the Australian fisheries is certainly necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for the Northern Territory, in his previous role as the Chief Minister of that Territory, for a number of years attempted to have introduced into the Federal Parliament legislation for this type of management. In fact, he said that he came to Canberra to do that in 1982. One will note the year and who was in Government at the time. Nothing has happened since 1982, but we have now before the Parliament comprehensive legislation for the future management of the Australian fisheries. He said that he went to Hobart prior to 1982 and that his words fell on deaf ears at that stage too. It is pleasing that we are as one in relation to this legislation. I believe that it will be in the best interests of the industry in the future.

In joining in the debate on this legislation, one must revert to the original legislation, the Fisheries Act of 1952. When that legislation was introduced the fishing industry was only a fledgling. At that time the total harvest of crayfish, prawns and oysters amounted to a mere $3.75m. If one contrasts that with the industry as it stands today, there is a stark difference. The fishing industry's input into Australia's gross domestic product stands at about $900m annually. The industry employs in excess of 200,000 people. In 1952, when the original legislation was introduced in this place, the industry was certainly not of that stature.

I wish very briefly to add to some of the comments made by other speakers on this legislation. I very much welcome it. It should be well-known by most Australians that the Gulf of Carpentaria, the far north-eastern coast of Australia and the Torres Strait fall within the electorate of Leichhardt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good fishing grounds, too.

—Good fishing grounds. The fishermen there have as one welcomed the approach of this Government, not only in relation to the Gulf of Carpentaria but also the Torres Strait and the east coast trawl fishery, which extends from Barrenjoey Point to the tip of Cape York Peninsula. In the management of fisheries in the future we must overcome the exploitation of the fisheries which has occurred over a long period. The fishermen now have the difficulty of very little return for their capitalisation in the industry. That has been brought about by a number of factors. I know that there are problems in relation to fuel pricing, but that is not the sole factor affecting the reduced returns of the fishermen. I ask that the people of Australia be told that there are other deep-seated problems. Some of these problems-not all of them-will be overcome with the introduction of this type of legislation. Certainly the problems of overexploitation and over-capitalisation will be overcome.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian fishing industry has too many large vessels. It is interesting to note that this Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) introduced a boat buy-back scheme. With total consultation with the State governments and the industry, this was a step that was supported and welcomed by the fishing industry. The industry has overcapitalisation and it has a weak export market. One looks with some trepidation at the Bureau of Agricultural Economics indications for the international market for prawns, which of course constitute the major product from the Gulf of Carpentaria, the Torres Strait and far north Queensland. The BAE indicates that the international market for prawns is likely to remain weak for some time. When one takes account of those factors, factors that already exist in the industry because there has been no proper development or implementation of marketing or management programs previously, and when one accepts that those difficulties and flaws in the industry already exist, one sees that this exemplifies more the necessity for the introduction of this type of legislation.

There are, in fact, three major fisheries in far north Queensland and I refer briefly to them. They are the East Coast Trawl Fishery-and I have already indicated to the House the geographical description of that fishery-the Northern Prawn Fishery and the Torres Strait Island Fishery. In conclusion, I can assure the House, other fishermen of Australia and the fishing industry that, from my discussions with a number of members of those fisheries, the fishermen and processors in the far north of Queensland welcome this type of legislation because it will lead to the proper management and development of those fisheries in the future. It is high time that the band-aid treatment of the previous Government for the fishing industry of Australia was cast aside and legislation such as this implemented. I join with members of the fishing industry in my part of Australia in commending the Minister for Primary Industry for introducing such wide-reaching and comprehensive legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I shall sum up quickly and thank the honourable members who have participated in the debate. The Government rejects the Opposition's foreshadowed amendment to the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill which proposes that there be a right of appeal against the suspension of a licence on reasonably believing that the holder has committed one of a number of offences specified in sub-clause 10 (a). It would not be proper to make such an amendment. To do so would create a situation in which a person suspected of breaching his licence or a prohibition made for the welfare of the fishery or of obtaining a licence fraudulently would be able to continue to enjoy the benefits of the licence. The Bill provides adequate protection for such a person. If he is not summoned to answer a charge within a month of the suspension, the suspension ceases. If the summons is issued the matter becomes one for the court to decide.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 28 is a drafting amendment which confirms the right of appeal against cancellation of a licence. This right was inserted in 1984 and at that time the Opposition did not oppose the omission of suspension of a licence from the list of appealable decisions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 28, page 16, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Reconsideration and review of decisions by the Minister or Secretary
28. Section 16A of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from sub-section (1) ''9A (1)'' (wherever occurring) and substituting ''9A (1), 3A''.

At present the Fisheries Act empowers the Minister or the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry to cancel a licence. The Minister or the Secretary may also suspend a licence for a limited period-that is, one month-until the completion of any prosecution for a breach of the licence conditions or for a longer specified period following the suspension or cancellation of the holder's State licence. Following amendments which came into effect in June 1984, the decision to cancel or suspend in the circumstances of the longer specified period that I mentioned may be reviewed under the provisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act. A suspension for the limited period or until completion of prosecution is not reviewable under the present Act. The Bill expands the grounds on which a licence may be either cancelled or suspended. However, the effect of a suspension will be reduced to a minimum imposed by the present scheme. Under the new scheme a licence will be suspended only for a maximum of one month or until the completion of the prosecution. As with the existing scheme where a licence is reviewed for this period, there is no right of review. I do not think that in itself justifies why it should be continued and carried forward into this legislation.

It may be argued that when these lesser periods of suspension are imposed the short period of suspension is insufficient to permit a review to be made. However, the Opposition believes that an extension of the right of review provisions is desirable and has therefore presented this amendment to the Bill. This amendment is advanced in a constructive sense because under the Bill and under other legislation there is no provision for appeal, which could be a very critical matter if a licence had been wrongly suspended. Departments and Ministers are not always right and in the course of a fishing season when a run is on a fisherman could be put to great loss as a result of an arbitrary decision taken either by the Secretary to the Department or by the Minister. Whether this is the right way to achieve our objective I do not know, but the Opposition would like to see some provision made-whether it is this provision or some other-to enable a quick review to be made where such a review or appeal is desired by the person who has suffered the suspension or the cancellation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my concluding remarks on the second reading I addressed this amendment. All I can do is repeat what I said at that time. The Government sees quite clearly that the Bill provides adequate protection for such a person as the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) refers to. If such a person is not summoned to answer a charge within a month of the suspension, the suspension ceases. It is not as if these decisions are taken lightly. For example, if someone was prawning in a nursery area or doing something that was very much against the Fisheries Act, it would be quite important that some action be taken rather than let it go without anything being done. If the summons is issued the matter becomes one for the court to decide. By and large we believe that such an individual as referred to by the honourable member would be protected. The Government rejects the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin)-by leave-read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DRIED FRUITS CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILLS:DRIED SULTANA PRODUCTION UNDERWRITING AMENDMENT BILL 1985DRIED VINE FRUITS EQUALIZATION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill 1985 concurrently with the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Amendment Bill 1985 and the Dried Vine Fruits Equalization Levy Amendment Bill 1985. As there is no objection, that course will be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DRIED FRUITS CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before addressing myself to the specific issues in these three Bills, the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill, the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Amendment Bill and the Dried Vine Fruits Equalization Levy Amendment Bill, which will have a disastrous effect upon those engaged in the dried fruits industry unless the Government is prepared to accept the amendments which I will move on behalf of the Opposition, I wish to say a few words about the Australian dried fruits industry. There is a perception that the Australian dried fruits producers are a heavily subsidised group of people and that Australia would be better off without such an industry. That perception is totally wrong. For the entire fruit industry the net government direct commitment is estimated at $2m. The underwriting payout during the 1983-84 season to the dried fruit industry was $1.3m with no net payments in 1984-85.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition also wishes to make the point that the industry contributes between $65m and $120m per annum to the gross domestic product. It earns an export income of between $50m and $80m per annum. The industry involves 4,000 growers and their families, employing 17,000 people both directly and indirectly. It is a very labour intensive industry. The equalisation payments are funded by a levy on the growers but involve a consumer transfer to the industry on the domestic market. Notwithstanding this fact, the product price for dried fruit in Australia has remained broadly in line with movements of the consumer price index. When one considers that there are 17,000 people involved in this industry, with a total net government payout of less than $2m, it is a small outlay when compared with the Hawke Labor Government's decision to apply a 15 per cent tariff on grain harvesters to guarantee the employment of 260 people engaged in farm machinery manufacture in a marginal seat in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —No equity. Absolutely no equity.

—No equity at all. This costly form of protection is being borne by a small number of grain growers in Australia when a $2m bounty could have achieved the same objective. But the Government chooses to impose a 15 per cent tariff costing grain growers in this country about $14m, which is pocketed by the Government, and at the same time it has afforded protection to the industry concerned, protecting the jobs of 260 people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not totally oppose the decision to limit the difference between the rate of equalisation payments and the average export return to 27.8 per cent for currants, 23.6 per cent for sultanas, and 47.2 per cent for raisins for the season commencing 1 January 1988; that is, for the coming three-year period. However, we are not prepared to go along with the five-year recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission that the level of assistance be reduced to 15 per cent because of the uncertainty of world market conditions and the devaluation of the dollar.

The Opposition believes it is essential for the IAC further to review the economic situation facing the dried fruits industry and those engaged in it in 1988 and to report on what measures should be taken to help strengthen the dried fruits industry to meet the competition from such countries as Greece, Turkey and the United States and countries which heavily subsidise their industries. By that time it will be interesting to see what the government of the day is prepared to do in respect of freeing up the wages system. It will also be interesting to see how far the Government is prepared to go in reducing the level of tariff protection on secondary industries in this country. I have been concerned that despite the substantial reduction in the level of assistance to agricultural industries falling from 28 per cent to 8 per cent over the past 12 years there has not been an equivalent fall in the level of assistance for secondary industries, which fell from 36 per cent to 25 per cent. Therefore, on average the actual fall in effective assistance for agricultural industries has fallen twice as fast as it has for manufacturing industries.

There is no way the farmers of this nation can go on having their levels of assistance and protection removed at such a rate while the levels of assistance remain as high as they do for secondary industries, and while we have a rigid institutionalised wages fixation system that is bloating the wage and on-wage costs structure in this country. The wages regime has an enormous bearing on the welfare of the dried fruits industry, which is a labour intensive industry. In fairness, no one in this Parliament should endeavour to single out the dried fruits industry or any other industry to be punished with medicine which has not been dealt out to other sectors of the Australian community.

I thought that the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), made a very good speech in this place yesterday. He made a point in a very articulate fashion in regard to the centralised wage fixation system and how it stands out like a sore thumb now that the Government has taken the right decision to free up the money and the financial system in this country. There is no way that the primary industries of this country or, for that matter, any small businesses or anybody else can afford to take treatment that the rest of the community is not prepared to take in regard to the removal of consumer transfers, bounties, subsidies or whatever. The time has come when there has to be a rethinking in this country about the whole structure of costs generally. Central to this issue is what we should do about wages at this point. The right decision has been taken in regard to the financial system of this country. It needed to be freed up, but now the big decision is facing this Government or a future government on the freeing up of the wages system and the removal of tariff levels of protection on industries in this country in accord with the actions that have been taken on the advice of the IAC in regard to the farming sector of Australia.

Each of these Bills will have a significant impact on the dried fruits industry, in particular on the export sector of the industry. The first Bill, the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill, increases the size of the Corporation from eight to 10 members. While the Wheat Bill reduces the number of members of the Australian Wheat Board, this Bill increases the size of the membership of the Corporation. At present, growers comprise four of the eight members. The extra two members will be appointed by the Minister, and must have a background in finance, commerce or marketing. The second Bill, the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Amendment Bill, changes the basis of underwriting from all sales to export sales only. The Dried Vine Fruits Equalisation Levy Amendment Bill imposes a ceiling on the difference between returns from domestic sales and export sales. The maximum variance between the domestic price and the average export price will be 15 per cent. At present there is no limit to this variance, which is estimated to be 37 per cent in the 1984 season.

The Opposition holds deep reservations about the practical application of these Bills. We will be seeking to amend the third Bill in order to align this legislation more closely to the needs of the dried fruits industry. The legislation as it stands will induce a short term artificial depression of market prices by unnecessarily distorting market forces. The paramount consideration of these Bills seems to be part of Labor's plan for a cheap food policy at the expense of the already impoverished farmers of Australia. In the longer term, the big losers will be not only the industry but also the consumers. There is a need for any legislation of this regulatory character to be constructed in the best long term interests of the producers and the consuming public.

The industry makes an important contribution to the Australian economy, largely unaided by Government assistance. Each of the 4,000 growers initiates an employment multiplier effect of 3.3 to one, so the industry is directly responsible for 17,000 jobs and indirectly responsible for tens of thousands of other jobs. Indeed whole communities, such as that great city of Mildura, which the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) represents so efficiently in this House, are largely dependent on this industry. On average, two-thirds of annual production is exported, making dried vine fruits the most export-oriented of the Australian horticultural industries.

In assessing these Bills, the Parliament must recognise the challenges faced by the industry in recent years. In particular, there have been wide fluctuations in world market prices, due to substantial seasonal surpluses from time to time being produced in Greece, Turkey and the United States of America. In 1980 the average export return to packers was $1,260 per tonne-more than $200 above the domestic return of $1,056. By last season the export return had dropped to $665 a tonne in the face of heavy overproduction by Greece and Turkey. Countervailing duties have now been imposed on Greek import, which will give honourable members some indication of the extent to which world prices have collapsed. Throughout this period, the Australian consumer has enjoyed an uninterrupted supply of high quality domestic fruit at a consistent price level.

There is no better dried fruit in the world than that produced in Australia. It is of a very high quality. It is a great pity that dried fruit is not put in all of the ration packs that are produced for the Army. In fact, I am shocked that that is not done because we have a great industry in Australia. There is no doubt that, when one is out in the bush and running short of tucker, there is nothing better than a bit of dried fruit to help survival. The old soldier, the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren), who is at the table, would know that.

Over the past decade, retail prices on the home market have broadly followed the Consumer Price Index, and the maximum increase in any one year has been 12.5 per cent. The 4,000 growers and another 13,000 employees along the industry chain operate largely without Government support. The $21.5m payment to the Australian Dried Fruits Corporations for equalisation of domestic and export returns are fully funded by the industry. Commonwealth underwriting for sultanas, guaranteeing a minimum return equal to 90 per cent of average net returns over the past two seasons and the present season, resulted in a payout of just $1.3m in 1983-84. No payments were anticipated in the 1984-85 Budget. Industry promotion, research and marketing are financed through industry levies. For the entire Australian fruit industry, the net direct government commitment this year is estimated at $2m. This is a small price to pay when, for instance, that $2m bounty has been used in Victoria to protect 260 jobs.

The dried vine fruit industry has tackled its challenges on the world market largely unaided the Government. Inevitably the growers have suffered falling returns because of world market fluctuations and the subsidy policies, overproduction and seasonal variations in other countries. The Industries Assistance Commission estimated the net cash operating surplus per farm in 1982-83 at less than $11,000. The industry recognised the need for ongoing rationalisation to achieve greater economies of scale. The Opposition's major concern lies with the imposition of new controls on the industry's domestic and export returns under the Equalisation Levy Amendment Bill, and I will outline this concern in detail shortly.

First, I refer to the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Amendment Bill, which alters existing arrangements from the start of the 1986 season. The present legislation has improved confidence within the industry by guaranteeing a minimum average net return of 90 per cent of the average production in the years of 1982, 1983 and 1984, rising to 95 per cent in 1985 and 1986. I underline the fact that underwriting provisions cost taxpayers less than 20c each in the last financial year, despite the dumping actions of export competing nations. The Bill now under consideration sets the guaranteed minimum rate at 80 per cent, but changes the base of the system from all sales to only export sales.

The Bill effectively matches or increases underwriting payments of recent years for the dominant export variety, sultanas. Although sultanas dominate export sales, there is a strong case for currants and raisins to be included under the provisions of this Bill. Their inclusion would further enhance the confidence of producers and could help to develop the export capacity of these varieties and maintain a balance of production between the varieties. Raisins, in particular gordos, have come under increasing demand from wineries. This has led to extensive plantings over recent years. Should the winery intake now stabilise, the export sector would be critically important to the viability of this section of the dried vine fruits industry.

I turn now to the Dried Vine Fruits Equalisation Levy Amendment Bill, which is of particular concern. The scheme presently in force was introduced in 1979 to provide for equalised returns from export and domestic sales in seasons when export returns are substantially below domestic returns. The present scheme was used for the first time in 1982, when a glut of sultanas flooded the international market. The levy is applied across domestic returns and the proceeds disbursed across all returns. There is no financial role for the Commonwealth, which acts only as an agency to collect and disburse the levy proceeds.

The Bill introduces a limit on maximum equalisation payments, tied to the world price. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has justified this new control by claiming that it will tie the industry to market signals and let growers experience the peaks and troughs of the volatile world prices. Applied to market realities, that is simply not true. In fact, returns to the industry will now become artificially depressed, threatening a situation of industry chaos and disrupting orderly rationalisation and attempts to improve economies of scale. The Bill reduces the differential between export and equalised returns to 15 per cent by 1990. The difference in the 1984 season is estimated to be 37 per cent.

To explain the concern of the industry and the Opposition parties over these provisions, it is helpful to look at price trends in recent years. From 1981 to 1985 the domestic return at ex-packer level increased by 15.6 per cent, or less than the CPI, on figures prepared by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. Over the same period, with the onset of dumping on the world market, the export return has dropped 46 per cent to a level today which in no way equates either costs of production or domestic prices in the nations offering these low prices-in particular, Greece and Turkey, whose governments heavily subsidise their products. Equalisation has cushioned the impact of this dumping by delivering an average return down 16.4 per cent over this five-year period.

The Minister justifies his Bill by saying that when world prices are low the domestic price will fall but when world prices are high the domestic price should rise accordingly. He argues that, when the world price rises, the industry should charge up to 15 per cent more than that price on the domestic market to make up for the times when the world price is depressed. How do the consumers feel about such a proposition? Let us take the 1979 and 1980 seasons, for example, when the world market showed a strong demand for high quality Australian sultanas. To use the Minister's argument, there would have been a 37 per cent leap in the domestic price in one year. At that time the domestic return was in fact 16 per cent below the average export return. If the world price were a more accurate reflection of real costs of production, the Minister's proposal might have a greater attraction. As it stands, this Bill can only produce wild price fluctuations on the Australian market, with serious consequences to the industry.

Heavy domestic price rises can only lead to consumer resistance. Therefore, the peaks which the Minister promises as compensation for the troughs are unlikely to materialise. Manufacturing companies such as Kellogg (Aust.) Pty Ltd absorb some 50 per cent of total domestic production. Should they find such products as breakfast foods priced out of their highly competitive markets through steep price increases, the next move would be to tool out of production into other lines. The costs of tooling back into dried fruits might well be prohibitive, and so the long term losers are not only the consumers and manufacturers but the dried fruits industry itself.

A severe contraction of market demand over a short period would have quite disastrous consequences for the industry. Should producers be forced out of production en masse, Australia would be left with just a rump of what was a vital domestic and export industry-one which today offers a stable supply of competitively priced, high quality produce to the Australian public. Why can the Government not see the damage that this kind of action proposed by the Minister could wreak on an important Australian industry?

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not want to see it.

—I do not think that Government members want to see it. The industry has done nothing to deserve this kind of treatment. Probably the reason why industry members have been singled out is that they do not vote Labor. I cannot understand why the industry has been singled out in the manner that it has. It has had plenty of opportunities in the past to exploit the Australian market in periods of high external demand. It has not done so. The industry has acted with great responsibility and the consumers have been the beneficiaries. Now the Minister is saying to the industry: 'I will force down your prices now, but some years down the track when there are shortages you should go your hardest to make up the leeway'.

SPEECH.PARA: Against the background of other recent moves by the Government, such as the new dairy marketing arrangements, there is one explanation for the Minister's actions. The Government has a dual problem-holding down the consumer price index while wages continue to rise in line with full indexation under the accord with the unions, on the one hand, and finding new markets for Australia's secondary industry output which is being rendered increasingly less competitive on world markets due to the wage increases, spurred on by increasing protection due to the devaluation of the dollar, and other fast-rising costs. This legislation and other decisions by this Government have all the hallmarks of a cheap food policy-that is, push down the prices of food in the short term, regardless of the medium and long term consequences to farmers. Labor seems to be banking on the world price remaining corrupt between now and the next election. The farmers around Australia see right through such a policy. They will not be fooled by such political tricks.

The limit of 15 per cent on the price differential will not achieve its stated goal of bringing the industry closer to market signals. In practice, it will do quite the opposite. An indication of the severity of this Bill is the scales adopted under clause 2, sub-sections (3) to (5). For the major export commodity, sultanas, the prescribed percentage declines from 32.4 per cent in 1986 to 15 per cent by 1990. For currants the percentage drops from 40.4 per cent and for raisins from 79.4 per cent to 15 per cent by 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —Survival of the fittest-that is what it is.

—That is what it is; absolutely. The coalition recognises that the world market has been corrupted by abnormally low prices, and that the 15 per cent maximum variation has been roundly rejected by the industry. I know that the industry is sick to death of inquiries. The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) said that the other day. The Opposition does not oppose the direction that the Government is taking as a result of the last Industries Assistance Commission report, but we are stopping short of going to 15 per cent over a five-year period, because we do not believe that they could forecast or foresee five years ahead. We do not know what this Government, or any future government, will do about wages. We do not know what any future government would do about protection levels in respect of secondary industry. To be acting in a vacuum, where one lift is going down while all the rest are going up, is a crazy state of affairs. Because of our concern, we believe that an IAC inquiry should be established in 1988 to determine more accurately the appropriate limit to the equalised returns. In Committee, we shall move an amendment, the terms of which have been circulated to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn briefly to the other Bill before this House, the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill. The Opposition does not seek to amend this Bill, but is concerned that the Corporation will be increased at a time of industry rationalisation. Producers will now have only 4 voices in 10, not 4 in 8. In 1978 the coalition reduced the membership from 12 to the present 8 in order to streamline operations and reduce costs. Now the minister says, on the one hand, that the industry needs to contract its production against a world market oversupply, and yet he is moving at the same time to increase the size of the Corporation.

These Bills give all Australians, primary producers and consumers alike, an insight to the Hawke Labor Government's approach to rural policy. This Government is a sectional, union-dominated government bound hand and foot by the accord. It cares not a fig about the farmers or anyone else for that matter. It is interested only in the fostering of union domination in this country. These Bills were introduced to this House couched in doubtful economic theory, based on so-called world market forces, which are, of course, corrupted through the dumping policies of other nations. Then, to give some respectable objective to these measures, the Minister labours on about adjustment.

Applied to market realities, the Bills will not achieve their goals. They will induce a short term depression of market prices at the expense of industry stability, the livelihoods of farmers and their families, and the eventual loss of an industry, exportation of jobs overseas and the loss of overseas exchange earnings. That is brilliant! These Bills serve, first and foremost, the short term political aspirations of the Labor Party. In the longer term, the big losers will be the producers, the people employed in the industry and, ultimately, the Australian people through loss of export income. It is particularly disturbing that such important changes have been thrust on the industry with a bare minimum of notice.

I believe that the Minister has treated the Australian dried fruit producers with absolute arrogance. I urge the Government to reconsider this legislation and to support the amendment which I shall propose to the Dried Vine Fruits Equalization Levy Amendment Bill. This amendment must be carried if the industry is to overcome its present difficulties, which are due to a corrupted world market. If the Parliament accepts this legislation in its present form, it will be sentencing the producers and the industry to a contraction, with heavy social and economic costs to the people directly involved in the industry, and to all the Australian people. I call on the Minister for Primary Industry to accept the amendment to be proposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The development or growth of multi-purpose grape production in Australia is a story of unprecedented agricultural productivity and successful decentralisation of industry and people. These developments grew out of an ideal combination of soil, water and climate, innovation and enterprise and substantial government support. These projects created a unique opportunity for individual enterprise. They provided work for thousands of men, women and their families at a time when returning ex-servicemen had little to look forward to. During the depression years, irrigation and drainage construction, the first in Australia, provided support and work for hundreds of the nation's unemployed. Today these regional communities are the stimulus for diversity of people, production and tourism and are the environment for a continuing contribution to the economy of Australia and the well-being of our people.

SPEECH.PARA: It is significant to recognise the demographic changes within the dried vine fruit industry, where households today are characterised by younger age structures, larger household sizes and high concentrations of overseas born persons of non-English speaking origins. In Sunraysia, using income multipliers, some $194m is contributed by the dried fruit industry to the local district economy. It is in this setting that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has introduced these three Bills that will impact upon the viability of this industry. The industry and the community have been stunned and shocked at the savaging of the dried fruit producers implicit in the legislation and appalled that the Minister and the Labor Government have made no attempt to meet the immediate or long term social and economic needs of this industry that has contributed so much and has the potential, through innovation and diversity, to enhance further the well-being of regional communities in the future.

This is a strong condemnation of this package of legislation. Before I go into details of each Bill let me summarise my reasons for making these assessments. The Minister has accepted an Industries Assistance Commission report that failed to take into account highly relevant considerations. It did not project any results of its recommendations on the incomes of producers or the large communities they support. It did not target any optimum production levels for the industry. It did not account for the social welfare effects of these recommendations to evaluate increased unemployment in areas already double the national average. The IAC recommendations are based on theoretical pure economics, but they cannot be accepted and should not be accepted by a government that allows the level of protection of farmers to fall to 8 per cent, and retains for manufacturers protection of 25 per cent and full indexation for all Australian wage and salary earners. In other words, the Minister is saying to primary producers: 'You will have to survive and compete in a deregulated environment, in a world market corrupted by subsidies, import duties and inefficiencies, while living domestically in a regulated economy with high costs'. Worse still, the Minister has removed the right of equity in prices between growers by destroying the philosophy of equalisation. The harshness of these decisions is that no care appears to have been given to the need for adjustment to take place in line with the long term trends of the industry. They are based upon an industry that is at the lowest ebb in its history. The cyclical nature of grape production and price movement in themselves should have prompted greater caution and understanding.

During my 13 years as a representative of these regions, major highs and lows have occurred on three occasions. Even as we debate this legislation we see that prices are generally up by 50 per cent on last year. These rapid changes have taken place as a response to the high quality of this season's fruit, a shortage of good quality produce throughout the world and the benefit of Australia's currency exchange rates. Current price estimates for 1985 sultanas range between $900 and $950 per tonne compared to prices of some $650 per tonne in 1984. Such variations and fluctuations of income clearly demand the need for stability in marketing arrangements and confidence in government support in times of adversity.

The Government has offered $5m additional adjustment assistance which is dependent on the appropriate State meeting one-third of this promise, but it has done absolutely nothing to improve rehabilitation measures, such as household support, to meet the unique problems of those who are self-employed. This neglect becomes significant if the displacement of many growers takes place and when increasing pressure on other grape outlets, such as wine production and the table grape industry, occurs. The Minister, when opening the federal conference of the Australian Dried Fruits Association in Mildura in July 1984, said:
I am pleased to note that the industry is recognising the hard realities and has been actively examining how its problems can be addressed.
He went on:
We will look for ways and means to ease that burden to minimise to the extent practicable the disruptive consequences of necessary adjustment.

The Minister has failed on both accounts in these Bills. No notice had been taken of the professional, documented and practical advice from the Industry, or of the trauma that will be caused by radical and forced adjustment.

I turn now to the Bills in detail. The first Bill changes the memberships of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation by adding two additional persons with special qualifications. A cynic may say that this is part of the Minister's desire to reduce grower influence and policy in the control of their own produce. I hope that additional expertise will achieve the stated aims. We have a Minister who is increasing the Corporation's membership effectively to erode grower influence while, at the same time, in the Australian Wheat Board legislation that we will soon be dealing with, he is reducing grower membership to achieve the same aim.

The second Bill amends the existing underwriting legislation. Underwriting was introduced to a number of rural industries by the previous Government in an endeavour to assist industries to avoid major price fluctuations while retaining a means of projecting market returns and potential to producers. The Government believes that these changes will provide roughly the same assistance. However, it can be shown that this year such arrangements would have provided a substantial gain to the industry, and additional payments are a possibility in future years. The one distinct disadvantage in this Bill is that underwriting applies only to sultanas, while changes made in the third Bill dealing with equalisation will bring about price fluctuations that will also affect currant and raisin growers. The 1985 currant crop may see a disposal of only 50 per cent of production and it is still unknown how much further production is to come on stream from new vines.

Raisin varieties, particularly gordos, have seen extensive plantings. Demand from wineries sees the present production of raisin varieties being diverted to wine. The result of these diversions is to leave the dried vine fruit industry with an insufficient tonnage to service available markets. These markets may be lost for all time and not recovered when raisin production increases and greater quantities of raisins are dried as new plantlings come into bearing. The exclusion of these varieties evidences the major deficiencies in this legislation which has no production targets and no stimulus for the dried vine fruit industry to continue to be the most innovative and progressive in the world. I urge the Minister to amend the underwriting Bill so that all dried vine fruits-sultanas, currants and raisins-receive equal treatment and equal degrees of cushioning to stop falls in world market prices.

The third Bill, the Dried Vine Fruits Equalisation Levy Amendment Bill, is a disaster and signals the Government's intent to impact on domestic prices and so ensure that any government commitment risk is nil or, at the best, minimal. The existing equalisation levy was designed and operates as a measure to equalise returns from all markets. The Government now plans to limit the value of the equalisation levy so as to place a maximum on the price that can be charged on the Australian domestic market. Thus the Government's expectations are that Australian prices will fall in line with the trend on export markets. The actual value of the equalisation levy in each year will no longer be simply the difference between the Australian market and the average export return. The new equalisation levy will vary each year depending on the total production of the season, the relative proportions sold to the Australian market and export markets, and the returns achieved from sales to export markets.

The result of limiting the equalisation levy in this manner is to destabilise totally the price for dried vine fruits in Australia. Estimates show variations in the Australian price over a four to five-year period of somewhere in the vicinity of 100 per cent. An average 5 per cent per annum increase in Australian dried vine fruit consumption has been achieved over the recent years by ensuring full supply to the Australian market and maintaining a pricing policy which has seen prices follow the changes in the consumer price index. Sudden price variations will destroy these sales levels. The Government fully intends the new equalisation mechanism to force Australian prices to match more closely export prices. Yet it appears that no thought has been given to the marketing realities of wild price fluctuations. Increasing the tonnage required to be sold on international markets is directly opposite to the need to stabilise the industry. When export markets are depressed and a low equalisation levy is set, very low Australian prices and returns to growers will be experienced. However, practical market forces will make it impossible to achieve the indicated peaks in Australian prices. The Government formula indicates price increases as high as 37 per cent from one year to the next. Obviously price increases of this magnitude could not be sustained without a severe buyer reaction and reduced consumption within Australia.

Another aspect of fluctuating prices within Australia is that the price for any period is the base on which all future prices will be founded. As price increases will be constrained by the market, returns lost through lower prices may never be totally recovered by subsequent price increases but, on the contrary, the lower returns will be compounded ever onwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.

—The shadow Minister obviously understands the situation that exists, as of course does the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). The Government has failed to recognise, therefore, that while aiming to reduce tonnages available to export markets it is essential for Australian producers to maintain and, where possible, to improve competitiveness on world markets. Increased pressure placed on growers will arise from an economist's expectation that the price mechanism support should be limited to a maximum of 15 per cent in any one year. This short sighted approach fails to take into consideration the long term nature of vine plantings and the highly variable nature of production and returns. The high variance in production and returns indicates that 15 per cent assistance provides insufficient support in the extreme low income years. The Minister, therefore, must amend this Bill to phase in the levy at a slower rate and I believe at no lower than 25 per cent at the end of the 1990 season. This would provide the industry with a greater capacity to absorb and avoid the considerable personal damage, trauma and loss of regional income associated with any adjustment. The amendment to be moved by the Opposition overcomes this lack of Government support, but it still, unfortunately, necessitates another IAC report. We are sick of IAC reports in the horticultural industries. They simply cannot afford to appear before the IAC on such frequent occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: The additional adjustment funds of $5m which are intended to facilitate a vine pull program may well have been highly beneficial if the new legislation had placed restraints on the industry maintaining or acquiring an undesirable dependence on export markets. It has rejected this course in favour of the use of overseas market forces as the principal means of adjusting the industry to reduced production levels. Total adjustment of the grape industry is needed as wine and table grapes will also see severe repercussions. The interdependence of dried vine fruits, wine and table grapes will see strong pressures on access to wineries and fresh fruit markets as dried vine fruit producers are forced by severe economic pressures to seek alternative markets.

Past reliance on IAC industry reports has been the basis for Government initiatives. This time the Minister has given an absolute imprimatur to the IAC, intent on introducing world price parity to Australian industry when the root cause of low world prices for dried vine fruit is directly related to European Economic Community subsidy policies and other international interventionist procedures, for example, Greek subsidies and United States of America actions. I ask the Minister why he rejected industry proposals that were designed to meet the long term rationalisation of the industry, that provided clear production targets and market signals, yet avoided exposing grape growers to the corrupt and violently fluctuating world markets. This approach, I believe, will result in adjustment, but only by virtue of the survival of the fittest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —One might reasonably ask as one rises in the House of Representatives this afternoon: Where are members of the Australian Labor Party? What is their interest in the welfare of the dried vine fruit growers of Australia? Why is it that I stand in a chamber almost empty to speak on behalf of those growers who sadly need real representation on the other side of this chamber.
—Not even the Minister for Primary Industry is here.

—Precisely. When I was preparing these comments and when members of the Opposition were being lobbied by various people from the Australian Dried Vine Fruits Association, those who came to see us were suntanned Australians. These men did not have the sort of sallow, chemical complexion that we see decorating the 'Come to Keppel Island' posters. Oh, no. These were men who love a sunburnt country. They love a sunburnt country because that sunburnt country gives them their living. These men were suntanned by exposure to the same sun as dries their product. Their hands were callused with the reality that the work in which they were involved was intently labour intensive. These men ran quite counter to the popular concept of the industry being a peasant industry. These men were articulate and informed.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) have already given details of the way in which this legislation will adversely impact on the Australian dried fruit industry. The honourable member for Gwydir has outlined precisely what the Opposition intends to do about these Bills and the honourable member for Mallee has talked about the history of the industry and the impact of this legislation on the Sunraysia area. I say to the House that the industry under consideration this afternoon is unique because it uses one of Australia's greatest natural resources and uses it to the full. This industry takes Australian sunshine and uses it to produce a uniquely Australian product whose quality is envied across the world. Few other places in the world so lend themselves to the drying of grapes and the production of dried fruit as do the Sunraysia area of Victoria and the Riverland areas of South Australia. Although dried fruit industries are labour intensive wherever one turns in the world, it would be quite wrong for me to leave the chamber giving the impression that these industries were solely labour intensive and that that was a burden from which they could not escape.

The same suntanned Aussies who came to talk to us when they were concerned about this legislation are the very men who have led the world in mechanising the dried fruit industry. If honourable members spend time in the Sunraysia, they will see that it is an area in which dried vine fruit production is more mechanised than it is in any other part of the globe. However, even with that level of mechanisation it is still a labour intensive industry.

Mr Deputy Speaker, will you allow me to take the time of the House for but a moment to explain what has to happen in order to put a dried currant, sultana or raisin on the dining room table? These grapes are not harvested in dried form-at least not until recently. They have to be picked and it is difficult to pick them mechanically in their fresh state because the process of mechanically picking breaks the berries. That is tolerable for the wine grape industry, but intolerable for the dried vine fruit industry which has to keep the berry intact. Sultanas and raisins have to be sprayed with chemicals and laid in the sun to dry. Concerned about the labour intensive nature of such a procedure, Australian growers have pioneered the technique of endeavouring to dry that bunch of gordos or sultanas, as the case may be, on the vine. That is no mean achievement because that means reducing the flow of sap to the bunch, spraying it with a chemical while still on the vine, allowing it to dry and then, because it is dried on the vine, being able to mechanically harvest it without damaging it. These are the very procedures in which these men are involved. They are the very adventurous procedures that keep this industry in the forefront in world terms but, in spite of these procedures, this industry is labour intensive and finds it difficult to survive in the face of subsidised overseas production.

Why is this industry in trouble? It is in trouble principally because in the early 1970s those who now sit opposite us were in government. They unwisely chose to take on the grape industry. Prime Minister Whitlam said: 'Let us reduce the differential between the excise on brandy and the customs duty on whisky'. One can ask: What has that got to do with dried fruit? As a result, Australian brandy sales plummeted and whisky sales, largely imported whisky, rose. So the brandy industry, which was once the buffer industry for excess dried fruit, disappeared. That is problem No. 1. But not content with stabbing the industry, the Whitlam Government then had to twist the sword as well. It rubbed out section 31 (a) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the tax provision which encouraged producers to hold on to stocks. With the removal of that section we saw the effective extinction of the Australian brandy industry. As the Australian brandy industry disappeared, so the problems for the dried vine fruit industries were exacerbated, because this buffer zone was being lost. As if that were not enough, while the Whitlam Government was taking this action the European Economic Community was subsidising agricultural production and so the EEC market for Australian dried fruit was effectively eroded. That market for Australian dried fruit fell from 40,000 tonnes to 20,000 tonnes. As if that, too, were not enough, the EEC was also building up an enormous wine lake as a result of its subsidised wine production. That wine lake has now flooded into the United States of America and so in the USA those Thomson seedless grapes, known in Australia as sultanas, that would have been produced for wine production were directed out of the wine market and were pushed on to the dried fruit market. So the world dried fruit market was flooded by a USA product that was never intended to be on the world market. Of course that has been a matter of major embarrassment to Australian growers and is no fault of those growers.

The legislation before the House is a further attack on these Australian growers, and that attack has been detailed by the honourable member for Gwydir and the honourable member for Mallee. The first of the three Bills, the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill, proposes that the Corporation's membership be extended by two but the growers are still to be denied a majority voice. The second Bill, the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Amendment Bill, changes the underwriting provisions and, as has been said, we are nervous about the way in which it excludes the currant and raisin crops from Australian dried vine fruit production. The third Bill, the Dried Vine Fruits Equalization Levy Amendment Bill, changes the equalization levy so that when the world price is low the domestic price will be low and when the world price is high the domestic price will be high.

On the surface of it one may say that that is fair enough, and I would not challenge that generalisation. But this will produce in the dried vine fruit industry a measure of unprecedented instability because the variations in price will be enormous. It is these enormous price variations that will make it difficult for the industry to survive, because it is an industry with long lead times. A person does not get into it one year and out of it the next; if he is into it he is into it for 30 years and what happens to the market-place this year affects the viability of a property for at least the next 20 years. The industry has said: 'Let us have some measure of stability in the industry and let us have some measure of assurance that as we are producing the best product in the world we will be given conditions that will enable us to continue that sort of quality production'.

I am conscious of the time restraint and I want to conclude by making one or two salient points. A point that ought to be reinforced but which has not been made in the debate is that Australia currently consumes more dried fruit per head of population than any other nation in the world. That tells us something about the Australian dried vine fruit industry. It has been diligent in its marketing and it has produced a product which Australians might reasonably be proud not only to sell but also to consume. The growers in the Sunraysia and Riverland areas were encouraged on to their properties by government action. We do not today make a plea to protect them but a plea that they be given a fair trading environment. We plead for a minimal injection of government funds that will enable them to survive the quite unfair agricultural trading climate that exists overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he accepts the judgment of the Melbourne Herald that the assets test not only discriminates against the aged but that it is also biased against the aged in that:

QUESTION.PARA: An urban pensioner with a four hundred thousand dollar house and thirty thousand dollars in the bank . . . may receive the full pension. Yet, a country pensioner living in a twenty thousand dollar house, with farmland worth one hundred and fifty thousand dollars and nothing in the bank . . . is entitled to no pension at all.
Does the Minister agree with these statements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I will refer firstly to that part of the question concerning the Melbourne Herald. The Melbourne Herald is a newspaper which, over the last several weeks at least, appears to me to have departed from the principles of responsible journalism. I would have thought that the very first tenet of responsible journalism is that the facts must be right. For a fortnight, in something like four editorials and articles on the first page of the newspaper almost every day, the Herald substantially got its facts wrong. That was underlined in its editorial of Monday, 29 April, when it said:

ANSWER.PARA: There are, as we have said all along, two monstrous flaws. First, the test is a selective tax on thrift. It will remain so until the same rules are applied to all recipients of welfare.

The theme of those articles over two weeks was that in fact the assets test related only to the age pension. As I pointed out to the Melbourne Herald, and as the Melbourne Herald was forced to acknowledge, in fact the assets test does not relate simply to the age pension; it relates to a whole range of pensions-the age, the invalid, the wives, the widows, the supporting parents, the spouse carers and the rehabilitation allowances and repatriation service pensions paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. So the Herald, which has had some reputation in this country, took two weeks to read the legislation and find out to whom the assets test applies. The second part of the honourable member's question concerned whether there was a bias against people within rural areas. I think honourable members ought to recognise--

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course there is. You know there is.

—I am not at all surprised by the comments of the Leader of the Opposition. Before the introduction of the assets test the aged in rural areas received pensions in far greater proportion than those in corresponding areas in the cities because people with expensive houses in the cities are less likely to receive a pension because of the income test-that is, they tend to be more income rich as well as asset rich-and that still applies. If one looks at the proportions of people in rural areas who are still receiving the pension following the introduction of the assets test, one finds a massive disproportion. For example, in an area such as Tenterfield in the seat of the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Sinclair, more than 90 per cent of the aged are on full or part pension, whereas in an affluent urban area, such as Crows Nest in Sydney, the proportion is two-thirds. In the suburb of Toorak in the electorate of the Leader of the Opposition, the proportion is between 35 and 40 per cent. It is true that there are higher proportions of people in rural areas on the age pension, but what is not true is that the assets test is applied inequitably between urban and rural areas. There are very wealthy people, and indeed there have been very wealthy pensioners, in rural areas in this country. There are also very wealthy people, and there have been very wealthy pensioners, within the urban areas.

ANSWER.PARA: Whatever else the Government has sought to do in relation to the assets test, it has sought to be equitable. I would have thought that is not an unreasonable principle to apply. I believe that if there were a little more honesty on the part of the Opposition it would think through a little bit of what its own rhetoric means; then we might see a little more understanding in relation to the assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Health whether he is aware of substantial delays in the payment of pharmacists' claims by the Department of Health. Are these delays caused by problems relating to the pharm-pay system? Can the Minister give the House an assurance that pharmacists will not have to wait several months to have their claims processed with the consequent cash flow problems?

—I thank the honourable member for Calare for his question. There have been regrettable delays in the payment of pharmacists' claims due to a number of factors beyond the effective control of the Department of Health. The new pharm-pay system has involved loss of productivity and recruitment and training problems which have affected the program. We have been plagued with industrial disputes and repetition strain injury has also affected the payment of those claims. Because the lag developed we took action in February to pay immediately 90 per cent of the claims without any assessment. Even this effort to deal with the lag proved insufficient, so from the beginning of April we paid 100 per cent without assessment and we are now rapidly catching up on that lag. April and May payments-that is, current payments-are being made within the 30-day period and we are confident that by the end of the month we will have caught up on all the 10 per cent lags. The formula we have used for paying 100 per cent of the claims has worked so well and proved to be so accurate that should any lag develop in the future we would immediately revert to that system to correct the problem.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it the case that, as of 4 April 1985, 1,286 applications had been received under the hardship provisions of the assets test but only 24 applications had been granted? Given the harshness manifested in these figures, what does the Minister intend to do about this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I suppose one conclusion to be drawn from that is that if those figures are correct-I do not have them with me-there are a large number of people who, having applied under the hardship provisions, clearly fall outside the guidelines in relation to the assets test. To apply under the hardship provisions is not necessarily any evidence at all that people are in such a situation that they require to be paid a full pension by the Government. I am aware of a number of people who have applied under the provisions and who have very substantial assets, some well over the limit with assets in the order of $200,000 to $300,000. Of course the hardship provisions are there to ensure that people who are unable to achieve an income from an asset for very good reasons are treated sympathetically. There is no suggestion-I want to nail this allegation as strongly as I possibly can-and there has never been any suggestion that in the administration by this Government of the assets test it is seeking to force people in any sense to sell their homes. That is the reason the assets test excluded the home and curtilage from the very beginning. That is the reason that, apart from the hardship provisions and the review processes, designed to ensure that there is an objective determination of hardship, the loans scheme was introduced as part of the assets test scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw attention to one aspect of the loans scheme which seems to me to be extraordinarily generous. A great deal of the complaints that have been made about the assets test have not come from aged people but from children and dependants-indeed, future beneficiaries of the estates of pensioners. It is part of the provisions of the loans scheme-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.

—If the honourable member listens, he might learn something. It is part of the provisions of the loans scheme that, when the Government recovers the money advanced by way of loan following the death of a pensioner, an amount of $100,000 is not recovered as part of that process. It seems to me that in many of the circumstances about which there has been the greatest amount of bleating, involving very aged people, the loans scheme is a very appropriate means to ensure that people do not suffer any disadvantage and that they are not put in the position of not receiving their pensions. If some Opposition members who show so much apparent concern in this place were to draw attention to the operation of the scheme in certain circumstances it would be useful and would assist to resolve many of the problems that no doubt exist for many people.
—Can the Prime Minister inform the House as to what would be involved in holding the anti-union summit proposed by the Queensland Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It ought to be increasingly clear to all members of this House and to the people of Australia that the confrontationist tactics that have been adopted by the Premier of Queensland have already wreaked very substantial economic costs upon Queensland, a State which, I remind the House, is already at the bottom of the heap in terms of economic management as a result of the disastrous economic policies being pursued by Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. Queensland's economic performance, according to any relevant economic criterion one wants to take, is the worst in Australia. Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen is the worst economic manager and the Queensland Government is the worst State Government in the country. It is also time that the Queensland Government in general and the Premier in particular understood not only that have they been seen through by the workers of Queensland but also that, increasingly, the confrontationist tactics the Premier is adopting are not receiving the support of the Australian business community.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very relevant that we should have seen today in the Australian Financial Review evidence of that repudiation by the Australian business community. There is a reference in the Financial Review to a recent study entitled: 'Control, Consensus or Chaos?' It was carried out by Professors Niland and Turner of the University of New South Wales. It is revealed that Australian business leaders favour the stability provided by the consensus approach of the prices and incomes accord. We have become accustomed to the fact that those opposite are interested not in facts, only in prejudices. However, we will put the facts before them. The study-a study of 219 top business executives-concluded that Australian corporate leaders prefer the predictability and stability of the co-operative approach to industrial relations that we as a Government have followed in this country since the beginning of 1983. The study-I repeat: a study of 219 top Australian business executives-concluded:
They prefer a tripartite approach in which unions, along with governments, work together to formulate the key features of the framework.
The concerns of 1981, when this study was undertaken, have real point in Queensland today. The study made this observation:

Many managers saw the Fraser Government as inept in industrial relations because of ill-timed intervention in particular industrial disputes, which smacked of grandstanding rather than genuine efforts to get matters sorted out.
The study went on to say:
. . . some managers even suggested--
does this come as a surprise-
that the Liberal-Country Party governments of the 1970s sought political advantage from industrial relations turmoil.

The situation has not changed in Queensland today. We even had the remarkable observation on 27 April this year when the Sydney Morning Herald reported the Queensland Premier as having said that he had sacked 1,000 striking linesmen in February as a way to confront the Federal Government. That is the confrontationism of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen in Queensland. He deliberately sacked 1,000 men. For what reason? To provoke confrontation with the Australian Government. The business community of Australia, as revealed by this independent study, has shown that it rejects the processes and principles of confrontation. I believe that, increasingly, it will become clear in Queensland that the Queensland business community rejects them also. It is about time that Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and the Queensland Government came to their senses and started to negotiate so that the interests of the Queensland business community and the people of Queensland as a whole can be preserved and protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to the widespread disquiet among many pensioners about the over-valuations given to their land under the assets test. Are these valuations made under instructions from the Minister or his Department? If not, what is he prepared to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Upon the introduction of the assets test we suffered the kind of hysteria that was generated by members of the Opposition-the Liberal Party in particular-who made statements about SS men and the intrusion of privacy. That seemed to be advocated by many people in the Opposition. These statements made the question of valuations a very sensitive matter and caused needless concern to hundreds of thousands of aged pensioners who were never considered likely to be affected, never received a form and are never likely to be affected by the assets test in any way. It is true that a very high proportion of the applications for review and appeals to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal turn on the question of valuation. The Government needs to take action in the area of revaluation, to ensure that whenever a pensioner requests--
—What action are you going to take?
—The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting across the table.

—The Leader of the Opposition is primarily interested in the question of the assets test from the point of view of cheap point scoring. He is not interested in the welfare of pensioners. Some people are concerned to hear the answer--
—It is time you started worrying about it.
—The Leader of the National Party has interjected three times. I have asked him twice not to. I will warn him the next time.

—The honourable member has asked a question which I think deserves a serious answer. I have said that the Government recognises that in a large number of cases, where there is a review or an appeal, there is a need to ensure a comprehensive valuation. In those cases we require the written permission of the pensioner concerned because we do not seek, and never have sought at any stage in relation to the assets test, to intrude on anyone's property without permission. Some of the cases that have been beat up in the media have been cases where we have not been able to carry out a valuation because we have not had that written permission.

ANSWER.PARA: Where that written permission is provided, we are seeking to ensure that those valuations are carried out as rapidly as possible. It is of major concern to the Government that the question of valuations ought to be resolved. I am trying to give an assurance to the House, if I am given an opportunity by the Opposition, that that is an area to which I believe we need to give particular attention to ensure that those revaluations occur as speedily as possible. I assure the honourable member that that will be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware--
—Been to sea lately?
—You're the bloke who ought to worry.
—Is this the next episode of Love Boat?
—I warn the honourable member for the Northern Territory that if he interjects again I will name him.
—I do not know what the interjections are about. I heard on the radio that it was a Federal Liberal Party member.
