—Is the Prime Minister aware of reports of recent fighting in Beirut and southern Lebanon, where many people, both Christians and Moslems, have been forced to flee for their lives, causing much distress to their relatives in Australia, many of whom live in my electorate of Grayndler? What steps will the Government take to bring an end to the fighting in Lebanon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have expected that the seriousness of the matter involved in the question asked by the honourable member for Grayndler would have had the effect of bringing to an end the hilarity on the other side of the House. Certainly it reflects no credit on the Leader of the National Party that, when the fighting in Lebanon was referred to, he said: 'It has nothing to compare with the fighting in Sydney Harbour'. It is an absolute disgrace.
—What were you giggling for?
—He said that and he knows it. If he had any decency, he would withdraw.
—So would you, to the back of the House.
—I warn the honourable member for Barker.
—He never said that at all. I am sitting right behind him.
—The honourable member for Franklin will cease interjecting.
—That was exaggerated.
—The honourable member for Franklin will not argue with the Chair, or he will be outside arguing.
—I will be better out there than in here.
—I warn the honourable member for Franklin.
—I believe that no Australian-
—When are you pulling the troops out of the Sinai?
—I warn the Leader of the National Party. If he interjects again, I will name him.
—She might name you, Bob.
—I also warn the honourable member for Groom.

—I would hope that the House would cease the uproar and hilarity which have been associated with the asking of this question. I ask honourable members on both sides of the House to realise the enormity of the tragic situation which has developed in Lebanon, which I believe deserves, and I think does receive, the attention of all honourable members.

ANSWER.PARA: On behalf of the Government, and I believe on behalf of the whole of the Parliament, I express our great distress at the news of the continued violence which is taking place in that tragic country. We are certainly concerned at the recent events in the south of Lebanon, where as many as 20,000 Christians are reported to have fled their homes and to have sought refuge in the city of Jezzine and other towns in the region. We can only regret that the opportunity presented by the withdrawal of the Israeli forces has not been taken to restore Lebanese Government authority in the south. We are also seriously concerned at the escalation of the fighting in Beirut.

The Government expresses its deepest sympathy to the very large Lebanese community in Australia, many of whom have relatives in Lebanon. We are very conscious of the anxiety and suffering that they are going through at this time. Despite what has gone on before, I believe I can say on behalf of all members of the Parliament that we would want the members of the Lebanese community in Australia to know that our thoughts are with them as they go through this period of suffering and anxiety. I emphasise, because of what has gone before, that that is said on behalf of all members of this Parliament.

We appreciate of course that there is no simple solution to the problems in Lebanon. No one has a magic wand to wave which will resolve those problems. It is obvious, but it should still be said, that the first requirement is for an end to the fighting there, and certainly we from Australia call on all parties in Lebanon to exercise maximum restraint because it is only when the guns are silenced in that country that efforts can then be undertaken aimed at securing a national reconciliation through consultation and a peaceful settlement of outstanding problems. We believe that agreement among the present warring factions is the only basis on which Lebanon's independence and sovereignty will be respected.

We all recognise that one of the great tragedies of Lebanon is that it should have become the battleground on which foreign forces conduct their battles openly or by proxy. We believe strongly that all external interference in Lebanon's internal affairs should be brought to an end. If such necessary preconditions were to be met, negotiations could then begin for a long term political settlement of that country's problems. In that respect I have noted suggestions that there should be a cantonal system of government along the lines of Switzerland. All one can say about that proposal, which has been floated in certain quarters, is that any such proposal would of course require the agreement of all of Lebanon's confessional groups.

I conclude by saying that the Government of Australia pledges to use all its influence, all the influence that we can bring to bear in the United Nations and in other international bodies, to pursue efforts aimed at bringing to an end the fighting in Lebanon, which is a necessary precondition to those consultations and negotiations which we would all hope would bring an end to the continuing tragedy in that country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. But first of all, I would concur with the remarks made by the Prime Minister on Lebanon and I would like to place that on the record. I am pleased to hear that the matter will be taken further, hopefully in the Security Council of the United Nations. I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he intends to amend the unfair and inequitable assets test legislation; if so, when and how?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the Leader of the Opposition should ask a question about altering the legislation because that reflects the divisions which are present within the Opposition parties in this respect. I shall just go over recent events. On 5 May the Leader of the Opposition stated that the assets test should be repealed. On 1 May Senator Messner said that the Opposition had rejected the notion of seeking amendments designed to correct anomalies in the assets test legislation, but on 5 May the Leader of the National Party called on the Government to introduce amendments to the assets test without delay. He said that the only way the Hawke Government could make up would be to amend the test and to do it soon. So, on the one hand we have the Leader of the Liberal Party saying: 'Let's get rid of the assets test'; on the other hand we have the Leader of the National Party saying: 'No, it is not so much that we want to get rid of it, we want to have it amended'. On 27 April the Leader of the Opposition said the Opposition had always opposed an assets test, yet if we go back to 27 November the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said:

ANSWER.PARA: I am personally in favour of a needs approach to the payment of welfare.

He attacked the method of the test proposed but quite clearly favoured the re-introduction of an assets test. That is why the honourable member for Bennelong has had very little to say on this issue. He, amongst some of his colleagues, is interested in thinking through the consistent elements of a policy in relation to welfare. As we saw when the Liberal Party announced its welfare policy in the last election, the informed reaction to that was: 'Well, what does it really mean?'. It did not have any cutting edge because essentially the Liberal Party has not made up its mind. The Opposition cannot decide between the attitudes of the Liberal Party and the National Party, between the wets and the dries or between the people in the country and those in the city. It does not matter where one goes, one finds people with different attitudes. There is one thing, however, that has always held this Opposition together and indeed has held the conservative parties together over the years. If they can see an opportunist short-term political advantage they will go for it because that is what they are about-cynical opportunism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Special Minister of State aware that the stated purpose of the proposed electoral redistribution in Queensland is to give fair representation? As this is also the basis for boundaries drawn in the Legislative Council in Western Australia, where an imbalance of 11:1 exists, can the Minister inform the House whether the rationale and procedures for distribution of electorates in the Commonwealth Parliament coincide in any way with those of the Queensland and Western Australian parliaments? If not, can he say whether elections for the Australian Parliament give fair representation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that every member of this House can be proud that the redistribution which took place last year and which was responsible for the election of this Parliament has no relationship at all to what will happen in Queensland under the redistribution in that State. The provisions of the Federal redistribution require that for each State there is an average set and seats must have enrolments which are up to or plus or minus 10 per cent from that average. Such boundaries must be fixed with the aim that in three and a half years time there shall be equality of voters. As of February of this year, the seat most above the quota, just slightly above 10 per cent, is that represented by that excellent member, the honourable member for Phillip. The one most below the quota in the national Parliament as of February was 9.29 per cent below and it is represented by another excellent member, the honourable member for Rankin. He is in a very fast growing area and obviously he will be there for a very long time.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting to note what is happening in Queensland. The President of the Liberal Party of Queensland, who sits in this Parliament, might have different views from some of his colleagues when they step up to the dispatch box giving their great support to Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen for everything that he does in Queensland. The National Party in Queensland will never destroy the Labor movement but it is out to destroy the Liberal Party and it is doing so very successfully. One only has to ask the honourable member for Ryan or the honourable member for Moncrieff because they could tell in detail what is happening to the Liberal Party as a result of its continuing capitulation to the National Party over so many years.
Lodgement of Annual Returns

This Bill amends section 263 of the Companies Act to provide that the annual return of a company may be lodged with the NCSC at any time between the end of the company's financial year and one month after the date of the annual general meeting held in respect of that financial year. The effect of this amendment wil be to make the ending of a company's financial year the event which creates the requirement to lodge an annual return, rather than the holding of the annual general meeting as at present. Thus, although the existing maximum time limits wil continue to apply for the lodgement of annual returns by the majority of companies, companies will be able to lodge their returns prior to the date of their annual general meetings if they so desire.

There is, nevertheless, one small group of companies that will be required to lodge their annual returns within a shorter period of time than at present. These are the companies that have established a branch share register outside Australia. As these companies have to obtain information from their branch share registers for the purpose of completing their annual returns, they are currently allowed an extra month in which to lodge those returns with the NCSC to compensate for communication delays between Australia and other parts of the world. However, with modern communication facilities, information can be obtained from overseas almost as quickly as from other parts of Australia. Accordingly, there appears to be no reason why these companies cannot lodge their annual returns within the same time limits as are imposed on other companies.

Sir Joh Bjelke-Peterson was interviewed, as is his wont, by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation on 25 March and he was asked about the redistribution. He was asked about the number of seats, whether more seats were needed in Queensland and whether Queensland's population had increased. This is a bit like the comment that the Minister for Primary Industry quoted yesterday-just have a listen to this. He replied:
Oh, it is increased a lot and growing dramatically, just as our skyline has changed dramatically; huge buildings, you can see them everywhere you go round the city. I saw some today.

So there is redistribution because Joh looks out his window and sees all these buildings going up in Brisbane. The ironical feature about the redistribution is that the people who work in those buildings or live around them are not going to be given any more say in Queensland; in fact they will be given less say. Following the redistribution there will be seven new seats in Queensland. There will be four electoral zones-four different types of citizens in Queensland. In the heavily populated south-eastern zone, taking in Brisbane with all the beaut big new buildings, there will be four new seats. It has been suggested that the redistribution will also wipe out four existing inner city seats, making eight new seats in the outer metropolitan and Gold Coast areas-two National Party strongholds. At the moment the Nationals hold 19 of the 47 seats.

There will be one new seat in the western and far northern zone. This will replace the existing Labor held seat of Mount Isa, which is coming out of the provincial zone. Mount Isa is being split down the middle-as any rational redistribution would do to a city!-making Mount Isa two bush seats leaning towards the Nationals. The Nationals presently hold six of the seven seats in the zone. In the country zone there will be two extra seats, probably just to the west of Brisbane and the Gold Coast, making them almost certainly National Party seats.
Opposition members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirteen of the 15 seats in the zone are presently National. When National Party members say 'hear, hear!' they should look down at the honourable member for Kooyong and keep saying it. He is the person they need to keep reminding about what is happening in Queensland. In the provincial city zone there will be no change in overall numbers, but there will have to be one new seat to make up for the loss of Mount Isa. This extra seat is likely to be in the Mackay-Prosperpine area, and will be National. Labor presently holds 10 of the 13 seats in this zone. The quotas for the zone are: South-eastern, 19,300; country 13,000; western and far northern, 9,500; and provincial, where Labor holds most of the seats, 19,000. The western and far northern zone electorates are allowed to deviate by more than the 20 per cent tolerance required in the other zones. The Premier's--

—Order! I did not hear what the honourable member for Mitchell said. If his comment reflected on the Chair, I ask him to withdraw it.

—At the last election the Premier's seat of Barambah had an enrolment of 11,600, while the largest Labor seat had an enrolment of 25,300. Far more interesting, of course, is that under the redistribution there will be a new seat in central Queensland, which could be tailor made for you know who-the son of the Premier. So he might be joining us.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a serious matter. It has taken a long time for this Parliament to be persuaded on this issue, over the heads of the National Party members who believe that the only way a parliament can be constituted is by giving weighting to rural electorates. That is not the way it should be done. Once we deviate from one vote one value, we can go right down to the extremes of the late Sir Thomas Playford or the present Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. There is only one way for the Australian people to go and that is to elect their parliaments on one vote one value. If parliamentarians from country areas have larger areas to look after, the parliaments should provide them with the facilities to look after those areas. If parliamentarians in the metropolitan areas which have increased numbers of people have a lot of non-citizens living in their electorates, they should be given the facilities to look after their electorates as well. There is no excuse for trying to manipulate the electorates as the Queensland Premier is doing in dividing Queensland into four separate classes of persons in order to continue his reign in Queensland and continue the further destruction of the Liberal Party which he set about some years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed again to the Minister for Social Security. My previous question was related to the assets test legislation, and I specifically asked him whether he intended to amend the unfair and inequitable assets test and in particular the assets test legislation and, if so, when and how?

We promised particularly in terms of the administration of the assets test that we would ensure that it was administered in the most sensitive manner. That commitment remains.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the brumby declared a protected species.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House follow the example of President Nixon in the USA by declaring our wild horses protected from industry and indiscriminate slaughter.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Grace,Mr Humphreys and Mr Jacobi.

PETITION.TITLE: Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the wild horses of Queensland and the Northern Territory declared a protected species.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will set aside a National Park for these horses and ensure that killing of feral animals be undertaken in a humane manner with proper legislation and enforcement.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Humphreys,Mr Langmore and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives should disallow the new Customs and Objectionable Publications Ordinance and that the Attorney-General should introduce laws to:
1. Prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography
2. Prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications
3. Register imported pornographic video tapes for non-commercial use with the Film Censorship Board
4. Require the Censor to more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes
5. Protect Australians, particularly women and children from exploitation; and
Your petitioners also request that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cowan and Mr Hicks.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth that:

(i) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult and any increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) The imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) Those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any category of students.
2. any form of Stamp Duty or similar system of the ''user pays'' principle in education not be introduced.
3. emphasis should be on increasing access to education by, among other things, increasing student financial assistance.
4. the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
5. the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs immediately clarify the government's attitude to the reintroduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Moore and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Australia: Zonal Charging Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the house of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That the current Telecom Australia practice of charging STD telephone rates for telephone users living in ''outer metropolitan'' areas is unfair given that Telecom's method of determining what is an outer metropolitan area (by drawing concentric circles on a map centring on the Perth GPO) does not take into account the development of regional and subregional corridors of urban growth which are encouraged by the West Australian State Government.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the recommendations of the House of Representatives Committee on Expenditure concerning Telecom's zonal charging policies be implemented so that areas of urban growth at significant distances from the Perth GPO are not automatically classified as STD telephone areas but instead that consideration be given to the development of areas of urban growth in relation to their STD status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Price of Petrol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. We are completely dissatisfied with the pricing policy of petrol in this country.
2. We are aware that it has an adverse effect on the living standards of the average wage earner of this country.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that the price of petrol be reduced by 3c a litre in line with a commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Koalas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the koala declared an endangered species and given the proper protection of the Commonwealth.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House declare that the koala may not be exported from this country and that urgent re-vegetation of their habitats be carried out. Your petitioners also humbly pray that Commonwealth Government funds will be made available for research into the disease Chlamydia Psittaci which is killing the koala.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that 'the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Farm Costs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Australia's great farm potential is being shackled by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Many Federal and State Government regulations, excessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of agriculture to compete on world markets, are increasing food costs for Australian families and creating widespread unemployment in both the country and cities.

The undersigned humbly petition the Parliaments of Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed costs and regulation, allowing Australian farmers to unlock farm potential so the nation as a whole can share the benefits of the resulting growth and prosperity.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Firefighting Aircraft
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Federal Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned request Commonwealth and State co-operation and financial commitment to-
(a) Providing an infrastructure and making aircraft available for the fighting of bushfires in New South Wales;

(b) Further, we request the Commonwealth Government to retain the surplus Grumman Tracker Aircraft (approximately 17) and associated spares, for the purpose of conversion to firefighting aircraft for use on the above project.
And your petitioners humbly pray that your Honourable House will respond to our plea.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax: Confectionery
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that there is a need to end the current discriminatory application of sales tax on confectionery and the other anomalies existing in sales tax law. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this tax should be replaced by a broad-based consumption tax with a uniform ad valorem rate, without any exemptions whatsoever.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The humble petitioners of certain undersigned Australian and overseas students respectfully showeth that:
1. The Overseas student program brings in a multitude of cultural, political and educational benefits as well as a net financial gain of A$5 million p.a., in foreign exchange. (Ref: Goldring Report)

2. Overseas students are under financial constraints. Most depend on their families for this financial support. The Goldring Report found 62% of Overseas students come from families with annual combined parental income of less than A$15,000.

3. The imposition of high Overseas student charges will deprive many Overseas students from getting a tertiary education and qualification in Australia despite their academic abilities. High charges will determine education in Australia for Overseas students on economic grounds.
4. The imposition of sudden and drastic increases in visa charges will also particularly disadvantage those current students, many of whom will be forced to discontinue their studies.
5. Overseas students do not displace local students. They represent a mere 3.4% of tertiary students. (Goldring Report)
6. The fluctuations and uncertainty in Overseas students policy has led to uncertainty, stress and fear in Overseas students.
Your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray that:

1. The Government re-affirm a commitment to its policy that supports the social and economic development of people and institutions in developing countries through access to Australia's education and training resources.
2. The Government formulate a consistent and considerate policy concerning Overseas students.
3. The Government reconsider, as a matter of urgency, the legislation of such a high increase in visa charges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Aerospace Agency
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

Whereas space technology involves many of the very highest engineering and scientific disciplines that Australia possesses, which may be applied at an international level to reap significant economic and technological return to the nation, and;
Since an appropriate space program for Australia must involve presently unco-ordinated industry, government and research agencies, united together with Federal Government funding;

Your petitioners therefore pray that you will support the establishment of an Australian Aerospace Agency to manage aerospace programs under a Federal Budget, promote technology transfer, and market our expertise overseas, while ensuring the continued operation of existing space-related facilities within the nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the Hawke Socialist Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test;
That the Assets Test discriminates grossly against those people living on acreage blocks or in rural areas;
That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of senior citizens is condemned as un-Australian;
That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have been united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher, in Queensland respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, property or wealth taxes, death or gift duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ''windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement.
the people of Australia are already being subjected to the oppressive tax policies of the highest taxing government in Australia's history-the Hawke Socialist Government.
Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the House of the Government's decision to sign a reciprocal agreement on social security with Italy and to start negotiations towards social security agreements with other interested migrant source countries as soon as practicable. I am very pleased to be able to announce Australia's preparedness to sign a social security agreement with Italy and I hope that the Italian Government will likewise announce its preparedness to sign shortly. This is a most significant decision for people with links with both Italy and Australia. It is also important for all migrants, whatever their country of origin, and for all those people who choose to spend part of their lives outside Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The basis on which the agreement with Italy has been negotiated shows that it is possible to negotiate reciprocal social security arrangements linking the Australian social security system and the very different type of social security systems which operate in most other countries. Now that we have bridged this gap in relation to Italy, I am confident that we can do likewise with other migrant source countries. For migrants to this country this decision is one of the most important to be taken by any government since the commencement of large scale immigration.

Honourable members will be aware that Australia has had reciprocal social security arrangements with New Zealand since 1943 and with the United Kingdom since 1954. We are now to have, at long last, comprehensive reciprocal agreements with non-English speaking countries. The type of agreement I am proposing is an improvement on the agreements we currently have, in that it better co-ordinates the social security coverage available from the countries involved. Reciprocal social security arrangements are important for migrants and all Australians who choose to move between Australia and other countries.

To understand their importance, I should point out that most social security systems, unlike Australia's, are contribution based. Many migrants coming to Australia have previously paid compulsory contributions to such systems. However, in a lot of cases, people would not have contributed for sufficient periods to allow them to meet essential minimum contribution requirements. This means that they have effectively lost those contributions. Reciprocal agreements would enable pensions to be paid by agreement countries on the basis of those contributions. In other words, when these migrants reach pensionable age or need income security support for such contingencies as widowhood or invalidity, they would be able to receive some payment from the country concerned. Again I emphasise that this is important not only for migrants but also for all Australians who have, at some time during their working life, lived abroad and contributed to an overseas social security system. Under an agreement an Australian who worked overseas and made contributions to an overseas system may also receive some pension as a result of those contributions. The number of people who might benefit from the reciprocal agreements is very significant. It is estimated that, if Australia can successfully negotiate agreements with the major migrant source countries, about one million people could benefit over the next 20 years.

Agreements are also important for the community as a whole. Payments of foreign pensions represent an inflow of foreign currency which assists the balance of payments. Agreements also have direct budgetary implications, to the extent that such payments are taxable and are taken into account under the income test arrangements of Australia's social security legislation. Of course, to obtain these benefits, Australia would be required to grant its pensions in the agreement country concerned.

I now want to refer to those migrants to Australia who want to retire to their home country or some other country before they reach Australian age pension age. Under Australia's social security law, pensions generally cannot be granted outside Australia. These people, who now leave before gaining a pension from Australia, cannot receive a pension overseas. Under reciprocal agreements such people may be entitled to receive an Australian pension payment proportional to the period of their residence in Australia. Furthermore, because agreements are reciprocal, people may also become entitled to some payment or increased payment from countries which are parties to agreements.

Paying a proportional pension abroad on the basis of residence in Australia is a new concept in this country. Proportional portability was announced by the previous Government in 1983 as the basis for negotiations of reciprocal agreements and it has been used as the basis for negotiations with Italy. Australia's social security law provides for universal flat rate pensions which are needs based, whereas, in most other countries, the amount of pension payable is largely dependent on the level of contributions made; the longer the contributory period and the greater those contributions, the higher the pension. In order to provide a rational basis for reciprocity it will be necessary to amend the law governing social security payments outside Australia so that the level of Australian pension payable abroad reflects the length of residence a person has had in Australia. I propose to bring forward for Parliament's consideration in the Budget session the necessary changes to the law. In the meantime I will be consulting members of the Federal and State ethnic communities councils of Australia about these changes, and agreements in general; and with representatives of ethnic communities about the specific agreements. These consultations have already commenced.

What I would like to emphasise is that this legislation will only come into effect when Australia has as many reciprocal agreements as practicable ready to sign. Pensioners now overseas will not be affected. Proportional payment of pensions overseas and reciprocal agreements go hand in hand. The Government is keen to ensure that the very great advantages of reciprocal agreements flow to the majority of migrants as soon as possible.

I believe that proportional portability, when linked with agreements, is a very reasonable concept. I can appreciate, because it is a new concept within the Australian system, that it may be difficult to understand readily. It is, however, a concept on which most international agreements on social security are based. It recognises that both Australia and any other country where a person has worked, share responsibility for income support. It also recognises that this responsibility is limited to the amount of time spent in each country. Reciprocal agreements will assist Australia and its agreement partners to meet social security responsibilities more compre- hensively.

The present arrangements Australia has for social security payments overseas fall short of a comprehensive coverage. For some people, Australia's position is unduly harsh and for others, it is overly generous. I have referred already to the unfair treatment of those who have left Australia-those people who cannot at present be granted an Australian pension because they have left. Some of those people may have spent the greater part of their lives here. Under the reciprocal agreement with Italy, Australia would be able to pay a pension to such people now living in Italy and reciprocal arrangements with other countries would enable Australia to pay pensions to such people in those countries.

To determine each country's responsibility for social welfare payments, it is necessary to set a period for maximum payment from any one country. Most countries set around 40 years as the period necessary to qualify for maximum payment. The Australian Government has decided to set 35 years as this period. In other words, to qualify for a maximum Australian pension overseas it would be necessary in future to have resided in Australia for 35 years during working life. The government believes that where a person has spent less than 35 years in Australia it is over-generous to pay a full Australian pension overseas. The equitable and affordable solution is for Australia to follow the pattern set by most income security systems throughout the world and to pay its pensions abroad on a proportional basis. To effect such a change the Government will need to introduce legislation to change the current arrangements for paying pensions overseas.

The need for the change was recognised by Senator Chaney when he was Minister for Social Security and this Government will carry it through. Members of the Italian community have been consulted during the negotiation of the reciprocal agreement and they and the Italian Government understand Australia's position on proportional portability. Consultations are continuing and I believe the Australian community as a whole will accept this new package for payments of pensions overseas.

I now turn to some of the main provisions of the agreement with Italy. This agreement would enable periods of residence in Australia to be added to periods of contributions in Italy and, if needed, the total of these periods can be used to gain eligibility for pensions from both Italy and Australia. The minimum period of residence or contributions required under the agreement by either country would be generally one year. Legislation governing the payment of a pension by Australia under this agreement will generally follow the provisions of the Social Security Act. There are some important differences, however, in the way in which Italian pension payments would be treated under the Australian income test. The agreement would provide that where Australia pays a part pension overseas, only a proportion of the Italian pension payable would be taken into account under the income test. Where Italy pays a supplement to top up its pension to the minimum Italian level, such a supplement would, except in some special circumstances, be exempted from the income test.

Reciprocity arrangements will effectively mean that people who have spent part of their life in more than one country will receive a package of pensions consisting of part pension from each country. Within Australia, it is possible that the sum of the part pensions payable would be below the pension currently paid by Australia. This would be unacceptable in Australia and accordingly, the agreement with Italy would provide that, where necessary, the pension paid by Italy will be topped up to the level of the Australian pension. Australia would be prepared to agree to similar arrangements under agreements with other countries. The agreement also provides for administrative arrangements so that each country will assist the other, not only in relation to payments under the agreement, but also in relation to payments made under existing provisions.

I believe that the proposed agreement with Italy has many benefits for Italians residing in Australia and for Australians residing in Italy. The Government is committed to ensuring its effective implementation as soon as possible and to seeking agreements with other countries so that similar benefits can be passed on to other ethnic groups and people who have moved between these countries and Australia. The importance of this matter has been recognised by this Government. Because of the major differences between the Australian and overseas social security systems there are considerable technical difficulties to overcome. Now that we have a model agreement which overcomes many of these difficulties, I am confident that great progress will be made in the future and that we will have the bipartisan support of this House for these important developments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The matter before the House is not something on which I want to take a lot of time, because the statement suggests that legislation will come into this House in the Budget session. That will be the opportunity to look at the whole legislation, and what it means. Obviously, in the two hours in which I have had the paper, I have not been able to plan a full response. It would be more effective at that later time.

SPEECH.PARA: The agreement comes at an appropriate time, because some people in the electorate, particularly of Italian descent, have been making representations concerning the part of a pension to which they are entitled from Australia, if they have lived here and gone back home. I understand that the present arrangement is that they have to come back to Australia and reside here for one year before they can become entitled to the Australian pension. That matter would probably be looked at very favourably by the Italians in our society. The agreement comes on the heels of two others, one with New Zealand and one with Great Britain.

I shall make a few comments concerning implementation. I notice that 35 years of working life has been set as the maximum. I have not seen anything in respect of a minimum working period. I believe there would have to be a base period before people could claim-for instance, if they were out here for six or 12 months. It would be fair to impose a basic limit, over which a person could work on a proportional basis.

There is also the complaint-the statement probably corrects this in many ways-that an Australian pension paid overseas represents a greater proportion of average weekly earnings in the country of receipt than it does in Australia. The statement says that there is a minimal topping up as far as an Australian pension supplement to Italy is concerned, and vice versa. I wish to point out that there are problems paying Australian pensions to people who reside overseas and rely solely on the Australian pension, if that pension represents a greater proportion of average weekly wage earnings in that country than in Australia.

I repeat the comment made by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). I believe that the legislation contains machinery clauses that have to be addressed, as far as the age pension is concerned, such as if an assets test is to be applied in the country of origin, how would this be determined? Would it be on exactly the same basis as in Australia? First, will it apply? Will it apply on the same basis as it applies in Australia, who will make the valuation and under what terms?

I turn to another problem, particularly in relation to Britain, where we have a reciprocal arrangement, where pensions are paid partly by Britain and are supplemented in Australia. There has been a great deal of concern from some people over the last six months about getting their pensions remitted to Australia; first, because of the strike in the head office of the Department of Health and Social Security in Britain and, secondly, because of the uncertainty of mail deliveries. I know of a migrant who, at the moment, is entitled to a full pension on a part time basis from both governments, but she is not receiving the pension from Great Britain on which she is means tested. In the light of the record of direct payments that the Department of Social Security has just been through-successfully, I understand-I wonder whether there could not be a better arrangement made in the payment of these pensions? Could they be paid in one sum, either by the British social security system or the Australian Department of Social Security, with an arrangement that any difference be adjusted from time to time?

That is a practical difficulty. I imagine that the same difficulty will occur, once pensions are determined in part by both governments, as to people getting that pension as an income supplement in the week or the fortnight in which they are entitled to it. There was not an actual costing on the exercise, but, by the time the legislation is through, the House should have available details of cost estimates, or what the reciprocal arrangements will mean. Also, if there are any changes in the Budget to the taxation laws by that time, such as were suggested in this morning's Press, of a 10 per cent tax on the lower levels, would it be necessary to have a withholding tax on those pensions before they left Australia?

There are probably quite a few other items that would naturally flow from the statement, but in view of the fact that legislation will come into the House I shall leave my comments on that matter. I ask the Minister just to address himself to those few points which are not covered in his statement but which will become real issues once the legislation comes before the House.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The continuing unjust imposition on Australian families of the Government's punitive assets test.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their place-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was surprised that the 22 members opposite who were coddling their consciences publicly regarding the assets test were not standing to support us in our raising of this matter of public importance today. In fact, if ever there were a need to raise a matter of public importance in this Parliament, it would be today. Throughout Question Time the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) backed and filled and discussed the whys, howfores and moreovers of the assets test at length-I started to conclude that the only thing that is a problem with it is the 'Howe' rather than the whys and wherefores-but no decision was taken to amend the legislation. The Minister had two opportunities near the end of Question Time to say that he would amend the legislation to eradicate the unfairness, the confusion and the punitive and discriminatory nature of this legislation; yet he did not do so. We have raised this matter today and we do not see one member opposite who has complained publicly-allegedly there are 22 of them-about the effect of the assets test on their pensioners. It seems to me that they are more preoccupied with perhaps trying to save their seats rather than looking after the savings of pensioners. The fact is that since the assets test came into effect on 21 March this year it has become clear that it is punitive and discriminatory in practice and wrong in principle. That is why we are seeking its repeal in a Bill which I have given notice of.

SPEECH.PARA: I just said that the assets test was punitive, discriminatory and wrong in principle. Let me say just what each of these means. The assets test is punitive because it robs elderly people of their pensions and reduces their living standards simply because, through a lifetime of hard work or thrift, they have created assets to provide them with independent and modest comfort in their retirement. Until this Government came along Australians were encouraged to put something aside for their retirement, to have a nest egg to give them a degree of independence. Now generations of Australians are being penalised for what they have been encouraged to do. I also said that the assets test is discriminatory. It is discriminatory because it makes unjust distinctions between city and rural pensioners, between those who own their own homes and those paying rent, and between those who can look after themselves and those who, through age or infirmity, seek to live with, say, their families or in retirement villages. I said it is wrong in principle. It is wrong in principle because the assets test is a retrospective tax on the elderly. For the 50,000 Australian men and women affected by the assets test 21 March was the day on which the Government changed the rules.

TALK.START.PARA: —A black day.

—Indeed, it was a black day. From that day the assets that they had accrued during their working lives became not a reward but a punishment. From that day the property they might have bought years before, to retire to, became for them no longer an asset but a liability. From that day their savings and their investments, carefully put together over years of effort and sacrifice-they were not enjoying two high incomes as were members of the Minister's family-and after scrimping and saving as the overwhelming majority of Australians in that middle earning group do, not at one or other end of the scale, which is the nature-
—You don't have a bone of principle in your body.

—You are still engaged in your class war mentality. When you claim that you are rethinking a matter you are merely rearranging your prejudices, and you know it. Unless you get out of your mind the class war mentality and recognise what is happening in the Australian community you will not recognise that from that day I mentioned you are also causing an enormous amount of confusion and anxiety. That is why the assets test, apart from being punitive and discriminatory, is wrong in principle. It taxes not present income and effort. It is not a tax on present income and effort. Pensioners throughout their lives have been taxed on all their work and effort. Now when they retire they are taxed on their past sacrifice and their savings. A socialist, as a member of a redistributive government-even a member of the Centre Left has said that it is a high taxing policy-may justify it because it is a tax on the elderly. But we will not abide by it. It is the sacrifice and the savings made during people's working lives which produce whatever assets they may seek to provide for their retirement, and they are being penalised for that. It is fundamentally wrong in principle to punish people financially, as the legislation which the Minister refuses to amend does, because they sought to provide for their future in the belief that any assets they created would eventually be free for them to use or dispose of as they wished without penalty and without hardship. That is the basic reason why we have said that the assets test should be repealed.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other reasons and among them is the Government's own confusion about the legislation which, in its present form, could be described as assets test mark four. Honourable members may remember that we had mark one in August 1983, mark two in December 1983, mark three in the shape of the report of the Gruen Panel of Review of Proposed Incomes and Assets Test, and mark four in the revised version announced on 1 June 1984 and passed on 10 September. We now seek its abolition but it appears that there will be a mark five of some sort, not by repeal of the legislation evidently but by some fiddling of bureaucratic regulation. As far back as 22 February 1984 the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) acknowledged the faults in the original legislation when he said:

It has become clear that there is continuing and justifiable uncertainty about whether the Government has yet found the best way to implement legislation on an assets test in a fair and equitable manner.

Honourable members should just bear in mind the words 'fair and equitable'. I put it to the Minister and indeed to the man who mouthed the words, the Prime Minister, when he used the words 'fair and equitable' in relation to the assets test. Is it fair and equitable that a pension in the city with a $200,000 house and $50,000 worth of assets keeps the pension, but a retired farmer with $50,000 house and land worth allegedly $200,000 loses it? The answer is no. To use the Prime Minister's words, is it fair and equitable that pensioners who feel they have been unjustifiably affected by the assets test are, in effect, regarded by this Minister and the Government as guilty of having too many assets until they prove themselves innocent? They are guilty in his and the Government's own words of having worked hard, saved and put money aside. Their assets are the sum total of their working lives. This Government says it is fair and equitable that they be judged guilty for doing that until they prove themselves innocent in regard to those assets by way of appeal to tribunals or his Department.

Is it fair and equitable, on the Government's own test, that the alternative to the assets test is the so-called pensions loans scheme which we correctly first identified as the pay as you die scheme, which it is. Fairness and equity were supposed to be embodied in the hardship provisions of the test. If we ask those who sought assistance under those provisions we will see what a bitter joke it has been to them. So stringent are the qualifications for assistance, as was indicated at Question Time today, that out of 1,286 applications received only 24 have been granted. Some fairness; some equity. If the Government thinks this is going to rub over the months and years ahead, it has another thing coming because people will not allow its ideological motives to seek some sort of equalising down in this community and to negate concepts of people being able to work hard and put money aside, as is their right in our sort of society as we see it. There might be a real cleavage in philosophic terms between the Government and ourselves on this question. We do not put this matter forward for votes, though we know we will get them. We put it forward because we believe people are entitled to work hard through their lives, improve their lot and have some benefit and independence on their retirement. Honourable members should bear in mind that in the Australia of today the people we are talking about who are being hit by this assets test are the people who, as children, suffered and endured the Depression. They are the people who, as young men and women, fought for this country in the Second World War. They then returned to help rebuild a peaceful and a prosperous nation. This is how this Government treats them when they are seeking peaceful and contented retirement.

In this context, let me give one more example of the Government's callous hypocrisy. In South Australia some of the people hardest hit by the assets test are soldier settlers, the veterans who, after World War II, were granted as a reward for their service and their bravery 640 acres to build a new life-the soldier's square mile as it was called. Few of them are rich and many of them have low incomes. But the assets test, because land values have been unrealistically assessed, will either rob them of their pensions, reduce their pensions or force them to sell up and leave their farms. This Government was generous in the circumstances. I will spit this out because it is deserving of being said. The Government made a great concession to these people. It said that their war decorations, however, were not to be regarded as an asset, so the pensioner veterans who are forced to walk off their farms at least can take their medals with them. Some generous, fair and equitable Government.

The Australia that I grew up in was a nation that had respect and genuine concern for our elderly citizens. I was taught, as were so many Australians, that one of the higher purposes in public life, one of our supposedly great achievements of the past was that we led the world in our care of and our compassion for the elderly. I am proud to belong to a party which helped to build a society in which all those who worked hard, who made sacrifices and for years put money aside for the future at the expense of some immediate comfort would be helped and supported in retirement. My friends from the National Party will not mind my saying, because so many of their forebears were associated with this, that it was the Government of a very great Liberal, Alfred Deakin, which in 1908 passed the law establishing the old age pension. He did it with the full support of the Labor Opposition. It is a sad irony that now a Labor government is taking away that pension from so many Australians. It is a sad irony, to put it mildly. I am aware that certain honourable members are unhappy about this development. They have the opportunity now to do something about it. The real solution is not to amend the test though, if in the end that is what we have to do to help, we will do it; the real solution is to get rid of it. I will give the unhappy honourable members opposite the chance to stand with us now-if they have the courage-and support me as, at the expiration of some remarks on the matter of public importance, I move for the suspension of Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent General Business Notice No. 1 given for Wednesday, 8 May 1985, being called on forthwith and a motion being moved for the second reading of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: — Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—I have moved the suspension of Standing Orders because it is clear from today that we will not get legislation to even amend the assets test, but we will have to revoke it by the measures that I have given notice of and the Bill that I have presented. I seek to suspend the Standing Orders in order that we can, in fact, proceed to a debate on the legislation. A motion to repeal Government legislation is not a matter to be lightly undertaken. But the repeal of the Government's assets test has become not only necessary, but also urgent, and for very compelling reasons: First, because it is creating manifest hardship and suffering for thousands of elderly Australians; second, because its discrimination between one group of pensioners and another is divisive and unjust; and third, because it is wrong in principle, as I said earlier, in that the assets test is a retrospective tax on savings and investment and it affects most cruelly people who have had no idea during their working lives that what they had put away for their retirement would become not assets, but liabilities. That is the need for honourable members opposite to support the Opposition and support this motion to suspend Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: Without the support of honourable members opposite, or without the 22 members who have coddled their consciences by either walking away or abstaining, I will not be able to get this Bill before the House and to the second reading stage. I ask honourable members opposite, if they have the courage of their convictions, or more than that, if they just believe that the assets test is wrong, to give support to this motion now. I recognise that they may have some problems with an Australian Labor Party that says it is all in favour of an assets test. Honourable members should remember there would not be an assets test today had this Government not legislated for it. So they may have a Caucus problem when it comes to the second reading. They may have to abstain on the Bill then. But 22 of them are concerned about the impact of the assets test and it will not cut across Labor policy for this Bill to be debated now, for it to be brought forward. I have the Bill; I am ready to go. I even have a third speech for the second reading, and a clause by clause analysis for the Committee stage. We are ready to go, as indicated by my moving this motion to suspend Standing Orders. As I say again, I take this action because the assets test strikes at the very heart of our concept of a compassionate and caring society. The assets test punishes thrift; it makes a mockery of sacrifice and of saving; and it ignores the contribution to Australia's security and prosperity made by a generation of Australians to whom we all in this House owe a profound debt. It goes further and visits that punishment on pensioners' families and their children by provisions which do not take into account the fact that the continuity of the family, its stability an its permanence is one of the mainstays of the Australian way of life.

I gave earlier some examples. I have given many more examples in the House on previous occasions. Members on this side in Question Time and in general debate have given an abundance of examples, which demand the repeal of this cruel legislation. I saw the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), the leader who scuttled from Queensland because he could not stand the heat of the kitchen there, on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program wringing his hands with concern about the assets test and all that he and 21 others, led by the honourable member for Gippsland-I am sorry, the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham); the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has done a great job in regard to the assets test-need do is support our Bill. The honourable member for McMillan has merely mouthed his concern. This man, who is normally so insignificant, told the Melbourne Herald-he is on the record-that he would fight to change this situation. It will be interesting to see what he says when the Herald rings him and asks why he will not even, by the sound of things, support this Bill getting to the second reading stage. Let us see how he gets out of that, how he explains his actions to all those pensioners in his electorate who are being hurt today.

Every member of this House has heard of individual cases from constituents and knows about problems raised by the media. While they may be individual cases, this does not in any way diminish the extent of the anxiety, of the suffering and of the hardship which the unprincipled legislation which the Government has imposed on this nation has caused because that suffering is the cruel sum of quite singular injustices. The fundamental reason why I have put forward this motion today is to get my legislation into the Parliament and have it debated. It is why the existing statute should be repealed. There are other reasons, one of which is that the confusion and the anxiety which it has created among Australia's elderly citizens are matched only by that of the Government itself. The confusion is clear in the changes that have been made, under public pressure, to make the legislation work, to make it more just and equitable. This is an exercise in futility because, frankly, such legislation could never be just or equitable. That is why we want to introduce legislation to repeal the assets test; it is why I seek with this procedural motion to suspend Standing Orders so that we can get on from this day with the passing of this legislation. My colleague Senator Messner will ensure that it goes through the Senate; so, by tonight, we could eradicate the assets test. If the existing legislation is still in place when honourable members opposite go to bed tonight, it is they who will be responsible-every one of them. This is their opportunity to free pensioners from the anxiety that they are suffering at present.

As I have said, by authoritative accounts 22 members on the Government side ought to be supporting us. This Bill will have the effect of rendering the assets test inoperative because it prescribes that, notwithstanding any of the provisions which implement the assets test, in determining a person's eligibility for a pension the value of that person's property or a spouse's property shall not be taken into account. That is why I say that the Government can end the assets test tonight. More steps will have to be taken; we have had to follow this simple procedure with the Bill and the provisions I have foreshadowed in seeking to suspend the Standing Orders because the provisions I have just referred to will render the assets test inoperative and of no effect. I am advised that it would then be desirable, after my Bill is enacted, to have further detailed amendments formally repealing each of the relevant sections of the legislation by which the assets test was implemented. If this Bill were to be passed here and in the Senate, the assets test from tonight could be inoperative and of no effect. Then, following the passage of our legislation, further provisions would be necessary to ensure that it could not be used.

This punitive, unjust and unprincipled legislation has oft been described by us as striking cruelly into the whole spectrum of Australian society because not only elderly people are suffering but also sons and daughters to whom inheritance undoubtedly will be denied will suffer. There are also those now contemplating retirement who see that the modest rewards of a lifetime of saving and sacrifice will now be lost to them. Its effects are not only punitive but also in a fundamental sense, as I said earlier, retrospective because the assets test taxes savings and investments created when no such legislation existed, nor was such a test even remotely in prospect. There was no warning of it in the election campaign of 1983. People had no idea that this legislation was to be implemented. It was not in prospect because until this Government acted as it did, it was a main strand in the fabric of the Australian way of life that those who worked, saved and made sacrifices for their future and that of their children and who sought to create some modest comfort for their later years should be rewarded by a somewhat peaceful and contented retirement. In one stroke the Government has torn that fabric apart. So, as well as being wrong in principle, unjust in practice and totally inept in its administration, the assets test is un-Australian and that is why it should be repealed. That is why this motion to suspend Standing Orders should be supported.
