It represents the start in establishing a truly national transport strategy for Australia because it deals not only with roads but also with railways, research and road safety. It is the first time a Federal government has adopted a comprehensive approach to land transport funding. I cannot emphasise too strongly the importance that efficient transport systems have to the economic well-being of all Australians. About $1 in every seven spent in this country is on transport. Transport impacts on every facet of our economic and social activity. Yet for too long inaction by Federal governments has allowed our transport systems to flounder without a national sense of direction or priority.

Since this Government has assumed office we have devoted considerable effort and resources to addressing the shortcomings of Australia's transport system in a cohesive and coherent way. We have made substantial progress which is due in large part to this Government's policy of working in consultation with other governments, industry and employees. The Bill now before the House will be the foundation upon which our overall approach to transport will be based. It provides a use related basis for determining Federal expenditure on land transport systems. Furthermore, the arrangements incorporate an automatic adjustment to match future inflationary movements as measured by the consumer price index.

It guarantees the continuity of the greatest road building program in Australia's history, which has been progressively implemented during our two years of government. Together with the Australian bicentennial roads development program, Federal expenditure on roads will total $1,245m in 1985-86. The Federal road safety promotion and research program undertaken by the Federal Office of Road Safety is incorporated into these arrangements as it is reasonable for road users to fund this area of Federal roads involvement. The Australian land transport program, or ALTP as it will no doubt be known, also maintains our support for research into land transport undertaken through the Australian Road Research Board and the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation.

Assistance is extended under the Bill to the interstate mainline railway network. Together with the establishment of the Railway Industry Council, this assistance will contribute to the development of a cohesive program to revive the Australian rail system.

The Bill establishes a trust fund which will operate on a similar basis to the ABRD Trust Fund. It provides that an indexed share of the existing excise charge on motor spirit and diesel fuel will be paid into the ALTP Trust Fund based on collections from 1 July 1985 until 30 June 1990. The initial rate has been set at 3.66c per litre. Recognising the value in providing a transitional arrangement, rather than immediately switching to the new funding method, we have provided an assurance that ALTP funding will be $810m in the first year. Clause 14 of the Bill provides for an adjustment to the excise rate to that which would have precisely raised $810m in the first year. Thus the States, local government and road interest groups have the type of funding they sought, with the additional protection of a transitional arrangement involving a guaranteed funding level for year one. The future level of expenditure under ALTP will depend upon the following two factors: The rate of consumption of motor spirit and diesel, which is the best measure of road use; and the rate of movements in the consumer price index to maintain the ALTP excise component in real terms. As I have noted earlier, together with the $440m to be provided under the ABRD program, the Federal Government's road building program in 1985-86 will total $1,245m-an increase of 82 per cent on 1981-82, the last full year of the Fraser Government. The legislation provides that specified maximum proportions of payments into the ALTP Trust Fund shall be allocated to the four roads categories and to road safety and to land transport research. These allocations have been decided after careful consideration.

The Federal Government has full financial responsibility for the construction and maintenance of national roads with the State road authorities acting as design and construction agents. Accordingly funding for national roads has been determined on the basis of maintaining, in real terms, this year's national roads expenditure under the Roads Grants Act. The Federal Government is committed to achieving an upgraded national highway system by 1988. The distribution among States of moneys allocated for national roads is not specified in the legislation, but will be determined on the basis of meeting that objective. This approach follows the arrangements adopted for national roads under the ABRD program.

Our Government also recognises the major responsibilities of local government for the development and upkeep of the local roads system. As a result funding for the local roads category in 1985-86 will also be maintained at the Roads Grants Act 1984-85 level in real terms. Accordingly there has been an adjustment to Federal funding for arterial roads. These roads are primarily a State responsibility and the States have always provided the bulk of the funding for their development. The Federal Government, for its part, has provided a major boost in assistance for these roads in recent years. Total Federal funding for arterial roads in 1985-86 will be 93 per cent more than the amount provided in 1981-82, the last full year of the Fraser Government. This means that Federal expenditure on arterial roads has grown at a faster rate than for national or local roads.

Funding for road safety and for land transport research will be limited to $5m in 1985-86, a marginal increase on the level of funding provided in the current year. Under the legislation there is also provision to fund the upgrading of the interstate mainline rail network. Funding will be conditional on the development of appropriate measures to improve the capacity of the network and the operational and commercial practices of the rail systems. Funding will be available as an option under the national roads category at the Federal Minister's discretion, or on request of the State Minister as an alternative under that State's rural arterial roads category. Overall, funding for railways will not exceed the contribution that railways make through their diesel excise payments to the ALTP Trust Fund.

Sections 17 and 18 of the Bill separate funding arrangements into two periods covering the initial two years and the subsequent three years. This provision has been included in order to allow a review of the State relativities in respect of arterial and local roads categories. Allocations to these categories in the second period are limited to 90 per cent of their initial share. The Federal Minister is required by section 19 to allocate the balance between these categories by 31 March 1987. Given that this program continues until 1990 and that existing relativities are substantially unchanged from those determined on the basis of a 1975 Bureau of Roads report, it is desirable that such a review be undertaken. I expect to appoint shortly a panel to carry out an independent review of State shares. The provisions of sections 18 and 19 allow that review to be undertaken in a manner which minimises disruption to the road construction and maintenance programs of the States and local government.

In order to provide some flexibility, sections 20 to 22 allow transfers between the various categories. I should emphasise that the transfer of funds from the urban arterial, rural arterial and local roads categories could only be undertaken at the request of, or with the agreement of, the relevant State Minister. Payments to the States or approved organisations or authorities are to be conditional upon the funds being expended for purposes approved by the Minister. The degree of Federal administrative involvement will vary from category to category. Federal approval will be required for construction projects and maintenance programs under the national, urban arterial and rural arterial roads categories.

Federal administrative controls with respect to the national roads program will follow those currently applying under the ABRD legislation. They include provision for the setting of standards and the requirement for construction works to go to tender. In respect of the arterial roads categories, a number of changes have been made. These include a provision to allow maintenance work to be eligible for Federal assistance and a requirement for approval of construction projects to enable the Federal Government to have a say in where its funds are used. As with the Roads Grants Act, there is no requirement for arterial road construction projects to be subject to tender. The States have emphasised to me the serious consequences that such a requirement, had it been included, would have had on their day labour work forces, particularly in provincial areas. Recognising our acceptance of the State argument that arterial roads are primarily their responsibility, it would have been unreasonable to include such a requirement in this legislation. I have assured State Ministers that the controls in respect of the arterial roads categories will operate in a manner that achieves administrative simplicity. Accordingly, I have indicated that the project approvals will be based on relatively generalised descriptions to identify the location of the project, the type of works to be undertaken and the project cost. I will be seeking State co-operation to direct Federal funds to a relatively few major projects on the more significant sections of the arterial roads networks.

Over time I expect to work together with the State to identify more clearly the network of major arterial roads which are of greater national significance and therefore to be accorded some priority in the allocation of Federal funds. This may at a latter stage involve the identification of a formal primary arterial road network. Assistance for local roads will again be distributed amongst States and local government authorities in each State in accordance with approved principles. No project approval arrangements will be involved and thus the overall arrangements are substantially in line with those applying to local roads under the Roads Grants Act. The arrangements also incorporate a new provision to allow bike paths to be founded under this category.

Federal approval of interstate mainline railway projects is required to ensure that the projects will upgrade the network and be related to improvements in operational and commercial practices of the rail systems. Provision is also made for appropriate construction works to go to tender. This arrangement mirrors a similar requirement in respect of urban public transport projects applying under the ABRD program.

The administrative provisions of the Bill will be substantially in accordance with those contained in the ABRD legislation. There are, however, a number of significant exceptions which I would bring to honourable members' attention. Section 32 of the Bill contains a number of provisions relating to obligations imposed upon the States and approved railway authorities. A number of these require appropriate recognition of the Federal road building effort, which constitutes over 35 per cent of total road expenditure. Similarly, Federal representatives are entitled to recognition of the efforts they make on behalf of their constituencies.

As national highways are 100 per cent funded by the Federal Government, provision is included to allow the Minister to exercise some control over the display of signs on that network. Simplified administrative arrangements in respect of the standards of national roads construction are provided. Previously, there were provisions for extensive Federal involvement to determine whether the construction of national roads had been carried out to approved standards. Under ALTP all that will be required will be a certificate from a suitable person, obviously the head of the relevant State road authority, that construction has been carried out in accordance with applicable standards.

Provision is also made for the proceeds of the sale of any land acquired by the State with Federal road funds provided since 1977 to be either repaid to the Federal Government or applied to road construction and maintenance purposes. This provision formalises an arrangement that was negotiated in 1977 by the then Federal Transport Minister with his State colleagues. It is desirable that it be given legislative basis particularly as the sums involved could be quite significant. This provision ensures that the proceeds of sale of land are applied to the original purpose for which they were provided.

The areas where the Federal Minister may delegate his powers have been marginally curtailed. Section 37 requires that ministerial declarations and directions be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. Over the life of the ALTP we will be able to make major progress along the path which has been the vision of a number of dedicated transport people since Australia's Federation. It is appropriate that I conclude by listing in simple form the objectives that I expect to achieve during the life of the legislation. These are:
establish arrangements which identify clearly for motorists and taxpayers the contribution users make to the maintenance and upgrading of our road and other transport systems;
in accordance with national priorities, assist the development and maintenance of Australia's land transport systems to facilitate the safe, reliable and efficient carriage of passengers and freight;
develop the national highway system to standards appropriate to meet the growing needs for safe transport between the major centres of population;
assist the development of urban arterial and rural arterial roads, in particular those which are of major national, commercial or industrial significance;
enable State and local governments to develop and maintain local road systems;
improve the capacity, quality and efficiency of the interstate mainline railway network;
assist activities which will enhance the safety of road users, including motorcyclists, pedestrians and cyclists; and
assist national research and development activities related to land transport.

In just 26 months we have done more than any other government to develop a coherent approach to our national transport system. Major investigations have been undertaken in virtually all areas of Federal responsibility to establish the basis on which to implement vital programs like ALTP. Specifically, in this Bill we have the fulfilment of this Government's long-standing policy commitment to the improvement of our nation's road system-a system which under conservative governments was starved of essential investment funds. Roads are the arteries which carry the life-blood of Australia. They represent a major public investment in the infrastructure upon which the health and livelihood of our national economy depends. As a government, we are building better roads for Australia and this Bill will ensure that we continue to do so. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide the Australian Shipping Commission with additional capital of $70,541,000. This additional capital is required to provide the Commission with a capital structure appropriate for a commercial enterprise and marks a further step in the Government's program of revitalising Australia's shipping industry. The Government's objective is to provide a sound base for the development of an efficient, competitive Australian shipping industry. Within this broad framework the Government is committed to ensuring the long term viability of its own shipping organisation. An efficient, profitable, commercially oriented Australian National Line is necessary to the overall effectiveness of the Australian shipping industry.

When this Government came to office in 1983, ANL was in a desperate situation. Not only was the Line financially bankrupt, with millions of dollars owed to its creditors, but also management was ineffective, the organisation was inefficient and its industrial relations record was poor. The previous Government had starved it of capital funds and had not given it sufficient freedom to operate as a commercial organisation. The ANL management structure needed overhaul. The Government responded to these problems in a positive, co-ordinated way. In 1983 we provided ANL with an emergency capital injection of $90m to meet its immediate financial crisis. This injection consisted of $30m in cash and $60m for the conversion of outstanding Treasury loans. We also agreed to roll over remaining domestic Treasury loans totalling $50.5m as they fell due. We amended the Australian Shipping Commission Act to give ANL greater commercial freedom and to enable the top management to be strengthened. We created new positions of part time Chairman and Managing Director, and appointed to them people with extensive commercial experience. We took important steps to improve industrial relations in ANL and the shipping industry generally.

The new ANL management has taken up the challenge set by the Government. It has rigorously overhauled and rationalised its organisational structure. It has critically reviewed all its commercial operations. In the light of this review some unprofitable services have been terminated. A program of disposing of uneconomic vessels and terminals has commenced. Steps are being taken to improve the productivity and profitability of its vessels and terminals. The effects of these tough decisions are now appearing, as clear evidence that the Government's policies are working. The ANL declared an operating profit of $3.3m in 1983-84 compared with an operating loss of $18.8m in 1982-83. I freely acknowledge and appreciate the contribution that the unions have made to achieve this result. But much more remains to be done before ANL can free itself from the legacy of past mismanagement. Continuing support and co-operation from the unions is needed to achieve this in what are tough market conditions for the shipping industry.

The extent of this task is revealed by its 1983-84 annual report. Past management had masked its actions by adopting accounting practices that over-valued the Line's assets and did not record the lease liabilities it had incurred. Those practices occurred under a so-called free enterprise private sector government. In fact they were endorsed by that government. Abnormal adjustments were necessary to correct this and reveal a truer asset situation. The result was a declared accumulated loss of $129.5m as at 30 June 1984. This meant that its accumulated losses had exceeded its capital and reserves by $3.7m. ANL was still technically bankrupt.

The Government determined last year that ANL's capital structure should be examined in greater detail to enable responsible decision to be taken on its longer term financial viability. A committee of officials was instructed to carry out this examination. It included representatives from the Departments of Transport, Finance and the Treasury and the ANL. The committee's report, the most comprehensive ever undertaken on the Line's finances, makes it clear that ANL operates in a very competitive environment both internationally and domestically. It has very high debt servicing charges, a legacy of past government policies, and its margin of revenues over costs is low. In 1983-84 this margin was less than 1 per cent. ANL is thus particularly susceptible to downturns in trading conditions, exchange rate movements and losses from industrial disputes. In the light of this report the Government decided to tackle ANL's financial problems at their source.

The Line's high indebtedness, the result of the past Government's approach to financing ANL's expansion into overseas trades, was the key problem that had to be solved. The $70.5m capital injection the Government decided on does this in two ways. First, it allows $50.5m of existing Treasury loans to be converted to capital. This, by reducing interest payments, provides a significant contribution to ANL's cash position. Secondly, the remaining $20m will be used to repay a Treasury on-lent loan falling due on 1 June 1985. This cash injection will help ANL get over a projected cash deficiency in 1985-86 and 1986-87. At the same time ANL's capital base has been re-established on a properly commercial basis.

The Government now believes that the $70.5m that this Bill will provide when enacted will put ANL into a position where it has the flexibility and incentive necessary to pursue improved commercial performance, to continue to restructure its activities and to seek out profitable new business opportunities. In saying this it should be made clear that ANL has not been given a feather-bedded path to future prosperity. The international shipping industry remains severely depressed with fierce competition coming from foreign shipowners in a very depressed market at least in the short run. On the Australian coast, competition is also increasing, for example, as new services start across the Bass Strait. There can be no doubt that ANL and its employees have a difficult task ahead of them.

In short, the Government has made what it considers to be a major effort to revitalise ANL. It has remedied the undercapitalisation that past governments should never have allowed to occur. It is now up to ANL management, its employees and the unions. It has been made clear to each that the Government expects continuing improvements in ANL's performance to generate and provide the cash required for investment in new ships and equipment and to pay dividends.

The Government is confident that this legislation provides the basis for a commercially viable national shipping line that will benefit all ANL customers, the Australian economy, and Australians generally. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) Adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) raised a matter of privilege. He referred to a notice displayed in the Parliament House post office advising of a union ban on all mail dispatches, including priority paid and express courier mail, to Queensland until 13 May 1985. My duty is to decide whether the facts, as presented, constitute prima facie evidence of a breach of privilege.

INTERJECT.PARA: The particular circumstances applying in the matter raised by the right honourable gentleman, as I understand them, are that union bans have been placed in respect of the conveyance of all mail to Queensland. These actions are not, I understand, directed in any particular way at members of parliament. The situation is rather that members, along with other people in the community, may be affected. Members are thus not being subjected to particular action in their capacity as members.

I have had recourse to the records of our own Parliament and to those of the United Kingdom House of Commons to assist me in this matter. Whilst I acknowledge that members may be inconvenienced by the actions in question, I am particularly aware of the general reluctance of the Parliament to extend the limits of contempt and of the general principle that the House should exercise its penal jurisdiction as sparingly as possible and only when satisfied that to do so is essential in order to provide reasonable protection for the House, its members and committees from substantial interference with their functions. Accordingly, I am of the opinion that the matter raised does not constitute a prima facie case of breach of privilege. I cannot, therefore, accord precedence to a motion in respect of the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Speaker, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Acting Speaker's ruling be dissented from.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the motion in writing?
—Yes. I hand a copy to the Clerk.
—I second the motion, Madam Acting Speaker, and reserve my right to speak.

—It is a difficult issue-I think that every member of this House accepts that-to determine whether a prima facie case is made out in respect of a breach of privilege. Obviously, any procedure or action which interrupts the normal business of a member of this place is a matter that raises concern. In common with many honourable members, I turned to see what privileges had previously been determined and in particular to see whether there existed any relevant procedures within our Standing Orders or within the Hansard record of your predecessors, Madam Acting Speaker, which might have relevance to this instance. Perhaps the one case that most accords with this category is that which was raised by the then honourable member for Maranoa, as reported at page 731 of House of Representatives Hansard of 15 March 1978. The matter, however, related specifically to an industrial dispute within the Australian Capital Territory, affecting the distribution of mail from Canberra out around the electorate. In his determination, Mr Speaker Snedden responded-I refer honourable members to page 760 of Hansard of the same date-as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I am informed that the strike is not directed at the Parliament but involves the non-conveyance of mails for whole of Canberra in which the parliamentary deliveries are but a part.

As I understand your ruling, Madam Acting Speaker, it similarly identifies the fact that this is an industrial dispute not applicable specifically to members of the Parliament, but certainly including the members of Parliament within its embrace. To that degree, therefore, it parallels the decision of your predecessor. However, I suggest that the reason why I must dissent from your ruling is that in this instance it is not a dispute affecting Canberra and hence the people of the Australian Capital Territory as a whole, but it affects mail into and out of one State of this Commonwealth. I suggest that that puts the whole question of this determination into an entirely different context.

When looking at the determination of just what is meant by parliamentary privilege and what we are talking about, I think it is worth while turning to Erskine May's Parliamentary Practice. I refer to the nineteenth edition. I know that there are a good many different editions in the House. On page 136 of that nineteenth edition, May states:

It would be vain to attempt in enumeration of every act which might be construed into a contempt, the power to punish for contempt being in its nature discretionary. Certain principles may, however, be collected from the Journals which will serve as general declarations of the law of Parliament. It may be stated generally that any act or omission which obstructs or impedes either House of Parliament in the performance of its functions, or which obstructs or impedes any member or officer of such House in the discharge of his duty, or which has a tendency, directly or indirectly, to produce such results may be treated as a contempt even though there is no precedent of the offence.

I put it to you, Madam Acting Speaker, that your ruling is in error because there is no doubt that this mail dispute, affecting delivery into and out of the State of Queensland, one State alone of the Commonwealth-a dispute which involves both a Commonwealth instrumentality and, indirectly, this Federal Government, which is putting itself on line with the Australian Council of Trade Unions blockade of Queensland in a most reprehensible fashion-is an act which obstructs or impedes this House and the Senate in the performance of their functions, on the first part, and which obstructs or impedes the members of this House and senators in the other place in the discharge of their duties. Accordingly, Madam Acting Speaker, I put it to you that your ruling is in error.
On the second matter, it might be worth while, before turning back to our House of Representatives Practice with respect to your ruling, to look at page 151 of the same edition, where May states:

Conduct not amounting to a direct attempt to influence a Member in the discharge of his duties, but having a tendency to impair his independence in the future performance of his duty, will also be treated as a breach of privilege.

In that respect there is a reference to a House of Commons precedent which shows that in regard to a letter sent by a parliamentary agent to a member with respect to the promoters of a private Bill, an interruption to its delivery constituted a prima facie breach of privilege. Madam Acting Speaker, I put it to you that we are not finally determining the question of privilege; we are determining whether or not an act by this Government and by the Australian Postal Commission, a Commonwealth instrumentality, is tantamount to seeing the members of this place in any way inhibited in the performance of their duty. I put it to you that that second point-that is, that they are acts tending indirectly to obstruct members in the discharge of their duties-has demonstrably been filled by the actions of Australia Post in putting up this notice.

I point out to all honourable members that this notice was put on the counter of the Parliament House post office. It is not something which is applicable to everybody. It applies particularly to members of this place, who are being told that they are not allowed and will not be able to send mail for the period up to 13 May. So it affects all members of this place. For that reason, I contend that it is a prima facie breach of privilege and it should be referred to the Standing Committee on Privileges. I again draw honourable members' attention to page 160 of that same edition of Erskine May, where it states:

As regards the forwarding of complaints by members of the armed forces to Members of Parliament, while it is the policy of service departments that the usual service channels should be used wherever possible, service regulations give an absolute right to servicemen to communicate with Members on all matters, including service matters, so long as there is no disclosure of secret information.

Madam Acting Speaker, I put it to you that exactly the same right applies in Australia. Because of this postal dispute servicemen will certainly be inhibited in contacting their many members of parliament in this place who would wish to try to pursue, quite properly, matters that fall within the category which I have just read from Erskine May. Within Erskine May there is a series of precedents which suggest that there is a prima facie breach of privilege in this case.

I would like to run briefly through two other precedents before I go on to some of the facts that surround this matter. I think it is worth turning to page 643, I think it is the first edition of the House of Representatives Practice, which states:

Parliamentary privilege relates to the rights and immunities which belong to the Parliament, its Members and others, which are essential for the operation of the Parliament. These rights and immunities allow the Parliament to meet and carry out its proper constitutional role, for Members to discharge their responsibilities to their constituents and for others properly involved in the parliamentary process to carry out their duties and responsibilities without obstruction or fear of prosecution.

Pensioners-any people-who wish to contact members of this Parliament and are inhibited by this deliberate act to prevent members sending mail from this place to Queensland and Queenslanders sending their mail to the Parliament are covered by that general provision. The House of Representatives Practice continues:
Privileges are not the prerogative of Members in their personal capacities. It has been stated:

Insofar as the House claims and Members enjoy those rights and immunities which are grouped under the general description of 'privileges', they are claimed and enjoyed by the House in its corporate capacity and by its Members on behalf of the citizens whom they represent.

When any of these rights and immunities, both of the Members, individually, and of the assembly in its collective capacity . . . are disregarded or attacked by any individual or authority, the offence is called a breach of privilege, and is punishable under the law of Parliament.

Madam Acting Speaker, I put it to you that that again is directly within the compass of this industrial stoppage, endorsed by Australia Post and supported by the Australian Government, and it deliberately intervenes in the proper process of the members of this Parliament and their constituents in the conduct of their lawful duty. I put it to you also that it is worth noting that section 92 of the Australian Constitution states:
On the imposition of uniform duties of customs, trade commerce, and intercourse among the States, whether by means of internal carriage or ocean navigation, shall be absolutely free.

So we have not only a prima facie breach of parliamentary privilege but also an interruption to the normal distribution of services and trade within and between the States. I believe that not only is that a matter of a breach of parliamentary privilege, but also it may well constitute an act contrary to the Australian Constitution. If we look at page 645 of the fifth edition of Odgers's Australian Senate Practice we find a statement by Sir Barnett Cocks, a former Clerk of the House of Commons. He comments:

Under the law of Parliament, any act which obstructs or impedes the House in its functions, or any Member of the House in his duties in the Commons, may be treated as a contempt, even though there may be no precedent for the offence.
Odgers's Australian Senate Practice continues:
At the beginning of each session at Westminster, the following Sessional Order is made:

That the Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis do take care that during the Session of Parliament, the passages through the streets leading to this House be kept free and open, and that no obstruction be permitted to hinder the passage of Members to and from this House, and that no disorder be allowed . . . or in the passage leading to this House, during the Sitting of Parliament, and that there be no annoyance therein or thereabouts; and that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House do communicate this Order to the Commissioner aforesaid.
It continues:

This freedom from obstruction in the coming to or the going from the House derives from the undoubted right of Parliament to the full service of its Members. It is a privilege which derives from the right and need of the House of Commons to protect itself, and in so doing to protect its Members.

There is little doubt that there is any amount of precedents that show that any interruption that affects the contact between members of the public and members of the parliament is such that it can constitute a breach of privilege. Madam Acting Speaker, I put it to you that all we need do in the present instance is constitute a prima facie case. We are not finally establishing the full details of it, but what we on this side of the Parliament seek to do is to ensure that the Privileges Committee can look at the circumstances which interrupt the passage of mail between the State of Queensland and the Parliament, between members of Parliament and that State. We look to ensure that there is a freedom of trade and commerce. We look to ensure that the Government does not give any countenance to the blackmail of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the members of the Electrical Trades Union of Australia who are seeking to disrupt the supply of power to people in Queensland. That is the genesis of the dispute. The ultimate is that this Government in this place is seeking to support an action by Australia Post, a statutory authority, which is interrupting members in the conduct of their duty. It is necessary for members in this place to recognise that it is not sufficient for the Parliament just to sit back and accept that there can be industrial action which precludes members from proper contact with their constituents. Madam Acting Speaker, I believe that it is a difficult decision for you to take. I appreciate the time, care and consideration which has been given both to an examination of appropriate precedents and to the responsibilities which you now exercise.

I think we need to remember that, in determining privilege, certainly there is no reason to extend the bounds beyond that on which determination has already been made. But it is essential that nobody in the Australian community sees an action taken by a wilful group of trade unionists to disrupt members in the conduct of their responsibilities. It is necessary that people in the community understand that those who are elected as members of this place have not just a right but a responsibility to conduct their affairs and relationships with their constituents in a way that is not interrupted by any procedure, and certainly not by an industrial stoppage. This notice to which I have referred was put on the post office desk. This is not just any post office; it is the post office of the Parliament of Australia. This direction is not being given specifically to the community at large; in this instance it is a direction being given to everybody who uses the Parliament House post office.

Madam Acting Speaker, when you gave your opinion earlier you talked about a ban applying to the community at large. This particular ban about which I am protesting is one that has occurred in this Parliament, it is one that applies directly to ensure that members of this place take note that they will not be able to conduct the affairs that they have a responsibility to undertake for their constituents. I can understand the difficulties in determining how far this law applies. If we take this notice as not being a breach of privilege, we need to remember that we can find all sorts of unlikely circumstances which might well be an extension of the present ban. To what extent will this Parliament allow industrial action to stop its procedures? If honourable members were precluded by industrial action from coming to Canberra and undertaking deliberations on matters of substance for this nation, if there were to be an industrial stoppage and a notice placed in the Parliament that there would be no access into this Parliament for honourable members or no communications, that would certainly be a breach of privilege. Indeed, the House of Commons each year promulgates a special procedure to ensure that such action will not be permitted.

A physical obstruction is a breach of privilege. To what degree is it different from this instance? This is not a physical obstruction, but it is an obstruction in communication. It is a deliberate obstruction because there is a notice on the post office desk. It is not something that is out there in the wild, it is here in the Parliament. What lies behind it all and what concerns me is that, quite obviously, this Government sees fit to give a statutory authority licence to ensure that there is not only just tacit support for the trade union movement but also positive support against the actions and considered responsibilities of an independent democratic State in this Federation.

Madam Acting Speaker, it is necessary that this Parliament very carefully deliberate on the determination you have made. It is a very serious matter when a trade union can interrupt the affairs of parliamentarians in this way. It is a matter which certainly does prevent a range of people from having proper contact. It means that members in this place are inhibited from conducting their affairs as they would wish. It means that my colleagues from Queensland-I know there are many of them because the people of Queensland know full well that the Government Party little represents them here-know that they are not going to be able to communicate by mail with their constituents. They know that if their constituents write to them about the assets test, which was before the Parliament today, about the drought that so adversely affects so many areas in Australia, about the problems that we are told will flow from the discussions on the tax changes that might be before the summit or about the problems that affect any of the financial deliberations that will come before the Parliament next Tuesday, the mail will be delayed. They know that they will be precluded from communicating with their constituents.

A decision of this kind is one which, I believe, must be taken with great care and deliberation. Madam Acting Speaker, I believe that Australian Senate Practice, May's Parliamentary Practice and our own House of Representatives Practice detail determinations which show that the determination you have made is in error. For that reason I moved dissent from your ruling. We need to know that you are going to act in the interests of members of this place. If your decision applies, it will mean that there can by any wilful interruption to the proceedings of this place. It does not apply in this instance only to the mail services, it applies by reference to any other communication by any honourable member with his constituency if it lies in one particular State.

I do not believe that it is sufficient to suggest that the precedents are not applicable simply because others will also be affected by the failure to deliver mail. In this instance parliamentary members are particularly affected. Because it applies to one State I suggest to you that the decision is quite different from the decision taken on an earlier occasion by Mr Speaker Snedden. I believe that it should be distinguished from that decision. I believe that this House should determine that a prima facie case has been established by the presentation of this notice which was on the desk of the post office in Parliament House. I, therefore, believe that we should endorse this motion of dissent from your ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Speaker, the Opposition, as I am sure you are aware, has not moved this motion of dissent from your ruling in any sense in a personal way. Matters of privilege affect all members of Parliament and in fact the question of privileges generally is absolutely fundamental to the operation of the Westminster system of government.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is wise for us all to reflect for a moment on what was one of the bases of privilege in the first place, when members of parliament in Westminster were at one stage being obstructed from travelling to the parliament to conduct their business, were being interfered with in their passage to the parliament, and as a result the Westminster Parliament took particular action to provide them with privilege. This is a very important aspect of the life of any parliamentarian particularly one operating under the Westminster system. What it is really all about is the interference in the actions of a member in the pursuance of his duties. The idea of privilege is to stop any undue interference being placed upon any member of the parliament to prevent him carrying out his duties properly and fully, or to coerce him in any way, to attempt to place undue pressure upon him in order to get him to change his opinion, or to cause him concern.

We have here a very serious matter because there is no doubt that members of parliament who represent electorates in Queensland do have the need to communicate with constituents in that State, as do those in the Ministry or the shadow Ministry who, as part of their broader duties, will need to have contact with people living in Queensland. Here we have a situation where a trade union has placed a ban on the transference of mail from Parliament House to Queensland and from Queensland to Parliament House. There are two aspects of this matter to which I think we need to pay attention. Firstly, we have a situation where a trade union is in fact setting itself above the authority of the Parliament. That is a matter which should be of concern to all members of the Parliament, no matter which particular political party they belong to. We know that in the majority of cases members of the Australian Labor Party owe their positions in this House to support from one trade union or another and therefore they are placed in an invidious situation because it could be said that they are acting at the behest of a trade union. In fact, there have been some cases recorded in history of matters of privilege being brought up in relation to attempted pressure from trade unions upon members of trade unions who were members of the House.

The other problem, of course, is that members of this Parliament, whether they be in the Senate or the House of Representatives, have had placed upon them an imposition which prevents them from sending mail to Queensland or receiving mail from Queensland, as I understand it. In my view that constitutes a contempt of this House and a breach of privilege. I quote from Odgers's Australian Senate Practice although, as I understand it, it may not be as applicable to this House as it is to the Senate. However, I think it is instructive for us to read what was said by Sir Barnett Cocks, a former Clerk of the House of Commons, and quoted in that publication:

Under the law of Parliament, any act which obstructs or impedes the House in its functions, or any Member of the House in his duties in the Commons, may be treated as a contempt, even though there be no precedent for the offence.

Madam Acting Speaker, I know you have relied upon precedents for the ruling you have made. I put it to you that the quote I have just read suggests that there is no need in this particular case to look to precedent for the decision that you take.

There is another aspect of this matter which has not been brought up at this stage but which I think needs to be at least considered. The post office in Parliament House operates within the precincts of the parliamentary Houses and as such comes within the jurisdiction of yourself, as the Acting Speaker, and the President of the Senate. As I understand it, any group or organisation which operates or has premises within this House or carries out its duties within this House must obey the rulings of the Speaker or the President. In this particular case I wonder whether or not the post office, situated within the precincts of Parliament House, made the decision it has taken available to you, Madam Acting Speaker, or to the President, or sought permission for its operations to be carried out, or rather not carried out, in this particular way. If it did not, I suggest that it is at least arguable that you and the President should look very closely at the operations of the post office within the precincts of the House to ensure that in so acting it has not rendered itself guilty of the charge of breach of privilege.

The other point I would like to raise has also been raised by the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Sinclair). I quote from a section in House of Representatives Practice, at page 655, headed 'Attempts by improper means to influence Members in their parliamentary conduct'. The first item under that heading is 'The offer of a bribe'; the second is 'Attempted intimidation of Members', under which it is stated:
To attempt by any means to influence a member in his conduct as a member is a breach of privilege.

That, on the face of it, is obviously the case in this particular circumstance. One could argue, and it has been argued, that the ban applies generally, that it does not apply only to members of parliament. But I suggest that privilege is available only to members of parliament and that therefore separates them out from the general population. That is why questions of privilege are so important to this House and to its individual members. Members of this House, whether they like it or not, because of their membership of the House attract to themselves the concept of parliamentary privilege. The argument that just because a particular situation applies to the population in general, therefore members of parliament must put up with it, does not take into account the overriding responsibility of members of parliament to carry out their duties on behalf of their constituents.

There is no doubt, Madam Acting Speaker, that the prevention of the passage of mail from and to members of parliament obviously interferes with their rights and duties as members of this House. Therefore, there is a very clear case in this particular circumstance for this question of privilege to be looked at perhaps more closely than has been the case up to now. We are not suggesting that the final analysis will not be in line with the ruling you have so far given. However, I put it to you, Madam Acting Speaker, that the matter was raised earlier today but the consideration of the matter was not extensive. I am not criticising your rapidity of thought or consideration in relation to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a reflection on the Acting Speaker.
—We have an interjection from an honourable member who is here as a representative of the trade unions. He has not got the courage to stand up to a situation in which the trade unions--

—Order! The honourable member for Warringah will resume his seat for a moment, please. I suggest to the House that this is a very important matter which is being debated and the Chair would appreciate it if honourable members would cease interjecting.

—The situation is that we have a government which is beholden to the trade unions. Everybody knows that and that in this instance, with action being carried out against the State of Queensland, this Government is craven in its acceptance of the Australian Council of Trade Union actions in relation to attempted blockades and other attempted action against individuals and the public generally. One of the worst aspects of this entire situation is that the postal service is involved. Here we have a Commonwealth instrumentality involved in a ban on mail passing to and from Queensland from members of parliament and to members of parliament. I think if for no other reason than the fact that it is a Commonwealth instrumentality and it is another example of unions seeking to place themselves above the Parliament, every parliamentarian in this place should treat the matter with the utmost seriousness. Not to do so is to accept an inferior position created by actions carried out by unelected people throughout the community and to denigrate their positions as members of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: We are suggesting that the matter should be looked at in more detail because there are some real ramifications which flow from it. I have already mentioned the fact that the action is being carried out within the precincts of Parliament House. I take it that neither you nor the President were consulted before that action was taken and I think it is your responsibility and the President's responsibility to oversee what does take place within the precincts of Parliament House. Above all, we as parliamentarians have to look extremely carefully at any attempt to interfere with the overriding right of this Parliament and its members to decide the laws of the land and to act for the good of the government of the country. Anything which interferes with the opportunities and rights of individual members of parliament, no matter which side of the House they sit upon, should be looked at with the utmost seriousness. I am not suggesting, Madam Acting Speaker, that you have not looked at it with the utmost seriousness. I am suggesting, though, that the matter is one which requires more consideration and that is the reason why the Opposition has moved this dissent from your ruling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Speaker, this is the 131st time since Federation that a dissent has been moved from the Speaker's ruling. There have been six occasions when dissent motions have been successful, and I have no doubt in my mind that everybody in this House, including the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), knows that this motion does not warrant success. This motion lacks the substance to be carried by this House. It would set a precedent of utter nonsense as far as privilege in this Parliament is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us deal with the matter as the House became aware of the events of the day. This matter was first raised in the Parliament by the right honourable member for New England when he declared that a sign which he said had been displayed in the post office in Parliament House suggested that mail was not being dispatched to certain areas. I understand from the people working at the post office that they were not asked whether the sign could be taken away. Some member of the Opposition just grabbed the sign and took it from the post office. The person who did that ought to return to the post office and apologise to the employees working there. The bans have not been imposed by the Australian Government authority Australia Post; they of course have been imposed by the unions involved. The mail is being accepted by Australia Post but not dispatched. The bans do not only affect the mail of members of parliament; they affect all mail. Madam Acting Speaker, when, based on all the precedents that Parliament has to offer you, you gave your statement before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I would have thought that the right honourable member for New England, having raised this matter, would have accepted that your explanation and your ruling were in fact correct based on matters that have previously been raised not only in this Parliament but also in the House of Commons, upon which our practices are so much based. I repeat, Madam Acting Speaker, what you told the House:

The particular circumstances applying in the matter raised by the right honourable gentleman, as I understand them, are that union bans have been placed in respect of the conveyance of all mail to Queensland. These actions are not, I understand, directed in any particular way at members of parliament. The situation is rather that members, along with other people in the community, may be affected. Members are thus not being subjected to particular action in their capacity as members.

I have had recourse to the records of our own Parliament and to those of the United Kingdom House of Commons to assist me in this matter. Whilst I acknowledge that members may be inconvenienced by the actions in question, I am particularly aware of the general reluctance of the Parliament to extend the limits of contempt and of the general principle that the House should exercise its penal jurisdiction as sparingly as possible and only when satisfied that to do so is essential in order to provide reasonable protection for the House, its members and committees from substantial interference with their functions.

Madam Acting Speaker, in quite a concise and succinct statement you outlined to the Parliament what is perfectly correct. This motion of dissent brings into ridicule the very operation of privilege in the Parliament. May I remind honourable members opposite that a number of parliamentary democracies have done away with privilege because of the way in which it was abused, which reflected upon the Chair and denigrated the role of the Chair. House of Representatives Practice, at page 222, states:

The procedure of dissenting from a ruling of the Speaker is not shared in the practice of the lower Houses of other major Commonwealth countries, namely, the United Kingdom, Canada and India. Before the dissent provision was abolished in the Canadian House of Commons, Laundry stated:

In practice, the rule tends to encourage Members to challenge Speakers' rulings, and when carried to extreme lengths . . . its use can seriously undermine the authority of the Chair and lead to a serious disruption of business. It is also open to criticism on the ground that a Speaker, in order to avoid the damage to his prestige and authority which the rejection of one of his rulings by the House would inevitable involve, might tend to rule as a matter of course in favour of the majority in order to ensure that his rulings will be sustained.
It is to be hoped that exercises that have been undertaken by the Opposition today will not lead to the abolition of the use of privilege in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you threatening us?

—I am not threatening the Opposition at all. The right honourable member for New England knows that very shortly in this Parliament time may be set aside for a debate of this nature. It is not so very long ago that a matter of privilege was referred to and discussed by the Committee of Privileges. It thought there was a prima facie case. The Parliament can get itself into an awful mess if it thinks that every time it is slightly upset by the actions of someone it can interpret these as a direction to try to prevent members of parliament from carrying out their duties. Allegations of breaches of privilege are serious matters which the House must deal with in all seriousness. Motions of dissent from the Speaker's rulings are even more serious.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no wish and no intention to make this issue one of partisan controversy and division. I have examined this case on its merits with full regard to the precedents which are available. Contempt is a broad and vague notion. Essentially we are called upon to judge questions which may affect the ability of members to carry out their official duties. In practice assessing cases of contempt becomes an exercise in political, professional and personal judgment. That exercise must be backed up by a precedent, by experience and, most of all, by common sense. I find that precedent, experience and common sense have all led the one way in helping me to make up my mind on this case. I have been guided by the consistent concern of our Parliament and of other Westminster systems around the world. They have remained reluctant to extend the boundaries of contempt and have resorted to exercising the penal jurisdiction of Parliament as sparingly as possible. I refer honourable members to a specific case which occurred in Westminster when the Speaker was asked to rule about pickets trying to prevent members from entering the Parliament. He said:
I now have to rule upon the complaint of breach of privilege raised yesterday by the hon. Member for Staffordshire, . . .
''namely, the action of certain public servants and those inciting them to frustrate the work of Parliament''.
I wish to make as clear as I can to the House my function, as I see it, in a matter such as this.

My duty is to decide whether in my judgment the facts alleged fall sufficiently clearly within an area in which a breach of privilege or a contempt of the House has been found by the House on a previous occasion to have been committed, or whether they fall sufficiently clearly within an area in which a possible breach of privilege or contempt should be considered, so that I should allow a motion relating to the complaint to have precedence.
As the House knows, I dislike the term ''prima facie case'', because I think that that implies a judgment on the merits of the case.
If I decide in the negative, that is not necessarily the end of the matter. The House could come to a decision on the point on a motion moved subsequently after notice.
In the present instance I know of no precedent for the House having reached decision upon, or indeed even having formally considered, a similar case.
There has also been of recent years a reluctance to extend the limits of contempt.

Accordingly, although important issues are involved affecting the efficiency and convenience of the house, which need careful consideration at some stage, and perhaps not only by the House, I have come to the conclusion that I should not allow a motion relating to the hon. Member's complaint to have precedence over the Orders of the Day.

As I have said earlier, this is not the first time this situation has occurred. A similar ruling was also given in 1978 when the former member for Maranoa, Mr Corbett, raised exactly the same question about a mail strike and about its impact upon the delivery of mail to his electorate from this Parliament House. Exactly the same decision was given by the Speaker in 1978 as has been given by the Acting Speaker now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was the Speaker then?

—The Speaker then was elected by a conservative government. We do not have to go back too far to find examples. One may recall action by the pilots who were going to stop transport to Canberra because of actions by the Government relating to a number of matters, one of which was the tax on lump sum superannuation payments. We did not hear the Opposition saying then: 'We have to do something about the pilots because they are preventing members of parliament from reaching the Parliament'. Madam Acting Speaker, your ruling is perfectly correct. It holds the Parliament in good stead. It cannot be misused as a precedent in future perhaps for frivolously wasting the time of Parliament on matters of privilege. Privilege, as I have said, is an enormously important weapon in the hands of this Parliament. It ought to be respected as such. The work that has been done by the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege under the chairmanship of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) will be up for debate in the Parliament. Hopefully, some of the mistakes previous Parliaments have made about how they thought they could interpret privilege will not be made in the future as a result of the hard work that has been done by the Committee. I invite honourable members opposite after this event to look at the precedents of parliament when they test their own consciences about this issue in deciding whether they think the action has been taken by the right honourable member for New England tonight is correct or otherwise. It is not correct and we reject it out of hand. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The right honourable member may proceed.
—It was claimed that the matter before us is frivolous. I quote from section 94 of the Postal Services Act 1975. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not wilfully obstruct or hinder the conveyance or delivery by or on behalf of the Commission of any mail or postal article.
Penalty-Imprisonment for 1 year.
This is not a lighthearted or frivolous matter. I thoroughly object to the suggestion that it is.
Original question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This is the first of two Bills being introduced concurrently which provide a legislative basis for decisions previously announced by the Government on the collection and disbursement of levy payments under the Bass Strait freight equalisation scheme. The amendments are in the nature of technical adjustments and arise primarily from changes in assessed freight costs and the need to correct anomalies in the rules governing the pattern of disbursements following the introduction of a partial allocation scheme for Bass Strait crude oil from 1 January 1985 and the closure of the BP refinery at Westernport, Victoria, during February 1985. The operation of the freight equalisation scheme, and the question of whether there should be any further change in the levy redistribution formula, will be further considered in light of the outcome of the Government's review of the desirability of accelerated movement towards a free market for indigenous crude oil.

The purpose of this first Bill is to amend the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act 1984 to give effect to variations in the rate of adjustment levy imposed on unstabilised crude petroleum oil produced in the Gippsland Basin in Bass Strait and announced in Parliament on 27 February 1985. The amendments increase the adjustment levy to $1.39 per kilolitre from 1 January 1985 and to $1.96 per kilolitre from 1 March 1985 in line with changes in the assessed costs of coastal freight movements of Bass Strait crude oil and decisions announced by the Government last October on the proportion of these costs to be redistributed among refiners. In order to minimise the legislative burden which may arise from future variations in the levy rate, clause 5 of the Bill defines the per kilolitre adjustment levy as a fixed 65 per cent of the special freight allowance component of the import parity price of Bass Strait crude oil as determined from time to time by the Minister.

The legislation has no financial implications for the Commonwealth. The amount of revenue raised through the adjustment levy is disbursed to eligible companies in accordance with provisions of the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act 1984. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hodgman) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Amendment Bill is the second of two interrelated Bills which give effect to changes in the operation of the Bass Strait coastal freight adjustment scheme following the introduction of a partial allocation scheme for Bass Strait crude oil from 1 January 1985 and the closure in February 1985 of the BP refinery at Westernport in Victoria.

This Bill amends the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act in three substantive respects. First, it provides for consequential amendments of the Act to harmonise its references to adjustment levy with the new rates of levy being introduced by parallel amendments of the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act. Secondly, it provides for reimbursement to the producers of amounts of levy paid on domestic free market sales from 1 January 1985 when the partial allocation scheme came into operation. Thirdly, it introduces a new basis for calculating each refiner's share in monthly disbursements from the Fund, designed to ensure that the new pattern of coastal movements of Bass Strait crude oil following the closure of the BP refinery at Westernport is reflected immediately in the pattern of disbursements. This is done by basing disbursements of levy collected after 1 March 1985 on the most recent six months movements.
This Bill also introduces several minor changes of a drafting nature. The legislation has no financial implications for the Commonwealth. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hodgman) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to implement a number of recent Government decisions in relation to the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the power of the Minister for Communications to prohibit the broadcasting of a matter. The proposed amendments may be summarised as follows: In relation to the miscellaneous amendments to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983, the Bill will address four issues. These are: Firstly, the ABC will be empowered to establish subsidiary companies and joint ventures to undertake authorised business activities; secondly, the position of the staff elected director on the Board of the ABC will be formalised; thirdly, the ABC will be permitted to appoint officers as unattached officers in line with the provisions of the Public Service Act 1922; and fourthly, the forfeiture of office of ABC staff will be provided for in circumstances identical to those provided for in the Public Service Act.

The Bill will also repeal the power of the Minister for Communications to prohibit the broadcasting or televising of any matter. The Minister has the power to prohibit items being broadcast by the Special Broadcasting Service under section 78A of the Broadcasting and Television Act, broadcasting by the commercial licencees under section 99 (3) of the same Act and broadcasting by the ABC under section 78 (1) of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act. It is not expected that these measures will result in any costs to the Commonwealth. While the ABC's power to establish subsidiary companies is designed to establish a more efficient and profitable operation of the Corporation's commercial activities, it is not possible, at this stage, to estimate the amount of dividends or profits that the Corporation will earn. On 17 March 1985, I foreshadowed legislative amendments which would enable the ABC to establish subsidiaries and to enter into other forms of joint venture. The Bill provides that the ABC may form or participate with other persons in the formation of companies, partnerships or other joint ventures which are to carry on an authorised business. An authorised business is, in turn, confined to the current range of the Corporation's permitted activities. The provision does not widen the categories of the Corporation's business activities; it modernises its corporate structure and enables it to join with the private sector in the furtherance of its activities in a more modern business like way.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the ABC is essentially a non-competitive authority operating in a fiercely competitive and commercial environment. It has some commercial operations such as merchandising and concert management; however, the ABC is not at present able to build effectively on its potential for developing such operations solely out of its own resources. The Government considers that by enabling the Corporation to establish subsidiary companies or to enter into joint ventures with other business groups, it will be able more effectively to utilise its expertise and resources. These business enterprises will be required to generate at least sufficient revenue to support their activities and where possible generate returns to the Corporation which may be applied to specific activities or broadcasting purposes such as the encouragement of Australian content in ABC drama productions. Some examples of the types of appropriate activities include concert management, the hiring out of spare capacity, such as film production equipment and studios during seasonal lulls, audience research and program sales.

There is considerable merit in allowing the ABC's commercial activities the same freedom that applies to the activities of a commercial authority such as Telecom. In fact, the legislative amendments are modelled on section 10A of the Telecommunications Act 1975. Government control would be maintained over the types of activities undertaken by the ABC utilising this new power. Before the ABC can enter into such an arrangement or devote funds to it, the approval of the Minister for Communications is necessary. Further, I will consult with the Treasurer and Minister for Finance before reaching any decision on such proposals. Also any agreement or contract between the Corporation and a subsidiary company must include a provision empowering the Corporation to terminate the agreement or contract if the venture ceases to undertake an activity approved by the Minister and the Minister may direct the Corporation to dispose of its interests in the company or terminate the agreement or the contract.

On 18 April 1985 I foreshadowed that the Government intended to provide statutory backing for the position of a staff elected director on the Board of the ABC. As honourable members will be aware, a representative of ABC staff, Mr Thomas Molomby, was appointed to the ABC Board on 15 December 1983. The purpose of these legislative amendments is to formalise the position of a staff elected director on the Board. This director will be automatically appointed to the Board following the declaration of the results of an election by ABC staff. The staff elected director will hold office for a term of two years whereas the other non-executive directors hold office for a period of five years. In other respects the staff elected director will have the same powers and functions as the other non-executive directors. Because of the rather unusual profile of ABC staff, the Bill goes to some lengths to define the eligibility of candidates and electors. Eligibility extends to full time employees who are defined as those who are employed for 24 or more hours per week and to persons who are contracted to perform services for the Corporation under the direction and control of the Managing Director or another officer of the Corporation. The Bill also allows for the staff elected director to have a deputy.

Two further legislative changes will be introduced to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act in respect of ABC staffing arrangements. These changes are consistent with provisions applying in the Australian Public Service. A new provision will empower the Managing Director to appoint a new officer as an unattached officer. This is in line with the power of the Public Service Board under section 42 of the Public Service Act 1922. The introduction of this section will give the ABC greater flexibility in staffing matters and enable it to recruit people to undertake tasks related to a range of positions or areas of work within the ABC.

The second amendment will introduce a forfeiture of office provision for continued absenteeism of ABC staff. The proposed amendment is based on a similar provision in the Public Service Act 1922, section 66A. The provision empowers the Managing Director to notify an officer who is absent on unauthorised leave for an extended period that he will be deemed to have retired unless the officer returns to duty or explains the absence to the Managing Director within two weeks of receiving the notice. As a safeguard an officer who has been deemed to have retired may apply to the Managing Director for reappointment to the Service. Where the Managing Director refuses such an application the officer may appeal to the Disciplinary Appeal Board against the refusal. The Disciplinary Appeal Board may confirm the refusal or recommend to the Managing Director that the appellant be reappointed. The Managing Director must accept such a recommendation.

On 18 April 1985 I announced that the Government intended to seek amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act to repeal the power of the Minister for Communications to prohibit radio and television broadcasts. It is the Government's view that these powers are incompatible with the ideals of a democratic society in peacetime. The exercise of these powers could result in objectionable censorship and the curbing of freedom of speech while providing a means for undue political influence over broadcasters. Section 118 of the Broadcasting and Television Act will continue to make it an offence to broadcast, or render for broadcasting, matters which are blasphemous, indecent or obscene while section 131 of the Broadcasting and Television Act will enable the Minister to exercise complete control over matters to be broadcast during an emergency. Furthermore, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has the power to direct commercial licensees to vary their programs to conform to standards determined by the Tribunal, and it also has the right to censor any matter of an objectionable nature. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hunt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 will amend the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946, the Postal Services Act 1975, the Radiocommunications Act 1983 and the Telecommunications Act 1975. Provisions of this Bill will allow Telecom Australia and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission to enter into currency hedging and financial futures contracts. It will also enable Australia Post, Telecom and OTC to lease property for periods longer than 10 years without the need for approval of the Minister for Communications, providing the cost of the lease does not exceed the current prescribed contract threshold-presently $2m in the case of Telecom and $500,000 in the case of Australia Post and OTC. The Bill also provides for amendments to the Telecommunications Act arising from recommendations of the report of the Vincent Review of Matters Affecting the Australian Telecommunications Commission and imposes a duty on Telecom to ensure its facilities are not used for illegal purposes. Other provisions of the Bill give effect to the recommendations of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest, relating to the disclosure of pecuniary interests by members of statutory bodies.

I will deal firstly with the currency and financial futures provisions of the Bill. In line with the majority of large business enterprises, there is a need for Telecom and OTC to manage their foreign exchange exposure in a prudent and effective manner. As will be appreciated, timing is critical in the placement of forward cover financial and foreign exchange contracts. In the interest of efficiency, the Government believes it is inappropriate to require the commissions to obtain approval for currency hedging or futures contracts when the main contract either is exempt from the requirement for ministerial consent or has already received it. Currency contracts are negotiated and renegotiated quickly in circumstances which make a requirement for ministerial approval impractical.
