This Bill will enable Telecom and OTC to respond efficiently to changing circumstances in financial markets but, at the same time, will prohibit any element of speculation by requiring dealings to be in accordance with guidelines to be determined by the Minister. Such an arrangement provides the flexibility necessary for commercial efficiency while ensuring the appropriate level of ministerial control. The Bill also repeals the requirement for ministerial approval of property leases entered into by Australia Post, Telecom and OTC for periods in excess of 10 years. Where the consideration for such leases exceeds the prescribed contract threshold value the arrangements will fall within the contract approval provisions of the legislation and adequate control will continue to be exercised through that process. As appropriate, the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services would continue to exercise approvals under the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act 1955.

I now turn to the other provisions included in this Bill. In March 1984 the Government appointed Mr F. H. R. Vincent, QC, to review certain allegations in regard to breaches of the laws of the Commonwealth, and impropriety or official misconduct by officers of Telecom. It is now a matter of public record that Mr Vincent concluded that the perception of substantial corruption within Telecom lacked anything remotely approaching an adequate evidentiary base and that any involvement by Telecom employees in starting price betting was relatively minor. The Government's detailed response to the matters raised by Mr Vincent was presented by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) on 13 September last year and it is not my intention to repeat the Minister's comments on this occasion. However, as part of the Government's response, this Bill will implement amendments to the Telecommunications Act arising from recommendations of the Vincent report. Consistent with those recommendations, it is the Government's intention to incorporate into the Act those offences currently in the by-laws and regulations dealing with the misuse of Telecom's network, including the supply, connection and maintenance of lines, apparatus, equipment or fittings, and the alteration or modification of approved private branch exchanges and private lines. The offence provisions in the Act are also intended to cover the use of the telecommunications service for the purpose of menacing another person, the sending of false information, the harassment of a person and the sending of indecent, obscene or offensive communications. The Bill substantially increases the monetary penalties relating to these offences. In a further response to the Vincent report, the Bill provides that Telecom is under a duty, in performing its functions, to use its best endeavours to ensure that its network is not used in, or in the furtherance of, an offence under Commonwealth, State or Territory law.

Other provisions in the Bill include amendments to the present disclosure of interest provisions in the Overseas Telecommunications Act, the Telecommunications Act and the Postal Services Act in order to bring the relevant sections into line with government policy on the disclosure of interests by members of statutory bodies. It also amends the Overseas Telecommunications Act to allow persons over 65 years of age to be appointed and hold office as commissioners. The age limitation will apply only to the office of Managing Director, the only full time commissioner.

Finally, the Bill amends the Radiocommunications Act. It provides for an amendment to the present definition of 'radio transmission' in section 3 (1) by expanding the definition to include transmissions or emissions of electromagnetic energy of frequencies in the range from three terahertz up to 420 terahertz. This amendment provides for the licensing of recently developed systems in infra-red spectrum. Section 65 of the Radiocommunications Act is amended by the Bill to remove the need to make regulations which would otherwise be necessary to protect Royal Flying Doctor Services from interference. The amendment was considered necessary as the role of the Royal Flying Doctor Service is different in kind from the other organisations and services specified in this section of the Act. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hunt) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PURCHASE OF AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING FACILITIES BY THE COMMONWEALTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That, in accordance with paragraph 8 (1) (d) of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, this House refers to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for investigation and report as necessary from time to time, the proposed acquisition of automatic data processing facilities by any Commonwealth department or authority of the Commonwealth staffed under the Public Service Act 1922; notification of intention of which is to be conveyed to the committee by the Minister responsible for the department or authority intending to acquire the facilities.
(2) That this resolution will continue in force unless and until amended or rescinded by the Senate or the House of Representatives in this or a subsequent Parliament.
(3) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting its concurrence.

The passing of the motion now before the House will enable the continued operation of revised procedures introduced in June 1984 to provide a mechanism for independent scrutiny of major individual automatic data processing acquisition proposals by the Commonwealth. The motion is similar in substance to that passed by the House and which received Senate concurrence last June but it provides for the arrangements to remain in force unless and until amended or repealed by this or a subsequent parliament. The reasons underlying last year's procedural revisions remain valid and I canvass them again only briefly. Under present arrangements ADP acquisitions costing less than $2m may be approved by individual Ministers, or those costing less than $1m by departmental heads, subject of course to availability of funds. However, purchases over $2m are submitted for approval in the Budget context.

Given the extent to which computers have become an essential tool in the administrative process, some relatively routine acquisitions can exceed the $2m threshold and can adequately be dealt with in this fashion. The problem is that from time to time some very large acquisition proposals come forward which are of such complexity and which raise such important related issues that they cannot be dealt with comprehensively under the severe pressures imposed by the Budget time-table.

Against this background the Government proposed, and the House has agreed, that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was the most appropriate and well-placed body to review major acquisitions, and to give attention also to associated global issues which could include, for example, such matters as employment considerations, education and retraining requirements, Australian industry participation, industrial issues, cost-effectiveness, and risks associated with the introduction of advanced technology.

In making this proposal, the Government did not, and does not now, ask the Joint Committee of Public Accounts to review Government decisions. The objective remains to allow Parliament, through its Committee, to form a judgment and provide advice before the decision is taken. Additional resources have been provided to the Committee to carry out this important task. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF 14 CHISHOLM PLACE, MELBOURNE, FOR AUSTRALIAN WHEAT BOARD

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969 and by reason of the urgent nature of the work, it is expedient that the following proposed work be carried out without it having been referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works: Development of 14 Chisholm Place, Melbourne, for the Australian Wheat Board.

This motion relates to a proposal which was being developed for reference to the Public Works Committee but which was delayed by the 1984 election. In December 1983 the Committee reported favourably on an Australian Wheat Board proposal to redevelop its headquarters buildings at Ceres House, Lonsdale Street, Melbourne. The House of Representatives resolved that it was expedient to proceed at the estimated cost of $7.17m and construction commenced in May 1984. Later developments, particularly an increase in the estimated rate of staff growth and recommendations by the Independent Committee of Inquiry into Commonwealth Laboratories, culminated in the Wheat Board purchasing a property for further expansion almost adjacent to its headquarters.

This further proposal, estimated to cost $3.93m, was being developed for reference to the Committee late last year. In normal circumstances it would be referred to the new Committee for consideration and report. However, construction within the existing Ceres House headquarters building has reached the point where decisions need to be made about changes to occupancies between the two proposals and, in relation to common services, to avoid slowing down or stopping various elements pending the passage of the proposal through the Public Works Committee processes.

With the House due to rise on 23 May, it is not likely that the proposal could be cleared to proceed until late August or early September, and the cost of such a delay would be about $960,000. This is a substantial potential penalty for the Australian Wheat Board, which is an off-Budget funded authority set up to provide orderly marketing for the Australian wheat industry and to maximise returns to growers. The circumstances have been discussed with the Public Works Committee and advice has been received that there is no objection to exemption being sought on urgency grounds.

A further point for honourable members to take into account is that the estimated cost of the work is less than the proposed revised mandatory reference limit of $6m, which has the support of the Committee, and for which enabling legislation is planned before the House rises for the recess. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning on construction can proceed. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, on behalf of the Opposition I support the motion moved by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West). I note the presence in the chamber of the shadow Minister for Primary Industry and Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt). We go along completely with what the Minister has said. In passing, I just say that there is always likely to be a confusion in relation to agricultural matters if one is not careful to specify what we are talking about. The Minister was in fact talking about the Australian Wheat Board premises at 14 Chisholm Place, Melbourne, which is known as Ceres House. I note with some interest that the blue business sheet indicates that these are premises for the Australian Meat Board, but in fact they are for the Australian Wheat Board.
—Wheat, not meat.

—It is wheat, not meat, as the Deputy Leader of the National Party points out. I am not being critical; I am simply making that point. What is important is that other legislation is coming through very shortly in relation to the Australian Wheat Board. I am sure that the Minister will note with some interest that that Board is one of the few that has representation from five States and not six. The plain fact is that unfortunately Tasmania is not represented on that Board.
—Do they grow wheat there?

—Indeed. Tasmania produces the finest biscuit flour in Australia. The wheat there is not good for bread but the flour from Tasmanian wheat is the finest biscuit flour in Australia. I do not want to pin down the Minister as he has had a very torrid day with his second introduction in four weeks of the same Bill relating to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. I simply want to say to him that in relation to this measure he has support from the Opposition. We look forward to the matter being referred to the Standing Committee on Public Works.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say for the record that the Opposition would not lightly go along with a proposition for exemption, but in this case the Minister has made out a case. I am sure my colleague the Deputy Leader of the National Party would confirm that the Opposition's view is that if we can save $900,000 of taxpayers' money we will do it. In this instance we support the motion moved by the Minister. We wish the Committee all the best in its deliberations and we note with some pleasure that $900,000 of taxpayers' money will be saved by the procedure put to the House, which the Opposition is very pleased to support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DRIED FRUITS CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILLS:DRIED SULTANA PRODUCTION UNDERWRITING AMENDMENT BILL 1985DRIED VINE FRUITS EQUALIZATION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: — Before the debate is resumed on this Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and Orders of the Day No. 7 and No. 8, the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Amendment Bill and the Dried Vine Fruit Equalisation Levy Amendment Bill respectively.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DRIED FRUITS CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you have said, this is a cognate debate on three Bills relating to the dried vine fruit industry-the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill, the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Amendment Bill and the Dried Vine Fruits Equalisation Levy Amendment Bill. The legislation which has been introduced by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) takes account of recent government decisions to look at future assistance arrangements for the dried vine fruits industry. The Minister in his second reading speech outlined the specific details of the various amendments. During the few minutes I have available to speak on the matter I intend to take some time to comment on the broader perspective of the Government's direction in respect of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst some honourable members opposite who have spoken on this matter today have referred specifically to this industry, they have not been able to grasp the fact that the approach being taken is consistent with a broader approach being taken by the Government in respect of the primary sector and our agricultural industries. Principally, the Government's policy is directed towards deregulating the sector, tidying up massive amounts of legislation which seem to interact and correspond, and trying to minimise the time spent in this House debating what are virtually machinery Bills. Most importantly, particularly with respect to this legislation, the Government is bringing the production of our primary products closer to market forces and bringing the primary producers in closer touch with the market realities that they are in fact responding to.

In my first speech in this place, I made reference to what I saw as the direction which ought to be taken by the Government in the primary sector. I commented at that time that honourable members on the other side of the House had continually tried to find one subsidy or protection scheme after another for the various components of the primary sector. I made the observation that that was not what the industries needed; they needed orderly and creative marketing and co-ordination of their productive capacities. That, in fact, is what is involved in this legislation.

I also made reference to the concern of the Minister for Primary Industry and his formation of the Government's primary industry, rural and provincial affairs committee, which is playing a significant role in ensuring that the Government's legislation in this sector brings the needs of country and rural Australia completely into co-ordination and integration with the activities of the Government.

Looking at this specific legislation, as I mentioned earlier, we intend particularly to bring the dried vine fruit industry more in touch with direct market forces. The principal impact of the legislation will be to increase the membership of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation by an additional two members, who will be specifically qualified in the area of dried fruit production. The principal objectives of that provision are to bring closer to the industry the realities of the increasing complexity of international marketing of dried vine fruit and to enhance the effectiveness of statutory marketing authorities. By providing for the appointment of two additional specially qualified members to the Corporation, we are trying to bring to the industry their skills in commerce, finance and marketing affairs. I believe that the Government is to be commended for that approach. The two members who will be added to the Corporation will considerably widen the Corporation's expertise. That will reflect in its performance and in the functions that it carries out.

I also make the point that this is not an isolated piece of legislation directed at a particular industry. It is consistent with directions being taken across the board, and the same sort of legislation and approach has been taken in the amendments to legislation on the dairy industry that have been introduced in this House. I think it is fair to make the observation that the past philosophy of those who were in government was virtually to produce export earnings at any cost. The dried vine fruit industry has had this approach applied to it. It has led to the situation where products which have been exported in order to derive rural export dollars have been obtained from markets which have not been viable and sold at prices which have not been viable. In the end the industry has been supported by the domestic market via a levy arrangement that the previous Government established. In other words, domestic consumers of the products of this industry, in the prices that they pay, have had to bear the burden of what amounts to highly unprofitable exports.

Now there is a need to bring production back within the realms of our domestic needs until we as a government can develop better opportunities for profitable export that this industry can respond to. Two areas are to be considered in respect of that approach. Firstly, there is the relationship of the levy as it exists in the industry to the export price; and, secondly, some attention needs to be given to the level of assistance which we will be continuing to provide for growers in the industry. That is another matter that has been commented on during the day by honourable members on the other side of the chamber. Again, it reflects their failure to perceive what is actually taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many dried fruit farmers do you have in your electorate?

—The honourable member will be able to tell us how many he has later. I will tell him about it as we go along. If we are going to talk about my experience, I suggest to the honourable member that I have lived longer in these areas and have spoken directly with these people about a more sensible arrangement on which to structure their approach and their industry than he has. I would be interested in hearing what he has to say later.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to observe how the relationship of the levy to the export price has operated in the past. The returns for each variety of dried fruit, whether it is sultanas, currants or raisins, have been equalised by imposing a levy on domestic sales and distributing the proceeds over all sales. The levy has, in practice, as the Minister observed when introducing the Bill, served to defend a particular level of domestic price by reflecting the difference between the domestic and estimated average export returns. Until recently the domestic price has been able to move roughly in line with consumer price index movements irrespective of prices on export markets. In other words, the difference between domestic and export prices has made sales on the Australian market highly vulnerable to import pressures.

The present equalisation arrangements provide for levels of assistance that fluctuate widely. In recent times that has been very high. The Industries Assistance Commission, which has been asked to investigate this industry and give a report, has commented that these arrangements have enabled domestic prices to subsidise export sales, disguising the true return from exports-these are not my words, they are the words of the Industries Assistance Commission-and encouraging a greater level of dried vine fruit production than is profitable for the industry. The effect that that has had ought to be taken into account. The industry itself recognises the need to reduce the level of production to that which can be sold profitably. The Government considers that the assistance provided through equalisation payments should be more stable and should make the industry more responsive to market signals. To achieve this the Government has decided to reduce progressively the maximum proportion of equalisation payments to average export returns.

I mentioned earlier that we also need to look at the general level of assistance to the industry that comes about as a result of these changes. I think that is important because the new arrangements are expected to provide roughly the same amount of assistance on average as at present. In other words, the producers are not suddenly being expected to face the realities of the market overnight; we are continuing the level of assistance while adjustments take place in the industry. However, with the system being based on returns from exports only rather than returns from all sales, underwriting will be more sensitive to the sharp falls in world market prices and will be more effective in providing the protection intended.

As an example, I will make a comparison of the new and the current systems and apply them to the data that has been made available in respect of production in 1982. Under the current arrangements, $16.38 per tonne was paid via the levy assistance. Had the new arrangements been in operation, $61 per tonne would have been payable. The effect of this assistance to the industry is to maintain current levels, but it is directed specifically to those producing for the export market. In conclusion, the legislation in respect of the dried vine fruits industry is a classic example of the problem that the Government inherited after years and years of establishing schemes for subsidies and protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been highly successful.

—It is a classic example. I know the farmers in this area. I will be interested to hear the comments which the honourable member for Mallee has to make about them. They are not Collins Street farmers. They are very hard-working and they have lived in the area for years. Some of them are very close to rural poverty. They are blockies with high debts. They have been completely exposed to fluctuations, such as growing conditions that change from one year to another, market fluctuations and interest rate fluctuations. Let me talk about that for a moment. I am sure that there is a significant difference in the operation of their industry under the current economic policies than under those which we inherited. One asks: How did the situation develop in this way? It has developed over years. Our predecessors had no overall strategy, just a piecemeal approach. Now these people in the industry have laid down a consistent approach that spreads across the whole primary industry sector. The Government is to be commended for taking the bit between the teeth, taking decisions and introducing a direction that those on the other side of the House simply have not been capable of taking.

SPEECH.PARA: In summing up, I would just say that these measures will encourage ongoing adjustment within the industry to place viable producers on a stronger footing in the long term. Numerous producers of dried vine fruits earn very low incomes from their farms for reasons such as inadequate farm areas or excessive debt structures. Basically they have no prospects of becoming economically viable. It is our intention to assist those growers as they move out of the industry in order for production to achieve levels that are economically viable. In saying that, I believe, as I mentioned earlier, that the decisions of the Government follow on from the report of the Industries Assistance Commission. We asked the Commission to inquire into the assistance needs of the industry because world market prices had fallen sharply. Under pressure from a major surplus of fruit, the industry was experiencing considerable financial difficulties. We have come to grips with the hard questions. I believe the Minister is to be commended for the steps that he is taking. With pleasure I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is currently considering cognately the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill, the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Amendment Bill and the Dried Vine Fruits Equalisation Levy Amendment Bill. I was interested in the comments made by the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) who was the first Labor back bencher to speak on these measures. A number of my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties have already spoken. At any rate, I welcome the honourable member's interest in this subject and his comment that he knows many of these hard-working blocky irrigators and operators in this vital primary industry. I wonder just how well he knows them and how much he really believes this package will help those people. I am not going to ask him to believe me in terms of answering that charge. I am going to ask him to believe the comments of the Australian Dried Fruits Association, ADFA, which is an independent, non-partisan organisation, as to what will be the consequences of this package. I ask the honourable member for Burke to consider what ADFA had to say about the package which the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has brought in here-not the comments of members of the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party, but those of a vital industry organisation which has researched this subject in a great deal of detail, as one would expect, and has capably carried the burden of the work in respect of this legislation in the industry's very difficult months recently.

SPEECH.PARA: ADFA contends that in the main there will be eight key consequences resulting from the adoption of this legislation. Firstly, the rejection of a market entitlement scheme prevents the formulation of an industry production target and fails to provide the clear market signals needed by growers, which is in direct answer to what the honourable member for Burke has said here tonight. Secondly, there will be greater instability in returns to growers in future years due to equalisation levy ceilings. These ceilings will force Australian prices for DVF to fluctuate widely. Thirdly, the low prices for any period on the Australian market would be the base for future prices. Returns to growers lost from the Australian market in any period would not be recovered but would be compounded forward.

Fourthly, the peaks demonstrated by the Government's equalisation levy formula would be unobtainable because of market pressures. For example, the Government formula when applied to past seasons shows that a price increase of up to 37 per cent should theoretically have been applied to the Australian market. However, the market would reject any price increase of that magnitude-of course it would-and if forced upon buyers would result in dramatic losses in sales and an increased export dependence for the industry. Fifthly, periods of low Australian prices could be forced on the industry and lead to dramatically reduced returns to growers because of pressures from buyers and the availability of imported fruit.

Sixthly, there is no increased protection from imports. While an import duty of $200 per tonne is retained, its real value is being rapidly eroded by inflation. Seventhly, the ADFA believes that the $5m adjustment money is inadequate to grapple with the adjustment of the industry needed. For example, even if the sum were fully expended on vine pull compensation less than 5,000 tonnes of production would be likely to be removed from the industry. Finally, the ADFA-not the National Party, not the Liberal Party-believes that there must be considerable doubt as to whether the $5m funding for adjustment will in fact be achieved. For the first time for a rural adjustment program, contributions will be required from the States. It is known that Victoria, the State with the greatest DVF adjustment need, may be reluctant to support the scheme under the terms announced by the Commonwealth. Significantly, there appears to have been little, if any, consultation with the States prior to the announcement, and no commitment of any State funds to date.

I ask the House, the honourable member for Burke and others to consider that they are the findings of the ADFA in respect of this legislative package before the House. Indeed, it is a tragedy that there has been this great lack of consultation with all sections of the industry by the Minister for Primary Industry. I accept that he is a busy man; nevertheless, so important is this industry and so vital is the legislative package that he has brought to the House on this occasion that he should have made the effort to make an extensive visit along the Murray River and to other key parts of the industry, especially into the Sunraysia in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), to my electorate of Farrer and also to the South Australian electorates in which we find so many of these people in absolutely desperate circumstances. Whilst I do not in any way blame the Minister for those desperate circumstances, he does have responsibility to move capably to adjust the situation. Instead, he has presented a package which, as I said, the Australian Dried Fruits Association has rejected.

I support the amendment so capably moved by the shadow Minister for Primary Industry and Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). In fact, I venture to suggest that perhaps the amendment could have gone even further because what we are asking for is time for this industry to adjust to the circumstances which are now prevailing and to the realities of the world market. It is interesting to hear the honourable member for Burke say that this is all part of Labor's consistent package to deregulate primary industries and inject market reality into every primary industry without qualification. Had the honourable member for Burke continued on that line I would have offered him membership of the modest members society and certainly he would have been welcomed into the club of economic dries.

Indeed, I think in one sense the honourable member was slightly accurate but he and this Government have stopped short with their half-hearted approach to deregulation. On the one hand they advocate the deregulation of a particular industry in isolation; on the other hand, that industry then has to survive against a totally regulated labour market, against a totally structured industrial award system which has little flexibility an makes little allowance for penalty rules. It is impossible for the industry to survive in such circumstances. That is why I reject the thrust of the comment by the honourable member for Burke. He and, indeed, the Minister and the Government are forcing half-hearted, half-baked deregulation packages on sections of industry, including the dairy industry and, in terms of this legislation, the dried fruits industry, without addressing the underlying major problem area of the inflexible labour market in this country.

In January, shortly after my election as the member for Farrer, in conjunction with the honourable member for Mallee and State colleagues in the Sunraysia area, I attended a number of meetings and deputations with many organisations in that area who expressed their concern about the Industries Assistance Commission report. Perhaps I should tell the House what happened to a copy of the IAC report on one occasion. It was ceremoniously buried in a coffin in Deakin Avenue, the main street of Mildura.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been resurrected.

—As the Deputy Leader of the National Party has pointed out, it has been resurrected in this legislation. Worse still, the thrust of all that is contained in this package will mean a return of this industry to the IAC at a later stage this decade. That is a bitter and costly pill for the dried fruits industry. As the honourable member for Mallee said earlier today, it is one that the dried fruits industry can ill afford. So many other industries which have to go before the IAC are reaching a stage where they are finding it very difficult to mount a substantive case because of the costs involved. This is especially so if they are not one of the major primary industries but are one of the smaller and more localised regional primary industries.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the House that the Minister has not realised the true impact of his legislation. I put it to the House that the Minister has not appreciated the massive hardship being faced by many irrigators on both sides of the State borders-in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, along the Murray River, and elsewhere in Australia-where the circumstances of farmers are ones of poverty, as the honourable member for Burke correctly suggested. Indeed, they suffer very real poverty levels, despite the many hours of work they put in for very little return. Unfortunately, on the face of it the legislation seeks to address this problem area. However, in reality it fails to address the problem in terms that would be acceptable and would solve the real problems associated with the dried fruits industry.

I share the reservations of my colleagues in relation to the legislation. I support strongly the amendment moved by my colleague the Deputy Leader of the National Party. There has to be an appreciation of the contribution of just under $200m each year which is made by the dried fruits industry. It is a decentralised industry which, to some extent, came about as a result of the post-World War II land settlement programs. As such, perhaps it deserves a greater measure of responsibility and obligation than do most other industries in terms of providing sufficient time for adjustment.

I am a realist. As I said before, I am a qualified free trader. I accept that there has to be change, that there has to be rationalisation. Equally, I submit to the Minister and to the House that there has to be time to allow this to happen without casting hundreds upon hundreds of dried fruit operators out into the cold without further adding to their hardship. In fact, the package before the House will do just that. Many of the blocks which were developed on the Victorian side after the Second World War in particular were of an uneconomic size. It is taking time and a process of adjustment is occurring. It is very sad that the odd boom that did occur, especially at the start of this decade, was not taken as a wonderful opportunity for the governments of those days, State and Federal, to seek to bring about a measure of adjustment when there was a margin to ease that adjustment in. Instead the adjustment comes at a very harsh time for the industry. It is always fashionable to knock a primary industry when it is on its knees.

The Australian Dried Fruits Association and other organisations with which both I and the honourable member for Mallee have been associated on this matter have put in an enormous amount of very capable work in respect of this legislation. I reiterate that they see it as being a package which will not provide what the Minister for Primary Industry sets out as objectives in terms of the important and decentralised dried fruits industry. I ask the Minister utilising the time delay with passage of the legislation through the Senate to give the legislation further consideration and to support the amendment brought forward by the Deputy Leader of the National Party. As I said at the outset, deregulation has a lot of intrinsic merit but cannot be considered in isolation. This package is in a sense an attempt at speedy deregulation in one industry, in one part of the equation without deregulating the labour market and without providing relief in other areas, such as the tax burden and the record high fuel prices which prevail in this country and which impact so heavily on my electors in Farrer and indeed on all country electorates.

The lack of sympathy shown by this Government to the farm cost situation in general is causing very real concern throughout rural Australia and it should be looked at again. If the matter is not considered before, at least we hope that in the course of the taxation summit sympathetic consideration will be given to farm costs so that there might be some relief through realistic changes to the tax structure, especially the tax structure on fuel, which is biting so hard in country areas.

I hold many reservations in relation to the legislative package before the House. I support the amendment moved by the Opposition. I hope very careful consideration will be given to the true impact of this package because it is a devastating package which will do a great deal of damage to a very important decentralised industry in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to sum up the debate and again thank the honourable members who have participated in it. Many honourable members have pointed out, with respect to the tale of this industry, that there are some people in desperate economic circumstances. The price of entry to this industry is not very high. A lot of people were sucked in by the high prices in 1980 and 1981 and were financed into the industry at terms that were not able to be met in terms of the industry's economic future over a longer period. In other words, it was a bit like the sugar industry; there was a very big increase in prices for a year or two and a lot of people took decisions on the basis of that rather than on the longer term prospects for the industry. The Opposition has relied pretty much on the telex from the Australian Dried Fruits Association in reaction to the Government's announced plans and, of course, I too have received that information. The National Party of Australia tonight in this House is again playing the old trick of trying to do what the industry wants it to do regardless of the industry's longer term needs or of any general consideration of government policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I will pick up some of the points that were made during the debate. The legislation is the result of pretty widespread consultation. It follows an Industries Assistance Commission report and industry consultation. There have been extensive discussions at meetings of the Australian Agricultural Council and I have met many people from the industry in my office, as well as having visited the Victorian and New South Wales areas of the industry two or three times since I have been Minister.

Another point concerned increased membership of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. I say simply that this is in line with the Government's policy of making statutory marketing authorities more commercially effective. The Opposition must realise that this industry comprises very few organisations. It is a very tightly run industry. I think that there is a little too much of hat swapping between the ADFA, the packers and the Corporation. In other words, it will not hurt the Corporation to have some additional members who will perhaps bring new insights to the industry, because the group of people from which one can select members of this Corporation is quite limited. The industry is quite regionally concentrated. There is only a handful of packers. It was the belief of the industry, and certainly of some members of the Corporation, that having two people with additional marketing expertise would enhance the thinking on the Corporation's board. The industry has been requesting that there be a market entitlement scheme. We certainly analysed that proposal in great depth. At the same time, although that was the Association's policy it has certainly been brought to my attention since the Government made this announcement that many people are very happy that we did not take the decision with respect to an entitlement scheme. Quite frankly, the indications were that there would be available a 100,000-tonne grape surplus for crushing into wine. If we inserted a two-pool entitlement scheme, the returns from the export market-if that is the price that one sets for the second part of the two-pool scheme-would be about $100 a tonne fresh rate versus a minimum South Australian price of $185 a tonne. In other words, we might have kept up the end of the dried vine fruits industry, but those people introducing multi-purpose grapes-whether they are diverting them into wine, dried fruit or table grapes-would have received less revenue if an entitlement scheme had been put in place.

While some reduction in production is desirable, there is no intention of defining specific production targets; rather, the industry should have clearer market signals so that producers are better informed. This is being achieved through changes to the equalisation arrangements. I do not believe it is responsible government policy to encourage people to invest in an industry unless one is prepared to continue to subsidise the industry. There is no sense in encouraging people into an industry to do their money, on the basis of industry arrangements that represent a false market picture for the person investing his money.

The equalisation arrangements are to provide an equalised return for all fruit, both domestic and export, which by 1990 will be no higher than 15 per cent above the average export return. The equalisation scheme does not allow the defence of domestic price movements in line with the consumer price index, irrespective of market circumstances. There has been quite a bit of confusion and misunderstanding regarding the proposed amended equalisation arrangements. That confusion is shared by the ADFA and the Opposition. While the arrangements will enable clearer market signals to be provided to producers, the arrangements will continue to provide for a considerable consumer transfer, even at the stage at which the equalised returns over all fruit are no more than 15 per cent above the average export return.

The following example illustrates the amount by which the equalisation arrangement could enable domestic prices to be above average export prices at the 15 per cent level. It is very difficult to cite numbers and expect people to understand them, but at least the example will be in Hansard and people can read it at their leisure and do the sums. If we assume that the Australian production is 65,000 tonnes and of that amount 45,000 tonnes are exported and 20,000 tonnes are sold on the domestic market, which is similar to the expected situation for the 1985 season, and if we also assume that the average export return is $1,000 per tonne-and thus at the 15 per cent level the maximum equalised return would be $1,150 per tonne-this would enable a domestic price of $1,488 per tonne, which is almost 50 per cent above the average export price. The working is as follows: The overall equalised return of $1,150 per tonne multiplied by the total production of 65,000 tonnes gives an overall return of $74,750,000. Deduct the return from exports of 45,000 tonnes multiplied by $1,000 per tonne, or $45m, and it leaves a return from domestic sales of $29,750,000. Divide the domestic return of $29,750,000 by the number of tonnes sold on the domestic market-that is, 20,000 tonnes-and it gives $1,488 per tonne which, as I said, is nearly 50 per cent higher. The formula, even at the 15 per cent level, allows for that level of protection to be in the present arrangements. Everyone is assuming that it is only a flat 15 per cent. With a higher proportion of fruit being exported, the domestic price allowed by the arithmetic is higher and the converse applies.

The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) raised the question of the industry not being protected by indexation-that is, that there is no consumer price index element in the formula-and pointed out that the industry has to compete in a situation in which the prices for inputs, including labour, is indexed. I guess that argument has a lot of currency in the bush at present, but by and large farmers are business people and business incomes are not indexed. I am quite happy to concede the fact that labour markets do not clear because prices for labour never move downwards, but I also point out that, while we have a mixed economy and while we have business people, governments in our sort of society do not index business incomes. If we were in the business of indexing business incomes, it would follow eventually that government would determine what was produced and how it was produced. That is one of the simple facts of the sort of society we live in. Ours is a mixed economy. The Australian Labor Party has no desire to so totally regulate primary industries in which people are investing their money.

To pick up some of the other points made by the honourable member for Farrer, I sympathise with the points he made about the tariff level. It has been at about $200 per tonne for a considerable time. But at least we can now recognise that the Greek fruit has been effectively countervailed and the United States fruit which was coming in has been effectively kept out by devaluation. So some of that pressure has been removed from the industry.

The Opposition proposes to stop at the third stage of phasing in in 1988, with some talk of an Industries Assistance Commission review then. The Opposition has assumed that the domestic price would, in theory, be that which arithmetically results from having an equalised price that is 15 per cent above the export price. I think I have already dealt with that matter. However, at times when world prices are very high, it would be unrealistic to expect the domestic returns to be set at a level which reflects an equalised return that is 15 per cent above the export price. At times when the world price is particularly low there is a constraint on the domestic price which can be supported by the equalisation arrangements but there is no constraint on the domestic price set by market forces. When world prices are very low the $200 per tonne duty in place still provides relatively higher protection as it is set in terms of a specific rate. In calendar year 1984 the average value of duty for imports was $1,104 per tonne, so the ad valorem equivalent of the $200 duty was 18 per cent.

Growers are receiving considerable protection from large falls in export prices for sultanas through the revised underwriting provisions which will now be more sensitive to price changes. I do not think it is appropriate to introduce a system which is subject to review after two or three years. It would create uncertainty and inhibit the adjustment which is needed to put those who are remaining in the industry on a stronger footing. It is not realistic for non-viable producers to expect a guarantee that they will stay in the industry regardless of changes in market circumstances. Some producers must need to adjust out of the industry. The new equalisation arrangements in place, while continuing to provide considerable assistance, will help get through clearer market signals to assist in the decision-making process. Assistance for adjustment is provided through the rural adjustment scheme and dried vine fruit growers will be helped by the provision of this additional $5m.

Underwriting is not to be applied to currants and raisins. Their production is much lower and the IAC believes that underwriting is not needed at this time. Quite frankly, last year's volumes were so low that no equalisation was applied. In the 1985 season production levels are estimated at 66,000 tonnes of sultanas, 5,000 tonnes of currants and 1,860 tonnes of raisins, so at present the volumes of currants and raisins do not justify underwriting.

I conclude by dealing with comments by the honourable member for Farrer on the $5m adjustment package. I can assure him that there has been a lot of consultation with the States and officials on this matter. The IAC suggested that if the $5m was used entirely for a vine pool scheme a payment of about $2,500 per hectare or about $24,200 for an average size block could be made, reducing production by about 10,000 tonnes. Most of the discussions took place last December with State government rural finance officers. There was a clear indication that adjustment assistance additional to the RAS was needed and that, especially for Victoria, a vine pool appeared to be appropriate. The New South Wales Government did not see it as clearly as that. It does not have quite the problems that are faced in Victoria. By and large there was agreement that existing funds in RAS Part A would be available.

In an earlier debate today I pointed out that the States have accumulated a lot of money under the rural adjustment scheme since 1977. One estimate by the Commonwealth-I cannot verify it exactly here-is that the Victorian Government has accumulated something like $100m in funds as a result of its operations of the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that in a trust fund?

—I do not know. On 26 April this year, once the scheme had been announced, I wrote to my ministerial counter parts in the States and asked whether the State governments wished to participate in the scheme. Thought through responses are still awaited but there is no indication that the States are not prepared to participate and the discussions I have had also privately with officials from the departments indicate that we will develop this package. To get 10,000 tonnes out with $5m will certainly help some of the people who are in the most distressed state in this industry at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.
